PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir,

I have the honour to enclose requisition from H. W. VanderVeen for teacher's desk and pupils' desks for use in the Ahousaht Day School, which I understand is about to open. I would recommend that these desks be supplied the school.

Enc.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Mr. Chas. A. Cox,
Indian Agent,
Alberni, B.C.

Dear Sir:

As desks and seats are absolute requirements in conducting a school I desire to make requisition on the department for the following:

1. Teachers' desk.
24. Seats and desks for the children.

Yours truly,

H.W. Vandersteen.
Ottawa, Aug. 30, 1927.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st instant enclosing a requisition from Mr. H. W. VanderVeen teacher of the Ahousaht Day School asking for 1 teacher's desk and 24 children's desks.

You did not state the size of the children's desks required.

Kindly supply this information at once to the Globe Furniture Co., Waterloo, Ont. to whom the Department is writing today instructing them to forward 24 children's desks and 1 teacher's desk on receipt of a letter from you stating the size of children's desks required.

Your obedient servant,

Chas. A. Cox, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Alberni, B. C.
Ottawa, Aug. 30, 1917.

Sir,

The Department requires 1 teacher's desk and 24 children's desks for the Ahousaht Day School. Mr. Agent Cox, Alberni, B.C., is being requested to inform you at once what size of desks are required.

On receipt of a letter from him, you will be good enough to ship 1 teacher's desk No. 121 in your catalogue and 24 children's desks of the size ordered by Mr. Cox.

Your obedient servant,

Received Nov. 14, 1917

H.W. Vander Veen
Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith lists of Ahousaht school children, as directed in your letter of January 30th, 1940.

In referring to the report of Capt. Barry in connection with proposed day school at Ahousaht, the situation has not been materially changed by the destruction of the residential school.

The two class rooms remain, but will require some repair at an approximate cost of $90.00, and I quite agree that these buildings would not be worth transporting to another site. The residence referred to was built by the Department, although on Church property, and was not much damaged by the fire. This could be used as a residence for the teacher if necessary, and I would strongly recommend that the teacher be a married man whose wife is a qualified nurse.

My reason for this lies in the fact that for many years a nurse has been employed at the school, and the natives have become dependent upon her for every minor illness and treatment, and unlike those at other reserves have lost their native self-reliance.

The proposed site for the new school is very good except for water and it would be necessary to dig and protect a well, as the water supply on the reserve is very poor.

The number of school age pupils as mentioned by Capt. Barry is overestimated, and possibly Capt. Barry took in the total pupilage at the school. This was made up as follows:

| Ahousaht Band | 42 |
|---------------|----|
| Others        | 30 |

Of this total, the thirty of the other bands will go to Alberni school, and of the Ahousaht Band approximately twenty-two will also have to go there, leaving only twenty for the day school.

D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
P. O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.
Under date of January 31, 1940, Department Letter 159-2-5, I am instructed by Mr. Phelan that the Church has requested that two teachers be retained for the day school, which request is approved. Capt. Barry, however, will be better able to judge as to the necessity for more than one, as recommended by me in my report on the fire.

With reference to size of the proposed school, it should not be necessary to provide for more than thirty-five pupils, and would also not need other than red cedar sills, which can be procured locally.

No provision need be made for manual training, as these people are all boat builders and can give the children practical training on the beach opposite the front of school site, as proposed.

It would appear from a study of the lists attached that a large percentage would need to go to residential school and this is accounted for by reason of the migratory habits of the people, who follow the fishing around the Coast and are absent from the village for many months of the year, also of course to adverse home conditions in many cases.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

January 16th 1940.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O.Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

I would refer you to the contents of Departmental letter 159-2-5 in regard to the construction of an Indian Day School at Ahousaht, West Coast Agency. Mr Hoey's letter is dated January 8th.

The present Ahousaht Indian Residential School is the property of the Woman's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada. It is not located on an Indian Reserve, but to the south of Mark-to-sis Indian Reserve, Ahousaht Band No. 15, and situated between the small bay and the lake as shown on Plan 3 of the Clayoquot Sound Indian Reserves in your possession.

At the present Ahousaht Indian Residential School there are two classrooms located in a simple long building with windows all on one side. This building is worth very little, and in any case being on United Church land is not the property of the Department. I have no doubt that in any case the material would be worth taking apart, transporting some half mile along a board walk through the woods to the middle of the Ahousaht village.

The teachers of the school at present live in the residential school building, which will of course be useless to us when the new Alberni Indian Residential School building is ready for occupation.

At the present Ahousaht Residential School there is a good house for the Missionary or Principal. This was erected late in 1936 I believe for it is first mentioned in my report on the school dated April 15th 1937, see confidential covering letter.

On Page 17 of my School Survey, West Coast Agency, forwarded to you in its final form on January 31, 1938 I recommended the erection of a one room day school at Ahousaht, and large enough to accommodate 35 pupils.

It was suggested that this new school should be located on the high piece of rocky land in front of the Indian village of Ahousaht. It was explained that this site is on the sea, and has large village greens on each side, a path at the rear or village side and the sea in front. It is in many ways an excellent site, is of course on the Indian Reserve, and as the Indians would no doubt like to have the new school in their own village it should not be difficult to obtain the surrender of sufficient land for this purpose.
Conditions have somewhat changed since my Survey Report was made on this West Coast Agency, and as it has now been decided to move a number of the pupils from Ucqualeetza to the new Alberni Indian Residential School a larger local day school will be needed at Ahousaht than was suggested in January 1938.

Provision should be made for the maximum number of pupils that can be taught by one teacher, and I would suggest that the actual schoolroom should be large enough to accommodate forty five children in place of the thirty five previously suggested.

The actual number of children of school age and under now at Ahousaht has changed since my survey was made, but no doubt the Indian Agent could supply the present figures. It may be taken as granted that there would be around forty pupils available as soon as the present residential school at Ahousaht was closed down.

The lumber mentioned in my above quoted Survey Report as available at the Ahousaht Residential School has now been used for other purposes.

I never considered that a cement basement would be necessary at Ahousaht, though there weather is very damp. The fact that funds are to be strictly limited leads me to recommend that one large schoolroom with the usual entrance halls is all that is necessary, for the main building. Two toilets and a woodshed would also be required.

As previously suggested the teacher could no doubt have room and board at the fairly new house used at present by Mr A.E.Caldwell, provided that the United Church intends to locate a Missionary at Ahousaht.

If the United Church is unable to provide accommodation for a teacher it will be necessary to change the type of day school and to include a residence for the teacher. The Department may consider that in any case this would be better. In this case the type of school erected at Pemberton would be best and a cement basement would be necessary.

The location suggested above for the new Ahousaht Indian Day School is within a few hundred yards of the whole of the Indian homes.

Apart from the list of pupils who will be available in September 1940 for such a school at Ahousaht, and which you can obtain of course from Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge, I believe that I have covered most of the points raised by Mr Hoey. If the school is to be of the size I recommend and taught by one teacher, probably a girl, there would be no need for provision of a Manual Training room. Should it be decided to add a teacher's residence as at Pemberton, provision could be made for Manual Training in the cement basement then necessary.

I hope that the information given here together with that in my previous reports on the West Coast Agency educational needs will enable the Department to gain a fairly accurate picture of the conditions.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant you may purchase dishes and equipment for the Ahousaht Indian Day School at a cost not exceeding $42.00. For the period March 1 to June 30, 1940, an amount of $18.00 a month will be allowed for the purchase of supplies for the midday meal.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent,
Port Alberni, B. C.
Sir:

I have the honour to submit a request of Mr. A. E. Caldwell, on behalf of the temporary day school recently established at Ahousaht, for permission to provide a mid-day meal.

As the location of the temporary school is quite a distance from the village, I would respectfully recommend that this be granted to the end of June, as it will also be a relief measure to the parents of these children who were formerly pupils of the Residential School.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I have your telegram of the 6th instant requesting authority to open a day school at Ahousaht. In this connection I would refer you to official letter of January 31 from Indian Agent Ashbridge a copy of which was forwarded to you at that time and should have reached you before the date that your wire was sent.

You should instruct Mr. Ashbridge to notify us regarding the exact date on which day school activities commence. At the same time you should have the two teachers prepare and forward the usual questionnaire forms which are enclosed.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B. C.

INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH DEPT OF MINES AND RESOURCES OTTAWA ONT

REQUEST AUTHORITY TO OPEN DAY SCHOOL AT THOUSAHT USING OLD CLASSROOMS FOR THIS PURPOSE FORTY CHILDREN AVAILABLE TO ATTEND SEE AGENTS REPORT ON FIRE FORWARDED BY AIR MAIL THIS OFFICE YESTERDAY PLEASE WIRE REPLY

D M MACKAY.
Ottawa, January 8, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am anxious to secure from you the fullest possible information in respect to the construction of an Indian day school at Ahousaht. In the 1940-41 estimates, despite drastic reductions in every branch of the government service, including our own branch, we succeeded in retaining an item of $3,500 for the construction of a school at Ahousaht to serve the pupils now in attendance at the residential school at that point. It is my understanding that a teacher's residence, the property of the United Church, already exists on the Ahousaht site. We have no information at our disposal, however, to indicate whether or not the present school is actually located on an Indian reserve. If the present buildings are on a reserve, would it be necessary to purchase a site for the new school? Should this school have full basement accommodation for vocational instruction? Would it be possible to secure a sketch of the site, the location of the present buildings and the distance of the school buildings from the Indian homes? I should like to know, also, to what extent we will be able to secure lumber from any of the present buildings that may be abandoned when the new school is erected.

Dear Major MacKay:

As requested I have given consideration to the contents of Mr Indian Agent Ashbridge's letter 4887/40/C of the 9th instant with reference to the erection of an Indian day school at Ahousaht.

The present classroom buildings used formerly by the children attending the Ahousaht Indian Residential School are unsuitable for a permanent Indian day school at Ahousaht and are not worth moving. I agree with the Indian Agent that some repair work might well be done at once to make it possible to carry on the education of the Ahousaht children for the balance of the present academic year and until the new school on the village site is ready for occupation.

While a married man as teacher, and particularly one whose wife was a qualified nurse would be of the greatest possible value at Ahousaht, the fact remains that we may not be able to secure such a teacher in the near future. I am informed that there will be a small surplus of teachers as soon as the Normal School term ends, but these will be for the most part young teachers and mainly girls.

The residence mentioned in this correspondence though erected by the Department appears to be on the United Church property and it may be the intention of the Church to have a resident missionary here, hence my suggestion that a girl teacher of the proposed new Ahousaht Indian day school might be able to have room and board in this residence, and thus obviate the necessity for the erection of a residence attached to the proposed new school.

When I suggested that there would be around 40 pupils available for the new day school at Ahousaht I took it for granted that most of the Ahousaht children, stated by the Indian Agent to be 42 in his last letter quoted above, would attend such a school. If however it is necessary for some 22 of these to go to the new Alberni Indian Residential School there could still be around twenty available for the proposed school, and my former recommendation of a one classroom building that is a school for one teacher still holds good. It should be large enough to take up to 45 children in case the attendance increases here and fewer pupils from Ahousaht can be accommodated at Alberni.

I note that the Indian Agent does not consider that the retention of two teachers at the temporary Ahousaht Indian Day School is necessary. If there are only 42 pupils in the Ahousaht Band the average attendance would hardly be in excess of 30, and one teacher could handle this quite well.
Mr Ashbridge however states that the Department in letter 159-2-5 dated January 31, 1940 has approved of the retention of two teachers at the present temporary Ahousaht Indian Day School, and it is therefore not necessary for me to make any recommendation.

It is of course fairer to the two teachers to allow them to retain their positions till the end of June 1940, but they will now I suppose be paid directly by the Department and not out of per capita grant.

It might be as well to let these teachers know as soon as the Department has come to a decision with regard to the future Ahousaht Indian Day School, for no doubt their services will be terminated at the end of the present academic year in June, and they should be given an opportunity to obtain other employment for the year 1940-41.

This letter should of course be read in continuation of my former letter on this subject dated January 18th 1940.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

I have to refer to your letter of May 30th enclosing a copy of a letter from Rev. R. B. Cochrane, Secretary, Board of Home Missions, United Church of Canada, in the matter of a location for a Day School at Ahousaht.

I may say that the suggestion that one or more of the remaining buildings of the Residential School unit be used as a Day School was considered some time ago and it was decided then that the site was too far from the village and as a considerable expenditure would be required to put the buildings in condition for our requirements, it would be desirable for these and other reasons to build the school in the Ahousaht village itself.

My own opinion is that the distance from the village to the old Residential School site is too far for the children to walk, especially in cold, wet, stormy weather, of which they have considerable on the West Coast. This distance would not be considered too great in settled communities or in an open farming country, but there are certain risks in having children traverse such a distance through uninhabited densely wooded country by trail, that should not be overlooked. There is no doubt in my mind that the attendance would be much better if the school were located in the village, and the presence of the teacher daily among the Indian people should be helpful to them in many respects. After careful consideration of all the circumstances, I am satisfied that it would be in the best interests of the Indians and the Department to build the school in the village, as proposed, and would appreciate receipt of the Department's decision in this matter at an early date.

Copies of letters from Mr. Inspector Barry and Mr. Ashbridge are forwarded herewith.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have considered with care the Department's airmail letter 159/36/5, dated May 30, 1940, with reference to a suggestion of Reverend R.B. Cochrane that no new Indian Day School be erected in the village of Ahousaht, West Coast Agency, but that rather the proposed Indian Day School be carried on in one of the two rooms formerly used as classrooms at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

I should like to point out to you that should the old classroom or classrooms be used the Ahousaht children will have a daily walk of some mile on a raised plank walk through the woods to and from school. I fear that accidents, children falling off planks, etc., quite likely to occur.

With the Day School so far from the Indian village it will be almost impossible to keep up a good percentage attendance while if the school were conducted in the Ahousaht village itself, the attendance would certainly be better and the teacher would be in a position to exercise a certain amount of control by visiting Indian parents in their own houses.

It should also be remembered that if we are to conduct an Indian Day School in this district it would be far better to have it located on the Indian Reserve itself than on property belonging to the Woman's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada, over which we have no control.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I have the honor to refer to your letter of June 6th in connection with the proposed day school at Ahousaht. The class rooms in use at the present time are situated on the site of the old Residential School which is church property and approximately three quarters of a mile from the village. These classrooms are badly constructed, poorly ventilated and lighted.

To modernize these rooms would mean spending considerable money on remodelling and repair, which money could be spent to better advantage in a Department owned school.

The people of Ahousaht cannot be said to be healthy and the children are not robust. I quite agree with Captain Barry that children having to walk a long distance in wet weather and being obliged to sit in a classroom with their present defects is detrimental to their health and also to school attendance.

Having the school at the village would bring the teacher into closer touch with parents, ensure better attendance. I would respectfully recommend that the new school as proposed be built at Ahousaht Village.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge your letter of April 18th, 1941, and to report on the Ahousaht Day School as follows:

The old classrooms at present in use are situated about one-quarter mile from the village and are part of the old Residential School, and presumably the property of the United Church. Classrooms are poorly constructed and, apart from doors and windows, would be of little value if torn down and taken to a new site.

It is not thought that the attendance at the Ahousaht School will at any time exceed twenty-five pupils, and it would be more economical to build a new schoolroom than to utilize the old buildings, with the exception of doors, windows, furnishings and desks. Reconstruction could not be carried out until late in the year, as the Indians are away on the fishing grounds from May to October, and I feel sure they would expect payment for labor.

Since the destruction of the Residential School the Indians have opposed the day school, and have sought admission for their children to both the Christie and Alberni Residential Schools on every pretext.

Present classrooms have been put in good order and in so far as their construction will permit, and new heater and lighting provided. Also rubber boots were provided for the children to keep them dry during the wet season, and mid-day meal given to eliminate the necessity of going home at mid-day.

In view of these conditions, I would respectfully recommend that the present classrooms be retained for at least another year, and the allowance for mid-day meal extended.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Re: Ahousaht Indian Day School

I have for acknowledgment a letter dated March 23, 1941, and also copy of a resolution passed by the Ahousaht Band, attached thereto.

It is noted that in this resolution the members of the Band ask for the construction of a new Indian day school at the Ahousaht Village.

No provision has been made in the estimates now before Parliament for the construction of Indian day or residential schools anywhere in the Dominion, and it is not at all likely that funds will be available for the construction of an Indian day school at Ahousaht at any time in the immediate future. In view of this fact, I have been wondering if the demolition of the present school and its reconstruction near the village has ever been seriously considered. I am aware, of course, that the existing building is somewhat old and dilapidated, but it has occurred to me that if the Indians are really interested in the education of their children they might undertake, during the summer months, the dismantling of the old building and the construction of a building at the village. A building reconstructed in this sense might not be ideal for educational purposes, but it might be suitable for their needs until times become somewhat normal. I am making this suggestion on the understanding that the labour costs involved would be borne by the Indians. We have no item in our estimates that would enable us to assume payment of the labour costs involved in the reconstruction of this school.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Sir:

I have the honor to refer to your letter of June 6th in connection with the proposed day school at Ahousaht. The class rooms in use at the present time are situated on the site of the old Residential School which is church property and approximately three quarters of a mile from the village. These classrooms are badly constructed, poorly ventilated and lighted.

To modernize these rooms would mean spending considerable money on remodelling and repair, which money could be spent to better advantage in a Department owned school.

The people of Ahousaht cannot be said to be healthy and the children are not robust. I quite agree with Captain Barry that children having to walk a long distance in wet weather and being obliged to sit in a classroom with their present defects is detrimental to their health and also to school attendance.

Having the school at the village would bring the teacher into closer touch with parents, ensure better attendance. I would respectfully recommend that the new school as proposed be built at Ahousaht Village.

Yours obediently,

"P.B.Ashbridge"

June 10, 1940.

Dear Major MacKay:

I have considered with care the Department's airmail letter 159/36/5, dated May 30, 1940, with reference to a suggestion of Reverend R.B. Cochrane that no new Indian Day School be erected in the village of Ahousaht, West Coast Agency, but that rather the proposed Indian Day School be carried on in one of the two rooms formerly used as classrooms at the Ahousaht Indian Residential School.

I should like to point out to you that should the old classroom or classrooms be used the Ahousaht children will have a daily walk of some mile on a raised plank walk through the woods to and from school. I fear that accidents, children falling off planks, etc., quite likely to occur.

With the Day School so far from the Indian village it will be almost impossible to keep up a good percentage attendance while if the school were conducted in the Ahousaht village itself, the attendance would certainly be better and the teacher would be in a position to exercise a certain amount of control by visiting Indian parents in their own houses.

It should also be remembered that if we are to conduct an Indian Day School in this district it would be far better to have it located on the Indian Reserve itself than on property belonging to the Woman's Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada, over which we have no control.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver, B.C.

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge your letter of April 12th, 1941, and to report on the Ahousaht Day School as follows:

The old classrooms at present in use are situated about one-quarter mile from the village and are part of the old Residential School, and presumably the property of the United Church. Classrooms are poorly constructed and, apart from doors and windows, would be of little value if torn down and taken to a new site.

It is not thought that the attendance at the Ahousaht School will at any time exceed twenty-five pupils, and it would be more economical to build a new schoolroom than to utilize the old buildings, with the exception of doors, windows, furnishings and desks. Reconstruction could not be carried out until late in the year, as the Indians are away on the fishing grounds from May to October, and I feel sure they would expect payment for labor.

Since the destruction of the Residential School the Indians have opposed the day school, and have sought admission for their children to both the Christie and Alberni Residential Schools on every pretext.

Present classrooms have been put in good order and in so far as their construction will permit, and new heater and lighting provided. Also rubber boots were provided for the children to keep them dry during the wet season, and mid-day meal given to eliminate the necessity of going home at mid-day.

In view of these conditions, I would respectfully recommend that the present classrooms be retained for at least another year, and the allowance for mid-day meal extended.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa,
March 2, 1948.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th ultimo with reference to using the United Church building at Ahousaht as a school in place of that now in use. It is felt that we should be allowed the use of this building free of rent and, if it is possible for the Agent to arrange this, the Department approves transferring the school. In that event you may expend an amount of $25.00 for the construction of outside toilets.

Please advise me if you can make the arrangements suggested in this letter.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Ashbridge's letter of the 23rd ultimo, and my reply of the 29th ultimo and his letter of the 16th instant with reference to his request for authority to use the United Church building at Ahousaht as a school in place of that now in use and some distance from the village.

It will be observed that there would be an expenditure of $25.00 for the construction of outside toilets and there would, presumably, be a rental not exceeding $10.00 per month payable to the Women's Missionary Society for the use of the building.

It would be appreciated if you would kindly give this matter consideration as conditions at that point in respect to the distance between the existing school and the village has been the subject of considerable difficulty for some time past.

I would recommend that the suggested changes be approved. I might add that Inspector Barry is in full agreement with the proposal.

Yours faithfully,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Sir:

I have the honour to report that at a band meeting held at Ahousaht on January 18th, 1942, this Band made a request that the Department allow them to use the church building in the village for a day school.

It will be remembered that this necessity is in line with recommendations made by Capt. Barry and myself that a school be built in the village, same school being rejected by the church. The church building referred to is suitable for a day school and the equipment of the present school can be easily transferred.

Conditions for the children at the present school are not good, and I would respectfully recommend that this request be granted.

The only expense involved I can see at present would be the construction of outside toilets, estimated cost twenty-five dollars.

I may say that Mr. Glover the present teacher is in full agreement with this request, and would give every assistance in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

P. B. Ashbridge,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have the honour to submit the regular Agency letter, covering conditions within this Agency during month ending January 31st, 1942.

Ahousaht Day School had a good attendance and appears to be making better progress. Classroom was clean and health of pupils fairly good. Mid-day meal is also supplied at this school due to long distance from the village.

A request was made by the parents to have the school held at the Church building in the village, a special report on this matter has been forwarded for the Department's consideration.

P.B. Ashbridge,

Funds at our disposal will not permit authorizing the serving of a midday lunch during the months of May and June.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,

Ucluelet Day School:
$8.00 per month from December 1, 1941 to March 31, 1942.

Your obedient servant,

The heating stove at the Ahousat Day School is in very poor condition and should be replaced as soon as possible.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

Ahousaht Indian Day School.

I have for answer your letter of May 7th with regard to the above Indian Day School.

As I advised you in our telephone conversation of this morning our District Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia has previously recommended that we consider the erection of a new Day School at this point. Due to previous commitments, it is not anticipated that this building will be erected this summer. However, it is high on Inspector Davey's list of required schools for British Columbia and it is expected that it will be included in our 1949-50 Estimates.

In view of the above recommendation, the Department would like to be advised further with regard to the views of those members of the Women's Missionary Society who were of the opinion that a Residential School should be built at Ahousaht.

Ahousaht Indian Day School.

During my recent trip to Toronto I had a long meeting with Dr. Dorey and officials of the Woman's Missionary Society of the United Church.

While we primarily discussed the closing of a residential school in the Prairie Provinces, we also discussed a number of matters in British Columbia. One of these dealt with the payment of rental on the church building used as a school at Ahousaht. Apparently, the Church has never received any rental for this building.

They also requested that we give consideration to the erection of a new school at Ahousaht this summer. Unfortunately, we have not a sum in our Estimates for its erection but I would suggest that we place it in the Supplementaries. If it is at all possible to arrange a transfer of funds from another project, this might be one to which you would give consideration.

Bernard F. Beary,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Ahousaht Indian Day School
Your file 868-5 (E)

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of April 27th wherein it is suggested that transfer of funds might be arranged for the erection of a new school at Ahousaht this year, information presently being assembled with regard to the cost of completing school buildings construction of which was started last year indicates that it will not be possible to allot funds for the erection of a school at Ahousaht without interfering with the priority which has been allotted to certain other school construction projects. It is intended, however, to make provision in the Estimates for the construction of a school at Ahousaht next year.

W. S. Arneil,

May 31, 1949.

Reverend George Dorey, D.D.,
Secretary, Board of Home Missions,
The United Church of Canada,
299 Queen Street West,
Toronto 2B, Ontario.

Ahousaht Indian Day School.

Dear Doctor Dorey:

You will recall our conversation concerning the building of a new school at Ahousaht this year. As you are aware, only 50% of our funds were voted before Parliament prorogued. As a result we have had to limit our building programme accordingly and I cannot now definitely assure you that this school will be built this summer.

I know this will be disappointing to the Woman's Missionary Society, as indeed it is to me. However, these are matters over which we have no control and we will do everything possible to make the school more comfortable next winter.

A new oil heater has recently been supplied to the school, in an effort to improve heating conditions. As you are aware, we were unable to obtain the services of an Indian to secure sufficient wood for this school. There is an oil station adjacent to the reserve, so we feel that at least things will be more comfortable for the teacher.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Colonel Neary:

Your letter of May 31st has been communicated to The Woman's Missionary Society, which regrets that it is not likely that the building will be proceeded with this year. There is not very much that can be done about this in view of the political circumstances which obtain at the present time and under which you have only a part of your appropriation available for 1949.

I am asked, however, to draw your attention to the fact that the church at Ahousaht is being occupied by your Department as a school for the last three years, and, so far, no rent has been paid. The Woman's Missionary Society thinks that it would be only fair to have the Department pay rent for this building as it does at certain other places.

I shall be glad if you will give this matter your attention and let us know what you are prepared to pay. The Society thinks that it ought to be worth $35.00 a month, which would be a pretty modest interest on the money that you will have to invest in a new school.

Yours sincerely,

July 18, 1949.

Attached is a voucher covering rental of the church building owned by the Woman's Missionary Society which has been used for school purposes since September 1942. It will be noted that I have reduced the amount of the voucher as prepared by Mr. Superintendent Garrard to cover only the period from April 1st, 1949 to the end of June. This has been done for two reasons. First, the amount of $2450.00 is probably in excess of the value of the building and second, the Department constructed a residence for the principal of the school which was turned over to the Woman's Missionary Society without cost to that organization.

It is recommended that the amount of $105.00 be paid to the Woman's Missionary Society for rental of this building for the last three months of the academic year.

It is hoped that it will be possible to construct our own school at Ahousaht in the 1950-51 fiscal year.

We have not address of the Woman's Missionary Society but it is assumed that the Department will have this information.

W.S. Arneil,

Dear Colonel Neary:

Would you be good enough to refer to your letter of July 27th, in which you said that you were prepared to pay rent for the church at Ahousaht from April 1st, 1949, and that you were sending a cheque for $105.00 for the quarter ending June 30th. The Woman's Missionary Society inform me that they did not receive a remittance of this amount. They are, however, now in receipt of a cheque for $35.00, the particulars of which are "Rental of building for school purposes, quarter July 1 to Sept. 30." There must surely be some mistake, because the cheque is only for $35.00, and we were under the impression that you had accepted the rental of $35.00 a month.

I shall be glad if you will look into these two matters and write me.

Yours sincerely,

GD.MLT

Re: Ahousaht Indian Day School
Your File 868-5 (E)

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of June 30th, plans for the proposed prefabricated school and nursing station, Ahousaht Reserve, have been received from Prefabricated Structures and two prints are today being forwarded to you under separate cover.

The Company's quotation in the amount of $12,810.00 is enclosed, together with a requisition in triplicate.

We realize that it may take some time to secure approval for the purchase of this building and in the meantime, if you so desire, will have our engineering staff prepare detailed specifications and plans for the erection of the building, installation of plumbing, heating and wiring, etc., which will enable the Department to advertise for tenders as soon as purchase is approved. Superintendent Garrard is being provided with Construction Report Forms, for completion and return and apart from this, there would appear to be nothing that this Office can do to expedite the matter.

I may say that the Regional Supervisor, Indian Health Services, has been provided with a copy of this plan which he has tentatively approved and forwarded to the Director, Indian Health Services, for his approval.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT it is necessary and that funds are provided in the Education Vote, No. 37, 1950-51, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, to provide a two-room Indian school with attached teachers' residences on the Ahousaht Indian Reserve, in the West Coast Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia;

THAT it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Ahousaht Indian Reserve;

THAT Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ............";

THAT due to the fact the Ahousaht Indian Reserve is situated up the west coast of Vancouver Island, with communication only by boat, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own locality;

THAT a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures Limited, Post Office Box 487, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake immediately the provision of a two-room prefabricated school with attached teachers' residences and nurse's quarters for a sum of $12,615.00 f. o. b., Vancouver;

THAT Indian Health Services of the Department of National Health and Welfare are prepared to contribute Eight and One-half Per Cent ($85) or $1,059.00 towards the
purchase of this building, in which will be provided a dispensary and living quarters for a nurse;

THAT funds amounting to $11,721.00 are available in Vote 99, 1930-31, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Citizenship and Immigration, for the construction of the school and teachers' residence and an amount of $1,059.00 will be provided by the Indian Health Services, Department of National Health and Welfare (Vote 237, 1930-31) for their share of the building.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that authority be granted to expend a sum not exceeding Twelve Thousand Eight Hundred and Ten Dollars ($12,810.00) in purchasing from Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 467, Vancouver, British Columbia, a two-room Indian day school with attached teachers' and nurse's residence for the Thompson Indian Reserve, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this school be provided.

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Citizenship and Immigration.
Ottawa, October 27, 1950

Please find enclosed a Submission to Council covering the purchase of a prefabricated school and attached teachers' residence for the above Indian Reserve, in the West Coast Indian Agency, British Columbia.

Indian Institute, Chilliwack, B.C.

The Missionary Committee on Construction and Finance met at Methodist church hall in the board room of the Wesley buildings on Friday night. In addition to the regular business routine matters, some important correspondence was dealt with. Letters received from missionaries abroad and from friends overseas in the field were considered. It was felt that there was no more important and suitable business for the General Board, but it was decided to allow the regular business to be discussed at the proper time.

The general secretary reported that the erection of the new Indian Institute buildings at Chilliwack, B.C., had been begun, and that the work was being done efficiently. Dear Sir,

I enclose herewith a memorandum addressed to the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs respecting our proposed Institute work at Chilliwack, B.C. This document will put you in possession of the main facts of the case, and will enable you to deal intelligently with Mr Dewdney in discussing the matter. You will see that I have not asked for any definite sum; this is because we do not know, as yet, what the entire cost of the enterprise will amount to, and I have thought that a preliminary grant at the present session, leaving further aid an open question, would be the best way to deal with the case. This much is certain, we have paid out $2500 for the site; the two buildings, for the boys and girls respectively, and the school building common to both, will be erected during the early summer; while the necessary outbuildings, and the appliances for cultivating the land will have to be provided. It is clear therefore that an expenditure of from $10,000 to $12,000 will be incurred before next autumn. I trust from this presentation of the case you will be able to procure substantial aid from the Government; and I think it would not be amiss to remind Mr Dewdney of the fact that we are simply asking a grant in aid, and are putting our own money largely into the enterprise, other Institutes in

A. S.
Visit of Rev. Dr. Sutherland.

Monday the 11th and Tuesday the 12th were excellent days in Chilliwack for such as availed themselves of their opportunity.

The occasion was the visit of the Rev. Dr. Sutherland, several secretaries of the Missionary Societies of the Methodist Church, the Rev. C. M. Tate, resident missionary, with his characteristic sagacity, had made interesting arrangements for the improvement of the school. A high-class evening service in the Spanish Schoolroom on Monday at 7:30 p.m., Indian school examination at the Coqualeetza Home on Tuesday at 9 p.m., and a lecture on Prohibition and Politics, in Henderson Hall Tuesday night at 8.

We regret that we are not in a position to speak of Mr. Tate being unable to attend. The lecture has been briefly reported already by another correspondent. We will make a few statements respecting the examination only.

Among those present were Dr. Sutherland, Mr. J. B. Bryant, President of the B. C. Conference, Judge Vowell, of Victoria (Indian Superintendent), Mr. McTavish, Westminster, Island agent, Mr. P. R. Wilson, P. H. Hogg and others, also a goodly number of the parents of the children of the school.

The Rev. C. M. Tate conducted the examination. The scholars did remarkably well throughout. Their answers came quickly and intelligently. Particularly was this struck with this. On the subjects of Geography and Scriptural History. We were much surprised at the original answers given to one of the boys during the question on Anatomy.—What is the use of alcohol? was asked. To preserve the body, said he to all living ones, was the reply. The musical talent of the children was also well evidenced in the highly satisfactory rendering of the hymns collectively.

At the close of the examination, the gentlemen on the platform briefly addressed the meeting.

Judge Vowell with well chosen words expressed his surprise and pleasure at what he had witnessed that afternoon, he had not expected to find such intelligence exhibited and advanced. He was in sympathy with the object and approved of its method and encouraged its future development and success.

Mr. McTavish noted with much satisfaction the progress the school had made since its opening 18 months ago. In all he most congratulated Mr. and Mrs. Tate and the ladies in charge. He also addressed a few words to the parents present in Chinook, pointing out the high privilege the children enjoyed in their training at the Coqualeetza Home.

Dr. Sutherland was delighted with what he had seen and heard during the inspection. He thought the work accomplished in the short time the school has been established (less than 3 years) was well worthy of comment; it indicated the aptitude of the school and the efficiency of the teachers and that no doubt the school better regulated and he would have many pleasant recollections and nice things to say about it when he returned to England. He also spoke a few words to the Indian parents which were in tenor similar to Mr. Tate.

The school being dismissed, the friends were taken through the various rooms of the institution and were shown samples of needlework and other work done by the children under the supervision of Miss Solmers. There are now about 80 children in the Home.

It is due to all that the three ladies in charge, Misses Clarke, Elderton and Solmers, are well qualified for the important work entrusted to them and of this in course of its operation the Women's Missionary Society commends itself to the hearty support of all right minded and true-hearted people.

Dear Sir,

A little over a year ago I was present at the opening of the Home School for Indian Children carried on by the Women's Missionary Society of the Methodist Church at Chilliwack. A few weeks ago I visited it again and was very much pleased to see the progress made by the scholars during the year. There are about 30 pupils in the home. Several of the boys have reached an age when they should be learning some trade or industry which will enable them to become self-supporting citizens when they reach manhood. It is quite a number such boys among the various bands of Indians who would be glad to receive help in that direction. It would be impossible to secure the facilities for a suitable industrial institution and form a home when the present Home is situated.

After several conferences with Mr. Tate, our missionary to the Indians of Fraser Valley, I have come to the conclusion that the best means of providing for the welfare of these people is to purchase the Popcorn Mills property consisting of sawmill, grist mill, shingle mill, excelsior mill with the usual machinery for dressing lumber. All is in good running order and the water power is excellent. There are several substantial buildings included and about 60 acres of land partly covered with good timber and partly bare.

It affords us very much pleasure to welcome you to Chilliwack again, especially as your visit is in connection with a matter in which we are all so much interested, - the opening of this beautiful school building. We wish you to convey our thanks to the Government for the assistance rendered in the erection of this edifice for the education of our children. As the white people fill up our country we are more than ever satisfied, that to compete with them successfully we must have education.

But, there are also other matters of which we would like to speak. The white people were not here first. By tradition we can trace our ancestry back for many generations, and it has been handed down to us that this land has always belonged to the Indians. We are glad however that the white people have come, and we share with them our
our land, trees, animals, birds and fish; but, we are troubled when we are told that we must no longer catch our fish in the way we have always caught them, viz., the long net anchored along the sides of our streams and rivers.

We are also told at certain seasons that we may catch fish for our own use, but not sell them to white people. We think this very unjust; for there are times when the sale of a salmon would bring to us little things which we could not otherwise have. And when the salmon are in season why should the Indians be compelled to pay license for catching and selling what belongs to them.

We would like you as our chief to enter protest against the wholesale slaughter of the sturgeon in the Fraser River. The Salmon are fished so much at the mouth of the river, that but few of them get up stream. We have always been able to get sturgeon however, and we have said very little about the salmon; but now that the white people are going about to destroy what seems to us our last resort, we think the time has come for us to speak.

THE INDUSTRIAL INSTITUTE.

Formal Opening of the School for the Training of Indian Children.

The formal opening of the Coqualeetza Industrial Institute, an institution organized by the Methodist Missionary Society took place on Thursday last noon last in the presence of a large number of visitors, the staff of the establishment, and the pupils.

The building, which is situated at Sardis, about fifteen miles from the town of Chilliwack, on a good graded road, presents a handsome appearance, standing boldly out from a broad expanse of meadow and cultivated land with a background of verdure-covered mountains. It is the largest and most complete establishment of its kind in Canada, and has received much credit upon both architect and builder. It is located in twenty acres of land, the whole of which is under cultivation, affording beautiful scenery. The building is the design of Mr. Hooper, the well-known architect, and is in every way adapted to carry out all its requirements. The structure is of brick, with three stories and basement, being 110 feet long by 62 feet in width. It has accommodation for 100 pupils, with a staff of 8 or 10 instructors. There are also kitchens, laundry, play-rooms, bath-rooms, and furnace-rooms. The ground floor has the kitchen, pantry, dining-room for pupils, sitting-room, sitting-room for teachers, and offices for principal and secretaries; the second floor contains dormitories, bed-rooms, store-rooms, and store-rooms. The third floor also contains dormitories, bed-rooms, store-rooms, and store-rooms. The establishment is heated and ventilated throughout by the "Smad Dowd" system, which also provides with complete sanitation and comfort; and in walking through the premises, the visitor is surprised and pleased at the order and cleanliness everywhere evident. The dormitories are lined with rows of iron cot-beds, strongly made, with woven wire mattresses, the upper end being elevated to form a pillow. On this is laid a thick felt mattress, very soft and yielding, and for covering there are good blankets.

An examination of the pupils was then conducted by Miss Smith, their teacher. The questioning was made individually, by classes, and collectively, and after each exercise the questions were also asked by calling by names, the answers being quick and correct in every case. Mr. Logan, seems to possess a thorough knowledge of the character and temperament of every pupil, and whose voice or sign is obeyed with a willing obedience, attesting the existence of that happy reliance and sympathy between teacher and pupil so necessary to successful training.

THE B. C. INDIANS.

Wards of the Government and What is Being Done For Them.

Few people, think we are to be found in this Province who do not take a strong interest in the Indians. They are the wards of the Government, and as such occupy a large share of the attention of those who administer the affairs of the Dominion. The Government may be located. The Indians in British Columbia are divided into three classes in those in the Territories in Manitoba and Saskatchewan. They are almost a self-supporting community, and if they would only take after and disciplined turn out to be excellent workers, they could support themselves, their families, and those who have to look to them for support. Here again, as unfortunately for the aborigines of the soil, civilization has been forced upon them, so that it might have done for poor Lo. Perceval, who died in England, where the laws of the land are proper. By proper management, surrounded with proper influences—namely, by the white man's instructions with base, vile people being rigidly excluded from the country—thrift and frugal the various tribes become, and the Indians are enabled to emulate the white people and their ways generally. No doubt there are some Indians liable for either good or evil, as are the whites, but they are not charged with their management, and the Indians are not expected to be continually on the alert in their behavior, as the whites are. But do the Indians themselves, and it becomes the duty of the Government to guard with esteem and veneration the men who are selected by the Government to look after their interests and welfare. We believe that his Indians are fortunate in having over them men of excellent character, principles, and habits of industry and honesty, and who are above every other consideration, and who give their care of the people committed to their charge. Such men are rare, and few, if indeed any, rarer than Mr. Vowell, who has been placed in charge of the preservation of the peace among the Indians living on the coast, or those who make their homes in the interior. This circumstance is largely owing to the fact that any grievances which may develop between the Indians are looked into by either the Superintendent or the Inspector General, or by the various agencies in this Province. When the Indians are treated fairly, the Indians have been tampered with by any means, and those who are those who, in defiance of the laws of the land, are engaged in robbing, in many instances helpless creatures, with the result that they are punished with the punishment which the law admits of being inflicted upon those who are found to be in default. Severe as the punishment may appear to be yet it is far better than death, and it is evident that many, who, soon as freed from the charge, go back to their former habits, and at once become themselves to a recollection of their former actions, and are quite prepared to hazard everything for the sake of obtaining wealth at the expense of the Indian, who, when deprived of his liberty, is no more able to control himself or his actions than a child. We will fire off a powder magazine by degrees. The imprisonment of the Indians, with a year or more imprisonment, with hard labor, might have a remedial influence, and as the law now stands, much good might be accomplished. Familiarity with the Indians and their ways, as we have indicated, will result in much good. The Government must look after and provide for the Indians, and the best way of elevating them to a higher standard of morality and physical attainment.

The Superintendent of Indian Affairs in this Province, A. W. Vowell, has been visiting the different tribes in this district, in order to ascertain what assistance can be given to them, and to see how they are progressing. He has visited the Squamish, the Squamish Indians, the Alchelitz, the Squamish Indians, and the Squamish Indians. The superintendent visited the tribes, and their properties range in value from $500 to $1000. The crops of potatoes, oats, peas, wheat and corn are very good, and the Indians are very industrious, especially as they were last year. The crops of last year, 1894, and the light crop of last year did not help them out much, and they are unable to supply the seed for last year in many instances. They feel that they are doing well, and the visit of Mr. Vowell, however, has encouraged them, although encouraging words he spoke to them, and they are convinced that the greatest sufferers would be enabled to get a better living by such assistance as would be deemed necessary. It may be stated that in consequence of the visit of Mr. Vowell and his agents, upon the Indians to clear their lands and improve their condition, and place them better off than they were five years ago, they have greatly increased their crops, and are looking forward this season with confidence and hope for the future, and their labors. Many of these tribes are now in a better position than they were five years ago, and are now carefully looked after that they rival the whites in all points of fitness and progress.

Mr. Vowell visited the Caribou Home at Sardis, in Chilliwack, which is now in charge of Rev. Mr. Wilson, who has been working with him in an efficient staff of assistants in the management of this deserving institution, which is conducted by the Wesleyan Methodists. At the time of Mr. Vowell's visit there were about 17 pupils, towards the education of whom the government department contributes a per capita sum. Mr. Vowell is certain that the Caribou Home is doing a great work for the after life of the pupils.

Mr. Vowell also visited the Mission, was likewise visited. Here he found 77 pupils, who are under the charge of Father Cheneau, and the larger are educated by the Sisters of Charity. They are educated in different buildings, and are given a thorough training in order to fit them for the world. Mr. Vowell demonstrated that it is better to keep the Indians in the mission schools than let them go to their relatives at home, where they are likely to be led astray by doing light work in the fields with their relatives. When permitted to visit their homes they are likely to be led astray by their fellow scholars. When away from their parents, they go back with refined ideas, and as men and women are educated, they are exposed to all influences, and soon make it evident that they are not satisfied according to modern ideas and standards. Mr. Vowell visited in order to everything surrounding them, and they are likely to have a very narrow escape from being degraded. Had it not been for the cool, bracing mountain air, and the water supplied in carrying water in the buckets supplied by the department the entire buildings would have been ruined.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of August 25th, No.121,607, giving the amount appropriated during the fiscal year 1897-98 to the Indian Industrial Institutes and Boarding schools under our care; also inquiring in regard to managing the Coqualeetza Institute on a smaller per capita grant under certain circumstances.

Touching this latter point, the time is scarcely ripe for a definite proposition. It is known to the Department that the entire cost of the Coqualeetza Institute (some $25,000) was provided for by the Missionary Society with the exception of $5000 granted by the Department. This was in such marked contrast to the treatment accorded by the Department to other denominations that it has been a standing grievance with us ever since. The request has been before the Department for a long time that the Government should re-imburse the Society for the expenditure on the Coqualeetza buildings, and thus put us upon a par with other denominations doing similar work. This is one of the points that would have to be settled before the question of a reduced per capita grant can be considered.

During the past month I paid a visit to Coqualeetza, and made a careful inspection of the buildings and the character of the work being done. The result of this inspecting was very satisfactory. The premises are in good condition, and so far as I could judge the pupils were healthy, contented, and making
commendable progress in the school, and in the various industrial pursuits. The members of the staff give good evidence of being devoted to their work, and of having in a marked degree the confidence and affection of the pupils. In order to do the most effective work, however, several things are necessary. The first is a separate building, chiefly for school purposes, so that the large room now occupied for school work may be turned into a dormitory, which is very much needed; and the kindergarten room into a store room, which is also a necessity. Our proposition would be that we provide plans for the proposed building, with estimates of cost, and that when these were approved, a grant should be made to the Missionary Society, and buildings erected by us under Government inspection, and to the satisfaction of the Department.

Another thing that is very much needed is additional land. There are but 20 acres connected with the Institute, and this does not afford sufficient space for giving the older boys that training in farm work which is so essential. The 20 acres composing the present site were purchased at the rate of $125 per acre. I ascertained that additional land adjoining the present 20 acres can be obtained at a cost of $100 per acre, which is cheap as prices go in that neighborhood. These are the more pressing matters at the present time, and I trust that they will receive favorable consideration from the Department.

For sometime past nearly 100 pupils have been in attendance, and others are seeking accommodation, but cannot be admitted for want of room. Just why it is that we should receive a per capita grant for only 50 pupils while in the other Institutes in British Columbia provision is made for the full number in attendance.
and in some case beyond that, we are quite unable to understand; but I indulge the hope that as this inequality has repeatedly been brought to the attention of the Department, it will be removed during the coming session.

Sir,

I have the honor to submit for the consideration of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs some facts and figures concerning the Indian Industrial Institute at Chilliwack, B.C., and to request that provision may be made at the ensuing session of Parliament to supply the more urgent wants of the Institute at the present time. When I visited the Institute last August I found everything in admirable order, under the direction of a staff who in fidelity to their various duties, and success in their work, are not exceeded, if they are equalled, by the staff of any other institute in the country. Nearly 100 pupils were in attendance which crowded the building somewhat uncomfortably, and as additional pupils can easily be secured, the circumstances point to the need of some form of increased accommodation in the near future. Although the number of pupils is so large, the per capita grant is allowed for 50 only, which is in marked contrast to the provision made in all the other Institutes and Boarding schools in British Columbia. My first request, therefore, is that provision may be made by the approaching session for a per capita grant for not less than 80 pupils. This we are fairly entitled to, and I think the request needs only to be mentioned in order to be granted.

In conversation with the Principal, Matron, and School Teacher, I found that two things are urgently needed at the present time; first, additional land for farm purposes, and second, a separate building large enough to accommodate the two divisions.
of the school, with one or two rooms for the sewing and dress-making department, and another for Band practice and similar purposes.

Respecting land, it will be remembered that there are about 20 acres adjoining the Institute, which does not afford sufficient room for the instruction of the older boys in farm work to which many of them take very readily. When visiting the place I found that 20 acres additional could be procured from Mr Webb, from whom the present site was purchased, the price asked being $100 per acre, which is $25 per acre less than was formerly paid. There was also an offer from Mr A.C.Wells to sell 50 acres across the Luckakuk River, in the rear of the present Institute site, at the same price as is asked by Mr Webb. Since that time, however, we have learned that on the main road leading from the Institute to Chilliwack there is an excellent farm of some 90 acres, which can be secured for about $55 per acre; the owner being out of the country and desires to sell. Sir,

Referring to our conversation in your Office on the 24th inst., I beg to submit a brief memorandum on the more important points, trusting that they will have your serious and favorable consideration.

As to the Coqualeetza Institute at Chilliwack, B.C., I beg to remind you that the entire expense of providing buildings and equipment was borne by the Missionary Society. It appeared that we had to do this or go without an Institute altogether, and in this respect the treatment was in marked contrast with that accorded to other Missionary Societies and Churches for whom buildings and equipment were provided by the Government. The only help received toward the original cost consisted of two grants from the Department of $2500 each, which exactly represents what we had to pay for the 20 acres of land upon which the buildings stand. Then after a length of time we received a per capita grant for only 10 pupils, at a time when more than 50 were in attendance; afterwards it was increased to a grant for 17 pupils, and ultimately within the past year or two a grant for 50, although fully 100 were in attendance. Here again is a marked discrimination, for I find from the Departmental Blue Book from the report of the Auditor General, that in the case of other Indian Institutes in British Columbia a per capita provision has been regularly voted by Parliament sometimes for a larger number than is...
actually in attendance, although I presume that payments were made only for those who did actually attend. The crowded state of the building at Coqualeetza embarrasses the work, and has, indeed, an element of danger. What we very much desire is the following:

1. That the Department will supply us with additional land, either by purchase or rental, so that we may have room enough to give the older boys the training in farm work which is so essential. I am informed that a farm of about 90 acres, half a mile or so from the Institute, can be purchased from a non-resident at about $55 per acre, which is only about half the price usually asked for land in the Chilliwack valley.

2. The erection of a building near the present Institute to furnish accommodation for the school work proper, that is, for the Kindergarten department and the advanced classes; also room enough for the Sewing Teacher and Dressmaker and her pupils, with perhaps an Office for the Principal. What we would propose is that we send you a rough sketch of the accommodation that is needed, and when plans are approved by the Department, a sum be voted for the cost of the buildings.

3. A per capita grant for 80 pupils instead of 50 as at present. As we have stated, fully 100 pupils are in attendance, of whom I believe 90 per cent are Indians within the meaning of the Act.

4. A beginning of Institute work at Hue-wil-get, on the
Upper Skeena we deem very important, and Boarding school work at Bella Bella, and at a point on the West Coast of Vancouver Island, is almost equally important. At Hug-wil-get we have land already secured, and some improvements made.

5. McDougall Orphanage, at Morley, N.W.T.—I am informed that there is a grant of $2000 available towards the enlargement of the building. The Indians are very averse to sending their children while they are so huddled together in the present limited space. In this case also, if the Department approves, we would furnish rough sketch of enlargement required, and proceed in the way suggested with reference to Coqualeetza. At Morley it will also be necessary for a house to be erected for the Principal. It is under contemplation to appoint Mr Stewart, who is now Principal's assistant at Bredon and if he, or any other man with a family, is appointed, a separate house would seem to be a necessity.

6. Boarding Schools.—There are three points in the North-West where boarding schools, from our point of view, are urgently needed; First, at Battle River, in Samson's Band; Second, Whitefish Lake, or between Whitefish Lake and Saddle Lake, in connection with Pakan's Band; Third, At Norway House as a centre from which quite a number of Bands can be reached. At these points the expenditure need not be very large. In each case probably $2000 would provide a building large enough to begin with. At Norway House, we are very desirous of institut-
ing medical and hospital work, and if the necessary buildings and outfittare provided for by the Government, I think that we can provide the Doctor and the Nurses. Of the vast importance of work of this kind among the Indians I need not speak, and perhaps there is no other centre from which so many can be reached as at Norway House.

Commending these various matters to your kind and favorable consideration, I am,

Sir,

Yours Obedient Servant,

A. Butterland

Extract of a letter from the Rev Joseph Hall, Principal of the Coqualeetza Institute, Chilliwack, B.C., dated October 20th 1896.

"We have had our Annual Shows at Chilliwack and New Westminster. We obtained 24 prizes at Chilliwack; 18 in the girls' department, and 6 in the boy's. The girls' work consisted of sewing, plain and fancy, knitting, darning, and mending. The sewing included also dressmaking. In all this the girls gave a good account of themselves. Their work was universally admired, as indeed it deserved to be. The girls' work secured 13 first prizes, and 5 second. It is to be remembered that the competition was against white girls and women. Some of the latter regarded themselves as experts in the lines in which they exhibited, but were fairly beaten by our pupils. In the vegetable department we won 2 first, and 4 second prizes. At the New Westminster Show we had to try our mettle as against the Institutional schools. Five schools entered. We came out ahead again; William's Lake being second, and Kamloops third. Our exhibit was greatly admired by visitors. Every department was represented. For our baking exhibit, it was necessary for the girls to be up at 1-30 o'clock on Monday morning, as the articles had to be down that morning at New Westminster, and the boat left the Chilliwack landing at 7 o'clock, and we must leave the Institute at 6 o'clock. But the bread, biscuits, cookies, ginger cakes, and layer cakes, are all ready and boxed up for the boat when the hour for leaving arrived. The Kindergarteners, too, had their handy work in. Ours is the only school in the country that has a Kindergarten department. Then the sewing work and fancy work showed up well."
A girl's cloak, cut, fitted and made throughout, by one of our girls for the occasion, showed what our dressmaking department is accomplishing for the girls. It was critically examined by many lady visitors, who expressed their surprise and delight, to know that the work was so excellently done. A child's dress by another of the girls won equal commendation. A large display of vegetables, cultivated by the boys from ten to 16 years of age, did great credit to them.

"There was great rejoicing in our Institute when the news of our success reached it; and of course when I came home I had to supply a large amount of details respecting the affair as possible."
