Dear Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 13th inst., No. 268, enclosing copy of a letter addressed to Rev. Mr. Allen, and bearing the signatures of Jack Usilick, James Usilick, Fred Usilick, and Mrs. Jack Usilick; in which are certain complaints made as to the treatment which the children of the Institute receive at the hands of the teachers. It is alleged that they are abused; that it is for this reason that they run away; that the Indians are used like dogs. This last complaint does not seem to be used against the Institute, nor to refer to the treatment of the children, but of the adult Indians, as it is immediately added apparently by way of explanation that they do not understand the law like the white man. It is further stated that Jack Usilick is in jail for keeping his child from school; and that Mr. Pearson went to Jack Usilick's home and ran in without warning; that he grabbed hold of the girl, and was going to run out of the house with her like a dog. It is claimed that this is not using the Indians right. Rev. Mr. Allen is appealed to for assistance if he can render any; and it is implied that it is the wish of the appellants that the Indian Department shall be advised of their grievances.

You desire that I explain in Triplicate for the information of the Department whether...
grounds for the assertions which the above named Indians make in their letter of complaint; also whether Mr Pearson acted in the manner described; and that I should report all circumstances fully, and with as little delay as possible.

The letter of the Indians, then, first, prefers a general charge of abuse of the children in the Institute. To this general charge, of course, only a general denial can be given; and this denial I now give; I deny most emphatically and unequivocally that the children of our Institute are abused by their teachers. The children do receive chastisements varying according to the nature of the offences which they commit. Corporal punishment is occasionally resorted to, but always with reluctance, and when other means fail to bring the refractory into submission to the authority of the teachers. I am happy to say that instances of insubordination are very infrequent indeed, and generally very readily conquered. Besides, we have occasionally an instance of unusual culpability which has to be corrected by suitable severity. But in no instance has any child received treatment which could be properly called abuse. No bruises are ever inflicted, and always justice is tempered with mercy; usually the pupil is reasoned with and shown how impossible it is that the offence committed can be allowed to go unpunished. Upon the general charge I have I think said all that is necessary. If any specific instance of wrong treatment is adduced I shall be prepared to deal with it. Instances do occur as in other similar institutions of pupils running away. I will not say that in no instance has any runaway given it as one of the reasons for his doing so that he did
not like the treatment he had received; but I will say that so far as my knowledge goes, very seldom is this reason assigned, and when it is given it will generally be found that the pupil assigned it in hope of being thereby justified in the eyes of others for taking this step, although this reason is not the real one for his running away. The restraints of discipline in study and work in many instances they may not like; to roam about in idleness, riding about on horseback at their pleasure, gallopping about from place to place and occupying themselves in unprofitable amusements they may prefer; but that any pupil ever had a reason for running away in his having received abuse or wrong treatment in the Home I must most emphatically deny. As in the previously considered general charge this is all that I can do. Let one particular charge be preferred and it shall be dealt with on its merits.

As to the assertion that Jack Usilick is in jail for keeping his child from school, I cannot understand how such a statement could possibly be made. I wonder how Jack Usilick's name came to be subscribed to such an unblushing falsehood. Was Jack's name signed to it without his knowledge? In this case the falsehood would not be his. He must at the time this letter was written have received his sentence. He must have had his trial, at which I am informed, Mr Indian Agent Devlin and Mr Stipendiary Magistrate Pelly presided. Every one in the court room must have known that he was committed to jail for being drunk and for beating his wife. The presiding magistrates would not allow the case to proceed without the prisoner being
advised of the offence with which he was charged, and opportunity being afforded him to make his defence and to adduce any testimony he might wish to offer on his own behalf. Neither would sentence be imposed without the nature of the offence being enlarged upon, and the justice of the penalty being pointed out. Thus the assertion of the letter is utterly foundationless and inexcusable.

I come now to the last point viz: concerning Mr Pearson.

On Friday Ev'g Jan. 5th, Jack Usilick's daughter having been away from the Institute nearly a week, Mr Pearson went to bring her back. He found her in her father's house. Mr Pearson does not remember whether he knocked at the door or not. Several people were in the house, and no objection was made to his entering. He explained his errand, stating that Mr Indian Agent Devlin had sent him for Charlotte. Mr Pearson told her to put on her things, meaning her hat, jacket &c. She did not attempt to get ready. He told her that if she did not put on her things she must go as she was. He then took her by the hand and drew her arm under his much as a gentleman and lady walk arm in arm, and told her to come along. Her mother then interfered, placing her hands upon Mr Pearson by way of preventing him from going forward with Charlotte. He warned her that she should not do that. Two American Indians who were present also stepped up and interfered to prevent Mr Pearson taking Charlotte away. As Mr P. was alone he released his hold upon the girl and withdrew, returning next day with help. But the girl has just told me that Mr Pearson was not in the least harsh nor rude, and that
if any one says that he was they say what is not true,
I do not think that I can say more. I am prepared to
meet all or any accusations or charges that may be
brought forward, by whomsoever they may be made.

I have the honor to remain,

My dear Mr Devlin,

Reverend Sir:-

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., calling the Department's attention to an unavoidable deficit of $1000.00 which has occurred during the past year in carrying on the Coqualeetza Institute. You attribute this deficit to embarrassing regulations:

First: - The strict application of the rule of discharge of pupils who have reached the age of 18 years. With regard to this rule I beg to say that greater latitude has been allowed the Coqualeetza Institute than to any other school for discharge. The last return shows that there were eleven pupils who had reached the age limit of 18 in attendance at this school, 5 of whom were 18 years old and 6, 19.

Second: - As to the payment of only half the per capita grant for pupils under ten years of age, I beg to say that this rule is applicable to all the industrial schools and the Department does not consider it advisable to change it, as it would only lead to filling up the schools with very young children instead of those of an age to benefit by the industrial school training given at these institutions.

Third: - The Department cannot pay the per capita grant

grant for more pupils than the number authorized, so being the limit at this school. REPORT OF THE COQUALNETZA INSTITUTE
FOR THE YEAR ENDING JUNE 30th., 1907.

BUILDINGS

1. The Main Building is a fine three storey brick with basement.
2. Principal's Residence: This is a good substantial, well built two storey with basement.
3. Farmers' Home: A nice comfortable cottage.
4. Barn: 56 by 46, which comprises a horse stable with room for eight horses, drive shed, apple cellar and cow.
5. New Henry: 32 by 16.
6. Cow Stable: 56 by 30, accommodation for 30 cows
7. Granary: 30 by 20
8. Work Shop: 16 x 12
9. Bake Shop: 16 by 12
10. New Open Shed: 40 by 20, with good shingle roof.
11. Barn, 60 x 60. This is in the centre of farm and used for storing hay and grain crop.

The most of these buildings are in a fair state of repair and answer the purpose intended.

FARM AND GARDEN:

This consists of about 90 acres of good rich land well adapted for agriculture and gardening.
The crops are as follows:

25 acres of grain
30 " " hay
14 " " roots, garden fruit and orchard.
20 " for building grounds and pasture

The crops are looking well and the outlook is for average crops.

The Chilliwack valley is beautifully situated and well adapted for fruit, orchards, gardens and farms, and this farm can be utilized for training these boys for farmers, gardeners and stock men.

The lack of neatness and finish around the stables and fields gives the impression that the farmer fails in making his Department the object lesson that it ought to be as a training school for Indian boys.

He has been here only a few months, yet it is a question if he is the right man for the position.

**LIVE STOCK:** There are 6 horses, two work teams, a driving horse and a pony. Two of the work horses are nearly used up, one in the wind and the other by age.

21 head of cattle, mostly milking stock (with quite a strain of Jersey) prove to be a good asset to the Institution, and 50 hens and 13 pigs make up the live stock.

**STAFF:** The Staff and Salaries paid are as follows:

Principal R. H. Cairns, $600. House, food, fuel & light
Farmer, Chas. Reid, $600. House and Garden
Carpenter Louis V. Masters, $400. Board and washing.
Matron Miss F. M. Kinley $300. Board and Washing
Teacher " M. Pitman 300. "
" L. Peregrino 300. "
Asst. Matron " H. E. Young 240. "
Cook " Mary Hortop 240. "
Laundress " F. E. Hudson 240. "
Seamstress, " M. B. Jeffries 240. "
Band Master R. Marshall 180. "

The building is kept neat and clean and excellent work is done in the laundry, kitchen and sewing-room.

**CLASS ROOMS:** In the School Room Department I found two teachers doing excellent work in the most approved methods.

The children were bright and evinced a keen interest in their studies, and their standing is above the average usually found in such schools.

They are classified as follows:

| Standard | Pupils |
|----------|--------|
| 1        | 37     |
| 2        | 10     |
| 3        | 20     |
| 4        | 15     |
| 5        | 4      |
| 6        | 6      |

34 of these are classed as good and 56 fair.

**HEATING & VENTILATION:**

The Smead Dowd system is in use and gives excellent satisfaction when properly handled, with probably the exception of heating a few of the smaller rooms, at strategic points in...
extreme weather.

The system provides for the heating and use of the air but once, and in a climate no colder than that of the Chilliwack Valley, no better ventilation need be looked for—pure fresh air pouring into the building as fast as the furnace can heat it.

**PUPILS:** There was an average attendance of 83 during the year. 11 of these are under ten.

7 were in attendance for whom no grant was received, these having been brought from homes not on Indian Reserves.

They are bright, happy and contented.

Their general health has been good. Two have been sent home on account of ill health; one of these died and the other is not improving. At present pupil No. 183 is not in good health and the Dr. advises that he be sent home.

The buildings lost by fire in December last have not been rebuilt. One of the girls' dormitories is being used for a primary school room, and the loss of the buildings have cramped the room and comfort in other departments.

The dormitories should have 100 quilts and 100 blankets.

REPORT OF THE COQUALEETZA INSTITUTE
FOR THE YEAR ENDING JUNE 30, 1910.

EXD.

The following improvements have been made to the plant during the year:

The main building has been greatly improved in its outside appearance by the addition of two coats of paint,—a first-class job has been done,—at a cost of $750.

A new bake oven has been built of sufficient size to bake all the bread required in the Institute; also

A new piggery has been constructed. These two buildings cost about $440, $400 of which was met by special grant and the balance was paid out of current expenditure.

Two tent dormitories have been well built by the special grant of $407 from the Government. These have good floors, shingled roof, chimneys and canvas sides, which can be kept open.

The boys' dormitory is 45 ft. by 16 ft. and has accommodation for 18 boys.

The girls have not yet occupied their's as a dormitory. It has been used as the Primary school room. These buildings cannot be surpassed in the British Columbia climate for comfort, fresh air, and sanitary conditions.

A bath-room has been fitted up for the lady members of the staff, at a cost of $100.

FARM AND GARDEN.

The farm and garden are looking well. There will be abundance of fruit and garden produce, and the average of the entire crop will be the largest yield in five years.

CLASS ROOM.

The usual work of the Class Rooms has been well maintained by the teachers, who are energetic and up-to-date in their methods.

INDUSTRIAL WORK.

The girls are receiving a training in the work of the kitchen, laundry, sewing room, and general house keeping; and the boys on the farm, garden and in the workshop.

THE PUPILS.

There are 90 pupils on the roll, 80 of them being present, the others being out on holiday,—are expected in the near future. They are all well fed and clothed, and appear to be in good health.

STAFF.

The staff and salaries paid is as follows:—

Mr. Cairns receives $200 a year from the Missionary Society for the missionary work he does in connection with the mission of the seven Indian Reserves. He also receives his table supplies and light and fuel for his home. As a mark of appreciation I would recommend that he receive an advance of $100 on his salary.

SALE OF LAND.

One acre, a three cornered piece next to the Creamery, was sold to the Creamery Company for $500. This Company is donating it to the B.C.H.R. Co. for a station.

.62 and .24 of an acre is sold to the B.C.H.R. Company for $200 and $85 respectively, a total of 1.86 acres for $285.

In making a transfer it was found that we could not produce a certificate of title. The Institute property has been obtained in four different transactions, and it now appears that we are not able to produce a certificate of title for any of it. To remedy this I engaged Mr. J. Polly, a lawyer of Chilliwack, with instructions that if the certificate of title cannot be found, to proceed and secure new certificate.

When the Principal receives this $325 for sale of land, I would recommend that it be disbursed as follows:

1. Pay Mr. J. Polly for his services, which will be $40 or $50.

2. Pay Mr. Wells $50, a promised donation towards a bonus of $1000 to the B.C.H.R. Co. About the beginning of the year a public meeting promised $1000 as a bonus, and all has been paid but the promise of the Institute. This was authorized by the late Dr. Sutherland in a letter addressed to Mr. Cairns, dated Feb. 3, 1910.

3. That the Principal be instructed to spend the balance in improving the fences of the entire property. Nothing has been done in this direction for some years.

IMPROVEMENTS NEEDED.

Some provision must be made for better accommodation in the laundry by providing a dry room and summer quarters. This can be done in an open shed, which stands at the rear of the main building at a cost of about $400. I would recommend that a special grant be made for this purpose.

The many improvements outside the main building together with those inside, especially those made by our W.M.S. during the past two years in refurnishing the private rooms of the lady members of the staff and also fitting up a bath-room for them at a total cost of $600, has left the ladies' sitting room and the spare bed-room much below the average of the tone of the Institution. To create harmony, these two rooms should be refurnished at a cost of $250 or $300. This ought to be referred to the W.M.S. for their favorable consideration so that they may have the opportunity of doing something for the women.

As the half day system is followed at this school there is ample room for all the pupils. Mr. Cairns claims that, while there is sleeping accommodation for 120 pupils, this number would lead to crowded conditions in the kitchen, lavatories and bath rooms and he states that in his opinion good work can be done with an average attendance of 100 pupils and when you get beyond that number you are apt to choke things. Sir:

In response to your letter of Dec. 23rd., No. 120292/10, I visited Coqualeetza Institute on Monday, Jan. 4th.

Some 15 pupils from Massett have arrived. It appears that the Thomas Crosby was at Massett on the way to Vancouver. Advantage was taken of this fact and 12 boys and 3 girls were sent to Coqualeetza.

There were 117 pupils in the school on the day of my visit. One girl was in the hospital and three were away on holiday. This makes 120 pupils.

A new dormitory has been added to the accommodation of the school. It is 45 by 18 by 11, will accommodate 18 pupils. It is a splendid building for the purpose for which it is used. The sides are canvas.

Mr. Raley will need to be restrained or he will overcrowd his school. He has had many applications for admission, and he does not like to refuse admission.

REPORT OF THE COQUALEETZA INSTITUTE FOR THE YEAR ENDING MARCH 31, 1915.

Since my last report, R. H. Cairns, who was principal for some eight years, resigned, and Rev. G. H. Raley was appointed to take charge on the 1st of July.

The Boys' Home at Port Simpson was closed, and fifteen of the pupils were transferred to the Coqualeetza Institute. The Government grant was changed from the basis of 90 to 110. Mr. Raley has been successful in filling the school. There were 113 children present at the close of the year in March, and 117 on the roll.

The present staff and their salaries are as follows:

In addition to the above salaries, the staff receives board and washing.

The tent dormitory, which was built during the year, has sleeping accommodation for twenty boys, and also makes provision for a member of the staff.

Some other improvements have been made, viz:
- A concrete floor has been laid in the girls' basement.
- Three out-buildings and the cow barn have been painted.
- The fences have been whitewashed.
- Some improvements have been made to the electric light system.

The live
The live stock consists of:- 6 horses, 14 cows, 6 two-year-olds, 10 yearlings, bull, 25 hogs and a flock of hens. For some years the farm was not kept as clean as possible. During the past two years Mr. Stronach has rendered good service as farming instructor. Great care will be necessary in keeping the weeds from spreading.

The half day system is adopted, the girls and boys working for one half of the day in the class-room and the other half at some industry. The girls are taught housekeeping, cooking, sewing, laundry work, music, etc. The boys are taught farming, gardening and care of stock. Many of these boys live in the north where farming and gardening are impracticable. Carpentry work and boat building should be added to the list of industries. The question of putting in a carpenter involves more than the payment of a salary.

Material
Material and tools must be found to work with. Repairs to the present buildings, and some new buildings that are necessary in connection with the Institute will keep a carpenter and a half dozen boys for the next four or five years. Some extra provisions should be made to provide for this necessary material over and above the per capita grant.

There are a large number of repairs and improvements needed.

1. The main building needs kalsomining and painting. The plaster is badly wrecked in many places, especially in the ceilings of the ground floor and hall-ways. The plaster should be replaced by Metallic ceilings and walls.

2. Window screens are needed for the main building and the Principal's Home.

3. The staff dining room and the parlour in the main building should be repapered, and also the parlour and sitting room in the principal's home.

4. There should be a hot water heater connected with the bath-room and laundry, and also a bath room fitted up for the lady members of the staff.

5. The drainage system of the main building is leaking between the building and the tank and needs repairing. I have not been able to discover whether this is a septic tank, and if so, whether it is properly installed. In order to make this examination, it would be necessary to empty the tank or remove the roof.

6. The wood-shed removed and a new one built where it would not take up so much of the boys' play ground.

7. The granary moved as it occupies ground that should be used for the boys' play ground.

8. A carpenter shop and general workshop is much needed.
9.- Another cottage built for the accommodation of a mechanical employee.

10.- A new laundry with washing machine and extractor. This could be operated by installing a five horse-power electric motor.

11.- A new corn barn and silo.

All these repairs and new buildings should be attended to at the earliest possible date.

Good work is being done in the class-rooms and also in the industries in all the departments which are covered in the present program of the school. Care is taken regarding the moral and religious instruction of the pupils. Good order and discipline is maintained throughout the Institute.

With the addition of the mechanical department and an increase of pupils, this Institute should become a model industrial school. All of which is respectfully submitted.
COQUALEETZA INDUSTRIAL INSTITUTE
CHILLIWACK VALLEY

THE FAIR 1915.

In less than one month the 1915 Fair of Northern British Columbia will be a thing of the past. Notwithstanding the financial outlook, prospects for a greater and better Fair for 1916 are good. The leading question is whether the 1915 Fair will justify the decision of the Directors early in the year to hold the third Annual Fair at this place. We think the continuance of this important feature of Northern progress. From the point of view of organization there is no doubt in the affirmative. We hope the fair will be attended and the citizens of Prince Rupert will extend a right royal welcome to the visitors in September next.

I enclose herewith a copy of a complaint signed by Mark Alexander, James Jones, Sarah Wallace and Mary Norman of the Queen Charlotte Agency, in regard to the treatment accorded the Indian children at the Coqualeetza Industrial School, and in reply to same have to advise as follows:

I visited this school on the 29th of March and was very courteously received by Mr. Raley, the Superintendent of the school. Dinner being served a few minutes after my arrival, Mr. Raley kindly conducted me through the dining room in which the children were assembled, in order that I might have an opportunity of forming an opinion as to the food served. The meal, which was served on enamel dishes, consisted of soup, boiling beef, potatoes, a pudding and bread, with water to drink. The food was good and substantial in quality and ample quantity served.

After dinner Mr. Raley kindly collected all the children from Massett and Skidegate. On inspecting these children I found that they all were in first class physical condition, the clothing was clean and substantial, and with one or two exceptions the shoes worn by the children were in good condition.

On the whole I must say the Indian parents have no just cause for complaint. The children seem to be happy.

Dear Mr. Scott.

The summer is on us again, and the Institute children with the happiest memories of their outings at Ocean Park the last two years they were able to enjoy through your thoughtful consideration are very anxious to go again. There will be about 55 in all who will not be able to go home for holidays, and if it is at all possible to finance again this year I shall be pleased to take them for an outing.

The maintenance of children away from home is more than at home but if the Indian Department could arrange to allow the same grant as last year which was $120.00 for transportation, we could finance the holiday.

The two years we have had our camp, the Ocean Park Board of Control have expressed pleasure at the conduct of the boys and girls, the order, cleanliness, and general spirit of the camp. This year they have offered us the use of the camp, tents and utensils for the last week in July and the first two weeks in August.

The change did both the children and the teachers who had charge of them inestimable good. The
investment was rightly placed in the interest of Child Welfare. This year we need it especially for the little children.

Our School has prepared an exhibit this year to be sent to Ottawa we believe the Department will be pleased with.

Sir,

I beg to inform you of the receipt of the following, from Rev. Geo. H. Raley, Principal of Cequleetza Industrial Institute, with reference to the "epidemic of influenza which swept over the country recently:"  

(Copy.)

"Cequleetza Industrial Institute,
Sardis, B. C., Nov. 22nd, 1918.

Dear Mr. Deasy.—We are now about clear of the Influenza. George Price, of Skidegate, is up and around the house, probably will be out tomorrow if the weather is fine. He had a very severe attack. Ezra Meedy has not completely recovered; he never was very strong. I am keeping him in bed and in all probability the Doctor will allow him to get up tomorrow or the next day. The rest of the Skidegate and Massett boys, in fact all the boys and girls, with the exception of one, are now able to be out. I think it is wonderful how you and Mrs. Deasy have met the situation at Massett with so few deaths. Down here Mr. Indian Agent Byrne and Desminien Constable Grant informed me that the Pitt Meadows as many as forty funerals were held out of about 260 Indians. The Lillooet tribe suffered greatly as did also Kitimat, Bella Bella and Kitkahtla. Trusting that Mrs. Deasy and yourself may both be sustained in these trying times by the Power in whom we trust and that you may really feel much comfort in the knowledge that you have given the best you could of yourselves to help these unfortunate people during their severe visitation, believe me, (Sd.) Geo. H. Raley."

In a previous letter Rev. Mr. Raley informed me of the death of an Indian Pupil, from Skidegate, Josephine McKay, daughter of the Chief Councillor of the Skidegate Band. This girl was the only victim that died from Influenza, at Cequleetza Institute, from the children of the Massett and Skidegate Bands.

Your Obedient Servant,

Reunion of Graduates and Friends of Coqualeetza Institute

A most enjoyable re-union of graduates and friends of Coqualeetza Indian Institute: Sardis, B.C., was held in the Central Hotel on Thursday evening. There were present, Rev. and Mrs. George H. Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th instant applying for a grant of $150.00 towards the cost of the transportation of children from Northern British Columbia to the Coqualeetsa Institute and stating that you have a large number of children coming down from the north to the school.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
If the children of the institutes were learned in dressmaking, boat-building and running of gasoline engines, we might do better with the sons and daughters of fishermen. Many of them have sewing machines in their houses and they send thousands of dollars to departmental stores before they will use the machines. The younger children of this province are able to care for themselves in a financial way. The Department educated them and we find the younger generation not or a person with the older ones when they come back to the reserve and an environment they have not been in touch with for years. Reserve life is not to their liking, and their morals appear disheartening. Marriage does not appear to benefit some of them, through relations and friends assuming the right, according to the old customs, of selecting husbands and wives. Great care should be taken in the marriage of young Indians and the license system is improving them in some respects. At the same time our Indians are advanced enough to come under some law whereby the marriage must be respected.

They have missionaries and churches on the reserves yet the Indian Agent is faced with the responsibilities of endeavouring to stop amongst those who are married without question. Marriage is a moral law for the good of mankind and it should be for the Indian what it is to the white man. Partaking the women was the main fault that we had to correct in the early days and it is not entirely eradicated. Illegitimacy, especially among the Indians who return from the schools, is not on the decrease. I am compelled to state that the birth of illegitimate children to girls, supposedly educated, is increasing. Naturally the Indians to a certain extent are "unmoral". They appear to know little of moral training and our greatest difficulty is keeping the young men and women from co-habiting, even with examples before them and with teachers of morality in their midst. Environment is against them and the young women are the mark of many of other races, associating with them, without considering the evil in the young men who associated with them in the boarding school.

Your obedient servant

Thomas Deasy

INTRODUCTION

Coqualeetza Institute, a residential school or college for the academic, technical and vocational training of the Indian boys and girls of British Columbia, has been in existence since 1886. It is located about 70 miles in an easterly direction from Vancouver. The situation of the Institute is particularly favoured, being in the midst of the famous Chilliwack Valley, one of the most fertile spots in the Dominion. The interest in the Institute is more provincial than local, the pupils being recruited from native villages lying between the border of Alaska on the north and the Straits of San Juan on the south.

The year just closing has been the most successful under the present regime. While advancement has been apparent in every department, a decided forward movement has taken place along the line of manual and vocational training for the boys, and home nursing for the girls. The year has also been marked by the organization of an Alumni Association.

Let me express my thanks to the student body for their general good conduct, diligence and progress, and above all, for a united effort to heighten the tone of the school.

Let me also record my appreciation of the devoted services, hearty co-operation, and splendid esprit de corps on the part of every member of the staff, without which the present status of Coqualeetza could not have been attained.

BOAT BUILDING.

For many years we have been dreaming of adding to the curricula of Coqualeetza Institute vocational training along the line of boat building. For want of encouragement and lack of funds, our dream has not materialized until this year. The above picture shows with what success our efforts have been crowned. This is the complement to our manual training class.

A thorough training in boat building will solve the problem of the future for many an ex-pupil. There is not one of the above class who should not be able to find ready employment as soon as he leaves the Institute and returns north. In other words, vocational training will put him on his feet.

The Instructor, Rev. J. C. Gibson, standing at the bow of the boat, is not only an expert in boat building, but also in C. S. E. T. work—consequently his influence with the boys counts for much. He speaks in the highest terms of his class.

The boat is thirty-six feet long and ten feet beam. The dimensions were suggested by Capt. Oliver, of the Marine Mission, as a suitable, safe and comfortable size for a Mission launch in northern waters, where it will probably be used, when completed, as a Mission launch.

For want of a suitable building in which to carry on this work, we have had to utilize the recreation hall for both manual training and vocational work.

FOREWORD

COQUALEETZA Institute for forty years has been a unit in the educational work of the Province of British Columbia.

The present economic requirements of all people demand that schools provide instruction along eminently practical lines. The Indian Department of Canada, in conjunction with the Church, with commendable foresight and enthusiasm is providing a system of modern training institutions or residential schools, with an essentially vocational foundation which will fit the Indian youth of both sexes as fully as possible for the life of their immediate future and the changing conditions which may affect their more remote future.

The highest aim is to make christian citizens of the pupils, and so they are taught to "Fear God," and "Honor the King." We seek to give the girls a clear idea of what true womanhood means. This embraces a study of the virtues and graces which go to make happy homes. For the boys we crave a conception of true manliness, a love for honest labor and an intelligent interest in the affairs of the state.

In all, we seek to instill a reverence for sacred things and respect for the rights of others. We have visions of leadership for some and a healthy atmosphere of usefulness for many, and the following lines seem to express what we desire all shall learn:

"We are not here to play, to dream, to drift,
We have hard work to do, and loads to lift,
Shun not the struggle, face it, 'tis God's gift.
Be strong, be strong!"

Sardis, B. C., October 21st, 1924.

COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SEARCH British Columbia over, no happier choice of location could have been selected for Coqualeetza Institute than that which it occupies. The Institute is planted in the heart of the Fraser Valley, two miles distant from the banks of the Fraser River. The valley itself is luxuriant with verdure, trees and flowers and its level fields are hemmed in by great mountain ranges, the sentinels of which are Mt. Cheam and Mt. Tamahai, lofty peaks, the source of the rivulets which run hither and thither through the country.

There is no doubt that unconsciously the beauty of the landscape, with its majesty and coloring, has an uplifting effect on the impressionable minds of the young.

The comfortable homes in the peaceful valley also tend to teach happiness and contentment, and the fact that many persons of culture and refinement are interested in the education and development of the native children, is a stimulus to our efforts.

In short, Coqualeetza Training Institute owes not a little to its advantageous location, in its manifold development work, which includes academic, prevocational, social and athletic lines, all necessary to the making of well-rounded, independent and self-supporting citizens such as the native boys and girls must learn to be in this land of Canada.

At present the school plant consists of a new, modern residence for 200 students with class rooms and assembly hall. It is comfortable and commodious, equipped with new furniture.

A principal's residence and one school officer's cottage are the other dwelling houses.

An up-to-date new farm completes the list.
HISTORICAL

1880—First Indian Day School organized by Rev. and Mrs. C. M. Tate at Squihala.

1886—First Day School organized at the Mission House at Coqualeetza.

1887—Twelve children were taken into residence at the Mission House at Coqualeetza.

1888—Coqualeetza Home was built. Miss Elderkin was placed in charge.

1891—The Coqualeetza Home was destroyed by fire, half of the pupils were sent to their homes, those remaining with their teachers were sheltered in the Mission House.

1893—A new building was erected. The edifice was completed in brick, three stories high, and a basement under the whole building, with accommodation for one hundred pupils. This was called the Coqualeetza Industrial Institute. Rev. C. M. Tate was made formal Governor.

1920—Dr. Duncan C. Scott, after consultation with Rev. T. Ferrier and Principal Raley, decided the 1893 building had served its day and arranged for plans to be drawn up for a new building. The same year R. Guerney Orr, Esq., Architect for the Indian Department, visited Coqualeetza, obtained data and commenced plans.

1921—The first unit of the new educational plant was commenced.

Indian Commissioner Corrects Report of New Indian School; Financed by the Government

Editor The Vancouver Sun: Sir.—In an article of yesterday's October 22, referring to the opening of the new Coqualeetza Indian Residential School at Sardis, B.C., there is a paragraph of the second last paragraph dealing with the manner in which this and other Indian residential schools are financed which does not properly state the fact, and I am of the opinion that it would be well that the public should know the full circumstances of the case, otherwise a false impression is liable to be created, not only among the whites, but the Indians as well.

Your newspaper article makes it appear that the Coqualeetza School is provided for through the sale of unoccupied Indian reserves and that the institution is free from mixed blood Indians, but those of mixed blood have to pay.

In this connection I beg to state that the funds for the building of this school were provided for by parliamentary appropriation, and not through the sale of unoccupied reserves, as stated. Neither is it correct that only children of full Indian blood are admitted free at the institution, as they are open to all children of enrolled members of bands, and in British Columbia there are a great number of persons of mixed Indian blood who are considered to be Indians under the Indian Act. For pupils of full or mixed Indian blood, being members of bands, the Dominion Government, through the Department of Indian Affairs, pays to the management of Residential Schools a per capita grant ranging from $150 to $176 per annum. Children of mixed blood who are not members of bands are not eligible for admission to these schools, as they do not come under the category of Indians as the term is now controlled by the provincial or municipal authorities in each province.

As an illustration of what is has been costing the Government of Canada for the education of Indian children in the Province of British Columbia, it is only necessary for me to point out that since this province entered the Union in 1871, the total amount expended by the Crown up to March 31, 1923, was $4,321,953. Prior to the entry of British Columbia becoming one of the provinces of the Dominion school work was nothing done along educational lines by the Colonial Government, but during the first 10 years thereafter the amount expended by the Dominion Government was $10,188; for the years 1882-83, $1,189; 1883-84, $1,000; 1884-85, $32,764; 1885-86, $482,541; 1886-87, $740,623; 1887-88, $750,948, and for the three years, 1890-91, 1891-92, 1892-93, the cost was $1,359,536. The figures for the final year that have not so far been published.

In the Province of British Columbia at present there are 43 Indian Day Schools with an enrollment of 1,550 pupils. Operating cost of these schools is approximately $150,000 per annum. There are also 16 Residential Schools in operation at which institutions, up to March 31, 1923, was 1,276 pupils. The new school at Sardis and one now under construction at Kaslo, both of which have capacity for a very considerably larger number of pupils than did the old schools being replaced by the new ones, when completed, should bring the enrollment up to approximately 1,000 pupils. The total operating cost of the 16 Residential Schools amounts to $663,630 per annum. All the funds for Residential and Day Schools are provided for by parliamentary appropriation.

During the past seven years new Residential Schools have been built by the Department of Indian Affairs from public funds as follows:

Alberni, $72,000; Kuper Island, $110,000; Fraser Lake, $188,000; Sechelt, $125,000; Sardis, $206,000. At Kamloops the entire unit of a fine large school with accommodation for 200 pupils has been completed and the contract has now been let for the east wing, and on completion of this second wing the west wing will be constructed. It is estimated that when the school is completed next year it will cost approximately $225,000.

W.E. DITCHBURN,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir:

A question has often arisen in my mind as to the right interpretation of the instructions of the Department regarding correspondence. We are instructed to "address the reply to the Secretary of the Department". Does that mean that the envelope shall be directed to you and the letter written to the head of the branch on the subject which belongs to his particular branch.

For instance if I want information or advice on school matters shall I write to Mr. Russell Ferrier and address the envelope to you or shall I write to you as Secretary of the Department and also address the envelope to you.

The same applies to building. Shall I as it were not recognize the presence of the architect and write to you as well as address the envelope to you. Is it the wish of the Department that we write as though the various branches were nonexistent so far as we who are outside are concerned?

It makes no difference to me but I am anxious to do the right thing as the Department wishes it to be done. At the same time I do not wish to be discourteous to any members of the Department.

If at your convenience and without any trouble could you let me know the custom and wish of the Department I should esteem it a favour and conform to it.

Thanking you for your interest and wishing you the compliments of the season,

Yours very truly,

School Helps

Indian Artists

Having a fine collection of early Indian handiwork, the new Coqualeetza Indian Institute at Sardis, B.C., promises to be a museum as well as a manufacturer. The school there will provide modern industrial education for the Indian youth of the province and also preserve for future development the early arts and handicrafts of the race.

The grand building just completed houses comfortably 200 students, boys and girls, in the main structure which cost $200,000 and which is supplemented by shops and barns. Its construction goes in line with the government's policy of providing for its Indian children schools that are something to be proud of.

Rev. George H. Reid, the principal, hopes to organize a league to provide wider markets for the native workers, to perpetuate familiarity with their fading past and to encourage purely native art. Already the walls of the main hall and reception rooms are covered with over 600 specimens of native work, revealing wonderful artistic skill and telling to the uninitiated much of the ethnological history of the Pacific Coast.

The school was founded in 1923 by a Methodist missionary, Rev. C. M. Tate.

The first sod of the new building was turned by Rev. Dr. Chown, the foundation stone laid by Duncan Campbell Scott, Litt.D., F.R.C.C., superintendent of Indian affairs and the completed structure dedicated by Rev. C. E. Manning, general secretary of Methodist home missions.

Expense and responsibility for the diversified education offered in agriculture, domestic sciences, trades, sciences and letters are borne jointly by the Dominion and by Methodism. W. B. Ditchburn, Indian commissioner for British Columbia, R. H. Grant, inspector of Indian schools, and Rev. T. F. Foster, Methodist superintendent of Indian hospitals and schools, have direct oversight. Their sympathies are with the policy of conserving the younger generation to prize the achievements of the past and to learn to fit themselves into white civilization.

FOREWORD

YOU will see as you turn the pages we have achieved; and what now? Why, still further achievement. We are not unmindful of our present attainment, for it is too wonderful, but it is the very thing which causes us to reach forth.

We present to you in this issue pictures of our beautiful building.

What effect has it on our work?

It inspires us to press forward and live up to our motto, "No backward step." It breathes an air of culture, refinement and learning hitherto unfelt. It attracts pupils as never before. It pleases and surprises our visitors. It radiates happiness, comfort and warmth and in the midst of such surroundings expansion is the natural sequence.

Our official opening was nearly all that could be desired. One presence was lacking. We refer to Duncan Campbell Scott, Litt., D., F.R.S.C., Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, to whom the native people of Canada owe much. FOUNDERS' DAY

October 21st, 1924

MARKING an epoch in the development of the educational life of the native people, the New Coqualeetza Residential School, Sardis, was opened for Indian children of the Province of British Columbia on the 21st day of October, 1924, by the Rev. Dr. Manning of Toronto, General Secretary of the missionary Society of the Methodist Church of Canada, with a golden key, symbolic of Christian education, which opens the door leading into every avenue of life and knowledge worth while.

W. E. Ditchburn, Esq., Indian Commissioner, of Victoria, ably presided over the opening ceremony. On the platform with him were, representing the Department of Indian Affairs, Mr. J. H. Agar, A. J. Davies, of New Westminster, and Mr. R. H. Carins, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province. Representing the Methodist Church with Dr. Manning were the Rev. T. Ferrier, Superintendent of Indian Schools and Hospitals for Canada, Rev. and Mrs. Tate, the founders of the original Coqualeetza Industrial Institute; Rev. O. Dunlop, D.D., Superintendent of Missions; Mrs. Derbyshire, representing the Women's Missionary Society; Rev. J. W. Westman, President of Conference; Dr. J. H. White; Rev. R. Whitmire, M.A., D.D., and Rev. Frank Raley. Over five hundred people gathered from far and near, exclusive of 201 pupils and a staff of 10 to witness the impressive ceremony.

Directly the doors were opened a public reception was held, Principal and Mrs. Raley and Miss Bell (the matron) receiving the guests. Members of the staff and senior pupils acted as guides to show the guests over the building. Tea was served in the staff dining-room, with Miss MacGregor, the boys' matron, acting as hostess, while Mrs. C. S. Pearson and Mrs. E. A. Wells presided at the tables. These two ladies had taken part at the opening of the original school. At 7.30 sixty guests sat down to a sumptuous banquet prepared by Miss Beckett, assisted by Miss Price and Miss Raley. Several toasts were proposed and responded to.

Wednesday a reception was held both afternoon and evening. About three hundred guests called: Mrs. J. H. White, Mrs. Teasdale, Miss Taylor and Miss McGregor officiated at the refreshments.

An interesting and impressive ceremony took place during the evening, when Mrs. A. U. DePorceer, of Vancouver, Organizing Secretary of the Provincial I.O.D.E., formally, on behalf of the Order, presented a collection of War Memorials Picture to the school.

Thursday evening the staff and the pupils and a few ex-pupils enjoyed a family banquet, the toast list being carried out by the pupils.

Extract from Vancouver paper:

Coqualeetza Residential School offers the Indians a unit in the educational life of this province. The educational work pursued at this school being a well-balanced combination of practical work with the academic, the school possesses the advantages of the ordinary modern convent and college, is ideally situated and ideally suited for the pursuit of both. With accommodations for 201 pupils and a staff of 15, the school is surrounded by ninety-two acres of the finest agricultural land in the well-known Sardis district, this land serving an excellent purpose for the training of the pupils in the various branches of farm work. One of the most modem of barns, with its stock, provides for instruction in animal husbandry.

The practical work includes instruction in the various branches of gardening and fruit production. In the school, the girls are taught all the branches of housekeeping, including baking, sewing, laundering, etc., and a visitor is delighted and surprised at the practical use the girls make of these accomplishments. The school has a large vegetable garden, and the pupils are instructed in the care of the same. The market food supply of the school is practically provided for by the products preserved and fresh of the farm.

The school is named after the Coqualeetza River, which flows off here, on which is located the namesake of twenty-three of the staff and students of Coqualeetza who fought in the Great War. The prevailing spirit of the institute is a high and worthy one, in endeavor to live up to its motto, "Vestigia Nudia Retenus." The school is under the direction of Mrs. J. H. White, who has been appointed with standard set by the principal, Rev. G. H. Raley, who adopts as his own motto the words of G. Glotz, "To my awards union things are achieved when they are well begun." The New Coqualeetza is surely well begun."
Mrs. G. H. Raley

This is an opportunity to place on record our gratitude to Mrs. Raley, the wife of the Principal. We know of her untiring devotion to the cause. Her many acts of kindness and consideration for the children and their friends have not passed unnoticed. She has been a true friend and a powerful helper to the school. The native people of Northern British Columbia know that in all the past years she never spared herself to make life happier for them whenever it was in her power.

Moreover, we are told by one who knows that it was Mrs. Raley who interested friends in the East so that the school is equipped by a piano, Victrola, and a large quantity of bedding, quilts and table clothes were donated. Precisely she has avoided associating herself with many benevolent bodies lest they be aware of her thoughtfulness. So now we take all the more pleasure in bringing to light her unselfish interest in the welfare of the school. Cognerons.

REV. S. D. CHOWN, D.D.

Coqualeetza was honoured in January by a two days' visit from the Rev. S. D. Chown, D.D., General Superintendent of the Methodist Church of Canada. This is historic for Dr. Chown was making his last tour of British Columbia in his official position as head of the Methodist Church. He very graciously addressed the entire school, assuring them he has never failing interest in Coqualeetza but has been glad of presenting him with an address which she had compiled in the name of the student body, Principal and Mrs. Raley and the staff of the school tendered Dr. Chown a reception, inviting as guests the Senior Students.

MISSIONARY PAGEANT

In Wesley Church, Vancouver, 25th to 29th November

Coqualeetza had its little share in the great Centenary Missionary Pageant put on in Vancouver last November. Representing the Local Committee, Mrs. Raley was present with ten pupils. The latter called forth abundant applause when the vast audience realized that these boys and girls were educated native children, the outcome of Christian Missions. Mrs. Raley's display of Indian curios was the unique attraction of the Missionary Conference.

The Spirit of Missions is duly fostered at Coqualeetza and this year found Missionary givings greatly increased. The students from the youngest to the oldest have learned that "it is more blessed to give than to receive," and although some have but a few pennies, all are most desirous of helping along the great cause of Missions.

VALEDICTORY ADDRESS

June 19th

The time has come when we, the Class of '25, must say farewell to Coqualeetza. A host of pleasant associations lies behind us, and it is with regret we bid good-bye to the staff and students. As we leave the school for which we have been taught and we fitted in to meet the future untried, we realize more fully how much we owe to it.

It is indeed a great privilege to be the first graduates of New Coqualeetza, and just as New Coqualeetza has grown from a mere idea, so must graduates grow by being true to their ideals and assuming responsibility. Leaving does not mean we sever our connection with the school, as we hope to uphold the traditions of the Alumni Association. We shall try to come show our devotion and loyalty to our Alma Mater by being true to her ideals and guarding well her honour. As we go out, we ask the teachers to accept our thanks, forget our faults and magnify our virtues.

LAUNDRY

In charge of Miss M. E. Taylor

Theory: 11½ hours weekly; application, 18 hours weekly.

Once again we are prepared for our annual test of three weeks' camp out in the glorious sunshine and fresh, pure air, when before our eyes not only the mountains of piles of soiled clothes, which are soon made clean and white by the electric machines, but also the laundry.

The girls have no less to do than in the old laundry, but rather more, owing to an increase in the number of pupils and the fact that they must be able to turn out all kinds of work in the big, light airy room, with its whirl and hum of the revolving tubs, and the rushing of water, the girls must learn to handle their boards, transforming these masses of wet clothes into clean crisp forms of all shapes and sizes ready for little bodies whose greatest joy in life seems to be playing.

Special mention is made of: 1. Jessie Simpson, 2. Mamie Ingram, 3. Lucy Jones.

MANUFACTURING

Instructor: Miss E. Carstairs

Theory: 11½ hours weekly; application, 18 hours weekly.

One of the most utilized departments in our new building is that of the manufacturing room. Here with its five machines—two treadle, two power, and one for the making of button-holes—hundreds of garments, as well as other useful articles, are made, and mostly everything belonging to the linen cupboard are made.

Besides the practical work, the girls are encouraged to make things for themselves, thus demonstrating and produce quite up-to-date creations. In the sewing of these they take great interest.

On leaving the school, each girl graduate takes with her a complete new outfit, which, generally, she herself has made.

If only someone would invent a machine for the making of old stockings, sometimes footless, and sometimes holes in the new, he or she would merit the heartfelt gratitude of the whole institution.

Worthy of special mention and ranking as follows: 1. Alice Cline, 2. Susan Jones, 3. Alice Brooks.

MENDING ROOM

In charge of Miss D. M. McKinnon

Theory: 3 hours weekly; application, 6 hours weekly.

Could one take a peep one day and see the stacks of clothes and pressing needing repair, she would immediately think of a revised Ten Commandments, "for grime may come and go, but clothes pile up forever."

However, with such girls as Mercy Wesley, Sophronia Wallace, Doris White, Rosalind Watson, Alice Percival, Alice Edgar, and Alice Sepass, we soon see our mending diminish.

Our girls also take keen interest in the art of embroidering ducks and bunnies for relaxation, and our specimen books, I think, are worthy of praise for such small children, most of them being under ten years of age.

Recommended for diploma: Mercy Wesley.
MANUAL INSTRUCTOR'S ANNUAL REPORT FOR THE YEAR 1924-25

A.G. Jameson (Instructor)

As the school year again draws near close the Manual Instructor has pleasure in presenting his report.

This year our work is to be the most productive of our lives. Our new residence, all of which we hope will help to tastefully furnish and be of interest to the resident and future pupils, is now being fitted out. The walls of the walls, the trimmings of the historic pictures presented by the L.C.D.E., and which now cover the walls, was a work of much thought and care. Large corn show cases, which have found a place in the Entrance Hall, help by their very appearance to make the room look like a museum. We are proud of the large bookcase occupying one side of the main room. This bookcase will be filled as time goes on with the ever-enlarging "Spencer Library." The instructor and his pupils have received many gifts of this precious treasure. The boys are interested in the development and are commended for their faithfulness and their craftsmanship in this and all other work undertaken during the term.

CARPENTRY

In charge of Mr. J.B. Pattison

The past year has been one of expansion and construction, reminding one of the Chambered Nautilus turning its own shell and building a larger one within. THE HORTICULTURAL DEPARTMENT

Instructor, Mr. P.F. Price, O.A.C.

The Horticultural Department is endeavoring to keep pace with the ever-increasing numbers of students.

We have nearly seven acres in garden and fruit, which require a great deal of attention. Preparation of the ground, hot beds, seedling, transplanting, weeding and cultivating are part of the course. Small fruits, their culture and care are included.

The boys take to the work very keenly. Many of them will have a good practical knowledge of the work, by which they will be able to earn a living when they graduate.

A number of trees have been planted and arrangements made for the erection of the new building. Landscape gardening has been occupying our time to some extent. The foundation for the beautifying of the grounds and building has been laid. A number of clambake and strolls have been set out this year.

The following boys are deserving of special mention in this department: Edward Young, Paul Mason, Oscar Ingram, Philip McKay.

SOCIAL ENTERPRISES

Cougaleetza endeavours to put a bit of the home spirit into its school life by observing special days and occasions. Thanksgiving called for a taffy pull in the evening. Christmas evensong was attended by trees laden with gifts, and its graded matters.

St. Valentine's Day was celebrated by the Principal and Mrs. Ferrier having his birthday, by a party for everyone, or rather parties, for our numbers are so large now, the latter was in the hall.

The Easter holidays were similarly observed, and Victoria Day and the King's Birthday were celebrated with picnics.

During the visit of the Rev. and Mrs. Ferrier, the senior students and the mentors gave a reception for them, and while in residence were sent for by the Principal's family and the staff. A very happy and successful evening was enjoyed.

During the year, the Cougaleetza choir has enjoyed several very delightful motor rides, a trip to the movies and Church services, and also a social evening at which the staff were invited. The choir is indebted to Mr. Teasdale, their conductor, for these pleasant outings and parties.

CULINARY DEPARTMENT

Under Direction of Miss L. Maclean (supply)

Theory 1½ hours weekly, application, 18 hours weekly.

The month of June brings us to the close of the second annual session in the culinary department of our new building.

This is perhaps not out of place, because three issues from the daily meals for nearly 230 people and many extra guests. Nearly every day was preceded by the preparation of the food for the next meal in season.

The breakfasting is a department by itself and includes the duties who see an opportunity to serve. Of course, they supervised from start to finish. Weekly cooking lessons are given a number of girls, who thus are trained in the art of cooking.

The prevailing idea in the mind of the cooking master is to produce good wholesome food, which will go to build up body and muscle and establish general good health in the boys and girls and fit them for the future.

Special days call for the special food, and, from the child's point of view, the end of a perfect day is that which finishes with a thanksgiving.

A new feature in our boys' school life is that of our junior band. Two or three have their own instruments—2 violins, 1 guitar, 1 mandolin, mandorgans. Many a dull or wet evening is made bright and happy by the strains of sweet music—or otherwise—supplemented by amateurs who would be in the concert, with tin whistles and the lonely corn covered with tissue paper. Some of the boys are really good, and some are striving to be good.

CONTRIBUTED

Our teacher, Robert Lawson, is out of work now. The small animals, to save their skins, vanish at his approach, for they know once seen they hear no more.

Our "Champion" has hurt his hand, now all the balls he can't catch—he misses.

Our tallest boy is still growing. If he keeps it up we shall save our leaders.

Axes to grind, axes to grind, is the song of our little wood-burners.

Our new little typist is getting on famously. She can do five words in fifteen minutes. Some speed!

Hazel Peters is our star ball player. Boys, beware—the girls will get you if you don't watch out.

Lucie Wilson and helpers are to be congratulated on their cookies made for the picnic on June 3rd. Te "oh's" and "ah's" of satisfaction should encourage them to bigger efforts for the pie-making on Saturday morning.

Mrs. Riley could not imagine how the boys and girls could put away so much of the good things to eat at their picnic in so short a time. Simply practice, Madam, that's how.

Miss Price, Miss Bell and Mrs. Scarlett are worrying over whose sweet peas will blossom first. No bets taken.

Sounds coming from the kindergarten room the other day called us to investigate, where we found a "young rat going on." All the old nursery rhyme characters were trying to come to life and undo the other fellow, and the two big tares were the loss of the whole lot.
Dear Sister,

I have a little time to myself today, so thought it would be a good idea to write you a letter.

Brother Isaac has gone to the "Miller" to pay a bill, and it is simply pouring cats and dogs. This is the first time he has ever even "nurse" need a storm of this sort, but the mo "Clements" y of the weather did not dampen his enthusiasm for his work. This morning he was doing a long dress bill, and the "Taylor" is making Brother Isaac a "MacGregor" Tartan suit—we will have to see if "Dad" can be put to get him into it, for the "Pattern" alone will scare him. However, we bribe him by saying that we are going to have "Makin's" best tea and everyone will do anything to get a cup of this special brand.

You must "single out" the "Makin's" tea—there is a story of another doctor's account hangs over her, and since having "Kalee" fever she has become "Kaley"—nervous.

Did you know we have our new home almost completely furnished? It has been rather a task for the "Pov" of everything is so terrific. You must get "Jame-on" to drive you over to call some day. We live in "Tee-Dale". We have a new clock "Bell" and it surely is a "buzzer", so do not be afraid I shall not hear you.

As ever,

S. COOG.

SARDIS, B. G.

A FEW REASONS WHY THE ADDITIONAL PER CAPITA SHOULD BE GRANTED FOR EXTRA PUPILS

I Some of the Indian children would have absolutely no chance and their status would never be improved. Each case is urged by either Indian Agent or missionary.

Some of the children whom I have had to take not only needed a chance but a home and were taken from homes of comparative destitution.

Among the last forty names on the register of children received into the school were:

5 fatherless,
9 motherless,
1 orphan,
6 father and mother living apart under deplorable conditions.
1 committed to the school.
1 whose right arm is amputated whose tribe feel he would be better cared for at Coqualeetza.

Several have had their names on the waiting list two or three years. Many of the above are as needy as they are deserving.

We have done the work fed clothed and educated the extra pupil without crowding. We have fulfilled the requirements of the agreement the Department has with the church except the important one. The sanction of the Department.

From your letter of January 12th, and from conversation with you on this subject last May I felt encouraged to believe provision might be arranged if I could accommodate the children without overcrowding.
6. As to accommodation, there is absolutely no crowding.

**KITCHEN** The range is a heavy duty Gurney Hotel range, four ovens with surface space for three hundred.

**BAKERY** We do not run it to capacity in either oven space or days per week.

**LAUNDRY** The machinery is well able to take care of the washing without taxing its power.

**DINING-ROOM** Before we took into residence the extra twenty pupils, we had used since the opening of the building little more than three quarters of the large dining-room, two of the tables each accommodating eighteen being unused.

**CLASS-ROOMS** The half day system is maintained except in the case of fifteen pupils in grade VIII and IX, who attend the class-room both morning and afternoon. There are one hundred and forty-seven individual desks. Deducting these fifteen desks there remain one hundred and thirty-two for the balance of the pupils namely two hundred and ten. In other words one hundred and five occupy the one hundred and thirty-two desks each session. There is space for another five desks in the Primary room also in the junior without crowding or giving the appearance of crowding.

**RECREATION ROOM** We have moved one of the old tent dormitories and placed it near the outside dormitory for additional play room. This will be finished to harmonize with the general building scheme.

**DORMITORIES** To meet the increased number of pupils we moved the largest open air dormitory to a suitable location and rebuilt it, boarding the sides with matched lumber then covered the sides with two thicknesses of tar paper, and finally with shingles. We boarded the walls inside with dressed lumber and kalsomined it. This building is sixty feet...
by eighteen by ten with open space to roof instead of ceiling, electric light is used and a stove for heating. The building is warm and homelike, only an occasional fire was needed last winter. The risk is small and a male officer of the school is always in charge. The beds are similar to those in the main building. No exception can be taken to the supervision as opening into this dormitory is a staff room where two male members sleep either one or the other always being on duty. The boys occupying this building are not over twelve years of age except the trusty monitor, their health has been excellent and their behaviour all that could be desired.

Personally I feel I have a good case if dealt with on its merits and without prejudice. I admit I took these children to care for in faith I was doing right but without permission being granted.
The United Church of Canada

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I am surprised to learn from your letter of June the 24th, the Department would pay no per capita grant for children who are not sleeping in the main building.

Not knowing the facts which would lead the Department to such a conclusion, I am at a loss to reconcile the idea with the policy of the Government. Has the Department the idea the children to are not supervised by responsible officers of the staff when they are not sleeping in the main building, or are not so warm and comfortable, or that they are not kept in as sanitary and healthful condition?

I may be wrong, but I do not think the Department will turn a deaf ear to your request as representative of the United Church of Canada, for a grant for an extra number of pupils. I am presuming you have urged the case as your letter of Jan. the 12th, and our later business conversation at Sardis, last May would lead me to believe.

Your letter and the almost total rejection of the building and repair account together with the treatment of the per capita holiday allowance would indicate financial stringency. I can hardly
think an unsympathetic attitude exists at Ottawa towards Coqualeetza.

I am quite aware I have undertaken work for the school in the interests of Indian children, unauthorized, but looking back over the history of the work of the church in British Columbia, nearly every new phase of the work which has been worth while was started by the man on the ground then recognized and sanctioned by the church.

Enclosed is a statement of few reasons why further consideration might be given to the issue and the payment of the per capita allowed for the extra number we have housed supervised, schooled, fed, housed clothed and educated.

Last night's paper gave the return of the High School Entrance examinations. We sent in six to write and they all passed. It is a good record for the year 100%.

On the 24th we hope to hear the good news of Ella Gladstone's success.

With kind regards

Dr. Scott,

The Church authorities and the Reverend Principal are urging that the Department allow an increased pupilage at the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. The present pupilage is 200. Commencement Annual

JUNE, 1927
Foreword

The plea made by the British Columbia Indians to the Indian Department a few years ago for High School privileges is now being met. Already a Junior High School has been in operation at Coqualeetza since 1924, with very gratifying results. Since publishing our last Annual, thirteen of our students tried the Provincial Examinations and thirteen passed (1926). In this connection Coqualeetza desires to express thanks to Principal Woodworth, B.A., and the staff of Chilliwack High School, for tutoring one of our pupils successfully through her Matriculation. We are demonstrating that it is quite possible for the native boys and girls of British Columbia to take a High School course with great advantage to themselves and the community. The brighter pupils through this course try out their capabilities in self analysis and find themselves, and their best suited activity in life. It is true there are failures—the same is true of all peoples—but the failure, or partial failure of some is due largely to the fact that they drift into unsuited employment upon leaving school. To help a graduate of the school in a wise selection of the work for which he is best fitted, is to render a most valuable service.

We are demonstrating also that it is quite possible, under satisfactory classroom conditions, to complete up to the seventh grade, a grade a year, even when but half a day is being spent at academic work, and the other half at pre-vocational training.

The time is approaching when, under the influence of Christian education, the citizenship of Canada will be enriched by the enfranchisement of a large number of progressive Indian youths.

Principal

Dated at Sardis, B.C.,
June, 1927.
Founders' Day

The 21st of October—Founders' Day—was celebrated in the usual manner. The first order of the day was the Flag Raising ceremony, conducted by Principal Ralph; followed by Tree Planting, where Mrs. Ralph, Mrs. H. White, Rev. Dr. White, Miss Wilson, the Principal, Mr. Fordham (the Head Master), and a number of other members of the Staff and Student Body put in a row of young maples along the driveway, to stand a living and lasting memorial through the years to come.

In the afternoon a football match between the Coqualeetza Team and the Chilliwack High School Team was played on the field. Though the Coqualeetza boys were beaten 3-0, we find it impossible to report that two of the three winning goals were shot by one of our own students, George Wilson, playing on the High School Team. After the game our boys entertained the visitors to tea and games, then the Coach of the High School Team, Mr. T. R. Smith, addressed us with a very pleasant concert, including readings and songs several of which were of his own composition.

According to custom, the school was thrown open to the public during the day, and a number of visitors availed themselves of the privilege of seeing what is being done, and how it is done, in our institution.

Valedictory Address

JUNE, 1927

Another year has passed, and we, the 1927 Graduates, are about to leave school for goods, as we say, and go out into the world of which we know but little, but where we hope to make a mark and things that we have been taught during our days at Coqualeetza. Throughout our school life we have been looking forward to this time with eager expectation. Now that it has arrived a feeling of sadness comes over us at the thought of saying goodbye to the many pupils and teachers who have been our friends. Often in our future life we will look back and recall the many happy times we have had here among them, and treasure their patronage and kindness. We shall go abroad, possibly even in another country than Canada, we will try by our example to be a credit to our school. We have the joy of knowing that it was the greatest wish of our people that we should have this opportunity of education, which enables us to find out our talents and develop our best qualities, and although it will be our earnest endeavor to justify their hopes in us. In saying goodbye, we thank our teachers. The influence they have exerted on us during our school days will be a power for good in our future lives, and we know that their best wishes follow us.

(Signed) MINNIE E. WILSON, Valedictorian.

Church Anniversary Services

"COQUALEETZA SUNDAY"

June 26th, 1927

There will be special music at the School Choir, and the address to the Graduating Class will be delivered by the Rev. Principal W. H. Smith, D.D., of Westminster Hall, Vancouver, B.C. Following this will be the presentation of Bibles.

There will be an offering taken at this service on behalf of the "Coqualeetza Chapel Fund." For many years the need of a suitable place in which to worship on the Lord's Day has been felt. The present building provides such a place, but there is not enough space to accommodate our regular Sunday congregation; hence during the week it is used for all kinds of social gatherings, parties, all types of lectures, moving pictures, and various forms of amusement. It is felt that in order to inculcate a fitting spirit of reverence in the hearts of the school students, the work of the chapel should be conducted in a manner kept wholly sacred to such purposes. With this aim in view of erecting such an edifice, the "Coqualeetza Chapel Fund" was instituted in September, 1916. The "nest egg" of the Fund was $2.50 conscience money sent in by a friend. This was deposited "In Trust" in the Bank of Toronto, Vancouver. On November 30th the interest on it was $1.00 cents. The fund was starting to grow. It has been growing ever since, until up to date (June 10th, 1927), it stands at $701.19. No public appeal has been made, but on Graduation Sunday the offering is devoted to this purpose; a yard of adhesive tape on the piano in the Principal's residence has received hundreds of pieces of small change; a few private donations have been received; there is one lady member of the Staff who subscribed one dollar; a monetary offering is placed in a special box covered with Indian designs for receiving any donation; visitors and others may from time to time wish to give. This offertory box stands at the entrance of the Assembly Hall, and is opened once a month and the contents deposited "in trust" in the Bank of Toronto. The number of the account is 2245. Our objective is $10,000.00.

To the regret of both students and staff (excepting the members of the Students' Council), Mr. McKie was forced to return to his home in the middle of the term owing to the serious illness of his wife. Before leaving, Mr. McKie entertained the members of the Students' Council at a moving picture in Chilliwack.

We Have Two Witnesses to report among the ex-pupils. Items of Interest

A LATE SPILL of cold and frosty weather last winter made it impossible for us to erect a skating rink on the playground which they much enjoyed.

We have GREATLY ENJOYED the reading of "The Coqualeetza," the Quarterly Review of St. George's Residential Indian School at Port Hope, which has been sent us by Mr. Macdonald.

Our boys who attend the Technical High School in Chilliwack were privileged this year, as last, in being taken on their Instruction Mr. T. W. G. Colman, to visit a number of the largest industrial plants in Vancouver. A very pleasant and profitable day was had.

The Annual Collection with the Maintenance and Extension Fund was made this year by Rev. J. T. Burchill, late of Belcarra, and Mr. Colman. The amount subscribed to that we were able to send away $48.00 in excess of our objective of $275.00. Miss Colman ably attended to the collection during the year along with the collection and remittance of the money.

The Christmas Decorations this year were especially worthy of mention. A number of everything imaginable were made by the students and these, with holly berries and bright mottoes made the hall a veritable Christmas tree. We also had an interesting display of paintings by the students, representing the Three Wise Men going to worship the baby Jesus. This was placed whole spread over the back of the Assembly Hall platform.

This Music Department of the school is growing steadily in interest and numbers. We have a class of twenty taking piano lessons this year, and two classes found it necessary to purchase an extra piano in order to accommodate them. In addition to this, three students are learning to play the violin. This year we shall have four pupils and two pupils in viola will try the Royal Academy Music Examinations in Chilliwack.

Tranquil Our Football Team was eliminated early from the league owing to the fact that we had really not the weight this year to compete with the other teams. However, yet considerable football has been enjoyed. We have tried to keep up our enthusiasm for the sport of the present of a football to our boys on his visit to us in October. The Department of Indian Affairs has supplied us with a number of balls this season.

Coqualeetza is doing what it can to foster the Native Art. The facilities of the Art Room are used by the drawing classes in the schoolroom and last year a number of paintings of Telkwa, Penticton and other places were exhibited at the Vancouver Exhibition. In the Manual Training classes the pupils are encouraged to employ Native Art designs in the making of their models. A class in basketry has been established for the purpose of making baskets for the Fraser and Thompson River Basket Making—these are, a cup basket based upon the design of the decorated Salish Indians; conventional designs of a geometrical pattern by imitation.

ALASKA THIS YEAR. Coqualeetza has demonstrated its ability to hold its own in various contests in which we have competed. We are proud to have won the first prize and second place diploma to all Indian Schools in the Province of British Columbia for the best written composition. A num- ber of prizes, a first and second, were also won for our short stories entered in the contest at the Chilliwack Exhibition. In a Ploughing Match held at Chilliwack, James Joseph came third in the ploughing competition under the plough and took first place for the best finish. Two of our boys, David and Robert, thereupon proceeded to amuse themselves by taking first prize in a Banjo Contest held at the Strand Theatre, Chilliwack. They first, then played a well arranged program and were by the Management to repeat their performance on another occasion.
