REPORT OF MANUAL TRAINING INSTRUCTOR
Mrs. A. J. Jamieson

The Instruction Department makes report of what has, in the opinion of the instructors, been a most successful year's work. A very wide range of subjects occupied some time this term, from small projects involving decorative work in Indian Motifs, to fairly large and more ambitious efforts. INDIANS OF B.C. TAKING ADVANTAGE OF OPPORTUNITY TO SECURE EDUCATION; MEDAL IS WON BY COQUALEETZA GIRL

SARDIS, February 25.—The demand for education in every branch of learning is wonderfully increasing among the native Indian population of British Columbia," states Principal Raley of the Coqualeetza residential school which is located at Sardis.

As a striking example of this Mr. Raley mentioned that Miss Minnie Wesley, 18-year-old pupil of this school has brought honor to herself, her people and the Coqualeetza school by winning the gold medal recently awarded her by the National Council of Canada for her essay on "The Place of Confederation in the History of Canada."

This competition was open to all Indian schools in the Dominion and there were fifteen thousand competitors. Miss Wesley also won the prize for the highest average marks.

Principal Raley further stated that there are 74 residents and 250 Indian children in the Dominion of Coqualeetza ranking highest in the number of resident pupils and the chiefest in B.C. coastal districts from the Straits of San Juan to the border of Alaska.

The Coqualeetza buildings are modern in every respect and though not yet completed, including the paved highway, have a site of about 90 acres, most of which is under cultivation. The produce is utilized on the premises. The total pupil roll at the present time stands at over 220, with a staff of eighteen. During the winter months a course of religious lectures are given at the school to the pupils by various professors from the University of British Columbia and other places. The general public is admitted.

Last Tuesday Rev. P. R. Stacey, R.C., spoke on the subject of "Our Relation to the Governments at Ottawa and Victoria." Last Wednesday evening, U.B.C. gave an illustrated lecture on "Niagara, the First Capital of Upper Canada."

Ottawa, August 1st, 1925.

Rev. Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo, requesting that a similar sum be granted as in previous years, viz. $200, towards the expenses of the transportation, rent of camp grounds, etc., in order that the pupils of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School can hold their annual camp at Ocean Park.

In reply I beg to inform you that the Department will allow a grant not exceeding the sum of $200 towards the expenses of the proposed holiday of the pupils. A properly certified voucher, in duplicate, together with receipts attached, should be forwarded by you in the usual manner covering the expenses incurred, which should not exceed the above authorized amount.

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

I am writing you for authority to extend the holidays for the pupils of Coqualeetza for two weeks.

I gather from a circular letter sent out from the Alert Bay School that a two months holiday is being authorized there this year, and when I was up the Northwest Coast two weeks ago I was besieged with requests to let the children have the same holidays at Coqualeetza as at Alert Bay. In a number of homes there are children attending both schools, and you can readily see that a difficult situation arises out of the unfavorable discrimination, one school having two months holidays and another six weeks. Do not think, however, that I am complaining in any sense whatever of the extension allowed at Alert Bay, where doubtless, it is as necessary as it is at Coqualeetza, for the various reasons outlined below.

First, I feel that ten and a half months is a very long period for Indian children to be confined in residence. The Indian child, more than any other, requires all the holiday it is possible to give him. There is no doubt but that they become exceedingly restless with a long period of routine. I know it is urged that they have a break at Christmas and Easter, but in the case of our school this does not take them away from the building, nor does it confer much benefit, owing to climatic conditions, weather vagaries, which make it impossible to spend fifty percent of the time out of doors.

The beneficial effect of a fortnight's extension at this time of the year on the health of the Indian child is beyond question, especially if they are fortunate enough to be favoured with plenty of sunshine, the real force and vitalizer. It will result in a greater resistance to disease, greater physical fitness, and consequent greater mental activity, benefits which would certainly repay the extra holiday. The children can spend practically all their time out-of-doors in the sunshine and fresh air. We have to remember the winter is coming on and the body wants building up to withstand the rigours of the winter and the routine of the long term. Further, the high temperature of the classroom in August in British Columbia does not conserve the physical well being of the child, nor help to stimulate concentrated effort. This year the extension would be particularly grateful, on account of the severe epidemic of measles through which we passed - but in any case the gain physically would be unquestionable, and deserves to be considered on its merits.

Looked at from the academic standpoint there would be no real loss, as we have adopted the provincial system largely, the classrooms not opening till the last September, with the result that pupils are in residence for two weeks without academic work. As you know, we are getting tangible results, and gradually leading the Indians of the villages from which the pupils are recruited to a higher plane of living. We do not feel that an extra two weeks holidays would in any way hinder these results, but would, on the contrary, help to secure greater
efficiency in the education of these children during the coming year.

A further point is that the parents are anxious to have their children earn a little money, and remain till the end of August at the cemeteries. Last year the fishing was a complete failure in the north, and the Indian people suffered severely financially in consequence.

Thus, as you see, the doctor's, teacher's, and parents' viewpoints are all in agreement as to the desirability of a lengthened summer holiday, and I might say I have talked the matter over with Mr. Indian Agent Collison of the Skeena River Agency, and also is heartily in sympathy with the idea for this year.

We cannot afford the extension unless granted by the Indian Department. Last year I extended holidays for a number and lost so much per capita that to do so again would make financing a burden that should hardly be expected.

I am not asking this to be a precedent, but to meet a present condition on its merits, and should it be granted it would be without prejudice to any future changes or decisions deemed wise by the Department.

If my suggestion appeals to you, would you kindly let me know your decision at the earliest opportunity.

Thanking you for your interest,

I am

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Rev. G. H. Raley,
Principal

FOREWORD

COQUALEETZA Institute for forty years has been a unit in the educational work of the Province of British Columbia.

The present economic requirements of all people demand that schools provide instruction along eminently practical lines. The Indian Department of Canada, in conjunction with the Church, with commendable foresight and enthusiasm is providing a system of modern training institutions or residential schools, with an essentially vocational foundation which will fit the Indian youth of both sexes as fully as possible for the life of their immediate future and the changing conditions which may affect their more remote future.

The highest aim is to make christian citizens of the pupils, and so they are taught to "Fear God," and "Honor the King." We seek to give the girls a clear idea of what true womanhood means. This embraces a study of the virtues and graces which go to make happy homes. For the boys we crave a conception of true manliness, a love for honest labor and an intelligent interest in the affairs of the state.

In all, we seek to instill a reverence for sacred things and respect for the rights of others. We have visions of leadership for some and a healthy atmosphere of usefulness for many, and the following lines seem to express what we desire all shall learn:

"We are not here to play, to dream, to drift,
We have hard work to do, and loads to lift,
Shun not the struggle, face it, 'tis God's gift.
Be strong, be strong!"

Sardis, B. C., October 21st, 1924.

COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL
SEARCH British Columbia over, no happier choice of location could have been selected for Coqualeetza Institute than that which it occupies. The Institute is planted in the heart of the Fraser Valley, two miles distant from the banks of the Fraser River. The valley itself is luxuriant with verdure, trees and flowers and its level fields are hemmed in by great mountain ranges, the sentinels of which are Mt. Cheam and Mt. Tamahai, lofty peaks, the source of the rivulets which run hither and thither through the country.

There is no doubt that unconsciously the beauty of the landscape, with its majesty and coloring, has an uplifting effect on the impressionable minds of the young.

The comfortable homes in the peaceful valley also tend to teach happiness and contentment, and the fact that many persons of culture and refinement are interested in the education and development of the native children, is a stimulus to our efforts.

In short, Coqualeetza Training Institute owes not a little to its advantageous location, in its manifold development work, which includes academic, prevocational, social and athletic lines, all necessary to the making of well-rounded, independent and self-supporting citizens such as the native boys and girls must learn to be in this land of Canada.

At present the school plant consists of a new, modern residence for 200 students with class rooms and assembly hall. It is comfortable and commodious, equipped with new furniture.

A principal's residence and one school officer's cottage are the other dwelling houses.

An up-to-date new farm completes the list.
HISTORICAL

1880—First Indian Day School organized by Rev. and Mrs. C. M. Tate at Squilala.

1886—First Day School organized at the Mission House at Coqualeetza.

1887—Twelve children were taken into residence at the Mission House at Coqualeetza.

1888—Coqualeetza Home was built. Miss Elderkin was placed in charge.

1891—The Coqualeetza Home was destroyed by fire, half of the pupils were sent to their homes, those remaining with their teachers were sheltered in the Mission House.

1893—A new building was erected. The edifice was completed in brick, three stories high, and a basement under the whole building, with accommodation for one hundred pupils. This was called the Coqualeetza Industrial Institute. Rev. C. M. Tate was made formal Governor.

1920—Dr. Duncan C. Scott, after consultation with Rev. T. Ferrier and Principal Raley, decided the 1893 building had served its day and arranged for plans to be drawn up for a new building. The same year R. Guerney Orr, Esq., Architect for the Indian Department, visited Coqualeetza, obtained data and commenced plans.

1921—The first unit of the new educational plant was commenced.

1922—The Assembly Hall with the boiler room completed.

1923—(May 27th) The Rev. S. D. Chown, D.D., L.L.D., General Superintendent of the Methodist Church, turned the first sod.

1923—(July 28th) Duncan C. Scott, Litt. D., F.R.S.C., Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, laid the corner stone of the main building.

Luncheon Guests

Previous to their official visit to Chilliwack city, Their Excellencies visited the school and residence of Rev. H. Raley, Principal of Coqualeetza Institute, and Mrs. Raley, at their home at Sardis.

The vice-regal party preceded by a highway patrol of motor cycles, arrived at the city, being met when they left their car by Rev. and Mrs. Raley and Miss Edith Raley, the latter in her uniform of Girl Guide. Coming in to the school, our host and his wife, Mr. and Mrs. MacLeod and Mrs. A. Lead Coode were introduced, they being most anxious to have dinner with Their Excellencies. Later the party was joined by Major Robertson and the Scouts. Indicating the very kindly and democratic spirit of their reception, they were pleased to have introduced to them the three girls from the school, Misses Edith, Helen and Clarence Wesley and his companion, Miss D. Marion, the former student playing the violin during the luncheon hour.

Immediately following the Governor-General and Lady Willingdon with their party were pleased to visit the school, being extended a hearty welcome along with an welcome in the best Guide and Scout style by the troops drawn up before the school.

In front of the school an address of welcome was read and presented by the Governor-General by Edna Tait, a student from the Upper Fraser Valley School, accompanied with characteristic totem poles painted by Frank Calder. A bower of wild flowers, necklaces and bracelets and a copy of the school annual were presented to Viscountess Willingdon by little Wilma Matheson.

The address of welcome read as follows:

"Your Excellencies, Viscountess Willingdon, Governor-General of Canada, and Viscountess Willingdon:

May it please Your Excellencies: We are honored today. Your presence and unbridled kindness to the staff and student body of Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. The representatives of the five distinct nations of Indians of British Columbia, who extend to You and Your Excellencies our welcome in their native languages which, translated, mean "Great Chief, we are very happy because you visit us today."

Plant Trees

A tree planting ceremony took place. Their Excellencies each planting an elm tree in front of the main building.

Following this Their Excellencies reviewed the Scouts, Guides and Brownies. They expressed much pleasure in reviewing the native troop of scouts and guides and commented on their neatness and smart appearance. The Brownies gave Her Excellency their grand salutes.

The party proceeded to the building which was inspected. They were pleased on the tidiness and cleanliness and well-kept appearance of the various departments as they passed through.

Visiting the Infirmary, they met with King's Scout Robert Gray, whom His Excellency remembered having met previously. Robert was on his way to attend the Jamboree in England.

Returning then to the main entrance of the building, the visitors book was signed and His Excellency addressed the school in a few masterful and inspiring sentences. He gave the students a message to take home to their people and told them he would take the greetings of the school to His Majesty King George V an assurance of their good-will and loyalty.

Dr. Duncan Campbell Scott,
Deputy Superintendent-General,
Department of Indian Affairs;
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

With some trepidation I am writing you regarding an increase in the per capita grant of Coqualeetza Residential School. We are receiving $170.00, and it is not sufficient for the work we are undertaking on behalf of the Department. For many years there has been no increase in our grant, while each year has seen a new development in the work, necessitated by the change of conditions, the changing times, and the progress of the native people of British Columbia generally.

We have highly qualified teachers and have to pay them well. We could get Old Country teachers at lower salaries than we have to pay for experienced teachers with Provincial certificates, but this would not meet the situation agreeable to the Department of Education or the Province, with whom, I understand, the Department of Indian Affairs wishes to work in harmony.

We have to pay very heavily for our water - more heavily, I believe, than nearly any other Residential School. Our water alone costs us nearly $1000. a year. In the old school we had a flat rate of $5.00 per month. In the new school we have been on a meter, and while the system is excellent and pressure is generally so good that we can throw a stream of water over the building from each standpipe, it is a great draft on our finances.

We endeavour to keep the school always in good repair. Strangers visiting here always carry away with them the impression that the Department of Indian Affairs is providing well for the wards of the country. However, to keep things going we know the Department would wish to have them cannot be done in our present circumstances without quite a struggle. There were a number of items last year that might legitimately have been attended to had we had more funds at our command.

I am assured of the generosity of the Department, and its willingness to do all in its power to assist in legitimate ways the schools, hospitals and general welfare of the Indians, and I trust you will pardon this appeal which, as I say, I make with some trepidation. This is the first time I have personally asked for an increase in the per capita grant for the school. If it would be possible to raise our per capita to $200., retro-active to the beginning of this school year, it would still be a conservative amount, and the results of such increased expenditure would justify the action.

SCHOOLS GENERAL:

Whilst on the subject of schools in this agency, it always seems to me a pity that Coqueleetza happens to be a Protestant school. It is situated right in Catholic territory, and there are possibly not twelve children there from the surrounding Agencies. Most of the children come from the Northwest coast and Queen Charlotte Islands, long and expensive journeys. Now, if a Protestant school is built in the neighbourhood of Prince Rupert, Coqueleetza will, I think, be nearly empty. Then, undoubtedly, a new school as got to be erected at Mission, a few miles away, for the Catholics. This means the cost of two new schools, when, apparently only one is required. I suppose it is impossible to arrange for a big, new Protestant school in the vicinity of Prince Rupert, and then have the Coqueleetza school renovated and done up, and handed over to the Catholics for administration, and not build at Mission.

What few Protestants there are in the locality could well go to St George's at Lytton, which, so far, has never been overcrowded.

June, 1931
Foreword

The outstanding event of the school year has been the Inter-Residential School Athletic Meet or, as it is called amongst us, the inter-school Olympiad, made possible by the sympathy and support of the Department of Indian Affairs. It is quite natural my mind should center on that subject as a foreword.

The need for friendly competition in sports has been felt by Indian Residential Schools for many years and the Meet we have just consummated has broken the undesirable but unavoidable isolation which has prevailed.

It is now universally admitted that inter-school sports answer deep-seated needs essential to a boy's or a girl's fullest development and education. It is also evident that sports and inter-school sports are the prototypes of the great lines of human interest, endeavor and achievement represented in adult life and educational work today.

Relating inter-school sports to their educational and social significance includes the universal passion and admiration of achievement in physical activity, bodily skill and prowess in sports. Athletics today have the same roots as those interests which once determined a race supremacy and inspired song and story. They are also essentially and fundamentally related to vigour and health and in the field of physical education are paramount in importance.

Let me say also that inter-school sports give a stimulus to attainment in athletic ability. In friendly contest we are conscious of a desire to exert ourselves to the limit. There is an incentive to make a supreme effort. The spiritual value of competition in which our boys and girls are absolutely engrossed is the MAXIMUM OF EFFORT which it calls forth. In life, in the majority of cases, the chief difference between men in the presence of a crisis, lies in the capacity for supreme effort. This capacity is part of our character. Competition in sports is an essential in the moral training of boys and girls, insomuch as without it few, if any, will ever reach a maximum of development of the will and the capacity to try—(I firmly believe "Education needs play and play needs education").

Coqualeetzaans, I congratulate you with all my heart upon the distinction you have won for yourselves and the honour you have brought to your school. It is good and right that you should be congratulated, but it would be a sad day for you and for our school were it ever to come to pass that any of you, even the most disappointed of you, could not rejoice in your opponent's success. It is a noble quality to rejoice in another's success. Could you do it? I believe you could. You have always endeavored to—what we have so often said to one another—"Play the game." Some of you will be leaving us so let us say, "Play the Game" in life's field of labour. To you all, "Godspeed and Good Luck."

"Coqualeetza,"
Sardin, B. C.,

The First Indian School Olympiad

When it became known that Coqualeetza was chosen by the Committee for the site for the first Indian School Olympiad more than a flutter of excitement ran through the school and immediately the members of the staff and students began to lay in plans for the event which was to be held for three days more.

The track for the quarter-mile dash involved the movement of hundreds of yards of gravel which was replaced by suitable material which made one of the best courses in B.C. Then the quarter-mile oval had to be regraded. This was accomplished chiefly through the good offices of the Rev. Mr. E. N. Wells, who obtained for us the services of a grader.

A small playground had to be erected, a dining marquee, camp kitchen, tents, suitable meals had to be planned, satisfactory provision in case of rain for sleeping quarters, everything could be left to chance and, in fact, Coqualeetza had to make suitable arrangements for the entertainment of guests. Every one on our staff and students volunteered to help and all were willing and voluntary helpers, considering extra duty a pleasure. The desire was to have pleasant and happy arrangements made for the comfort and welfare and happiness of the visitors.

The details of most events were previously worked out by the Principals of the three schools competing—St. George's, Lytton; St. Michael's, Alert Bay; Coqualeetza, Sardis. A program for the three days covered a complete and wide range of field and track events, including races, relays, hurdles and spectacles alike. The numbers and school contestants were 1-2-3 St. Georges; 2-6-9 St. Michael's; 5-1-75 Coqualeetza. The colors of the school were worn: St. George's, red and white; St. Michael's, blue and gold; Coqualeetza, black and gold. The contests, boxing matches and races were held in the Sardis Community Hall and the shooting competition in the Drill Hall at Chilliwack.

Indian Schools' Olympiad Gets Away to Auspicious Start at Coqualeetza

(Mrs. C. Barber, press correspondent to Chilliwack Progress and Vancouver Daily Province)

With flags flying, spirits high and hearts beating fast with excitement, Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, Sardis, is this week the centre of much interest and the venue of many. The occasion is the first annual Indian School Olympiad, Canada, sponsored by the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, and participated in by twenty-five representatives of the three Indian schools, St. George's, Lytton; St. Michael's, Alert Bay; and Coqualeetza, Sardis. Judging from the success and interest which has attended the event, there should be no difficulty in the recommending that the meet become an annual one, and one which will prove attractive to more and more schools as the years go by.

Monday evening a reception was held in Coqualeetza hall, when Principal and Mrs. G. H. Riley and their staff welcomed very delightfully, visiting officials, the principals of the two visiting schools, Rev. A. R. Lett and Rev. E. F. Anfield, and their wives, and the boys and girls who would next day enter the ranks in friendly competition with each other.

A short address to the children of the school at Coqualeetza was given by Principal Riley, after which Mayor E. Manuel and Rev. Mr. A. Wells extended a welcome to the visitors on behalf of the city and municipality. Reply was made by Rev. A. R. Lett, chairman of the Olympiad committee; Rev. E. F. Anfield, secretary, and Captain Barry, inspector of Indian schools in B.C. Each speaker emphasized the importance of playing games for the game's sake, of the need of good sportsmanship in all events, and making the meet a happy one for all competitors. They also voiced the hope that other schools would compete in Olympiads to be held in the future.

Following the addresses, a social hour was spent, visitors and guests becoming acquainted with each other, and taking the opportunity of admiring the handsome shield and other trophies on exhibition, to be won in the coming three days.

Musical numbers were excellently given by pupils of Coqualeetza, a two-piano duet being particularly enjoyable.

Preceding over the prettily arranged tea tables were Mrs. J. H. White and Miss McGregor, boys' matron, and Mrs. R. E. W. Biddell and Miss Taylor, girls' matron at the school, Mrs. A. Charlton cut the ice and Miss Taylor serving were Miss Estel MacKay, lady superintendent, Miss Milson, Miss Kathleen Clark, Vancouver, and Miss Alice Smith, Chilliwack.

Tuesday morning was an ideal day on which to begin the extended program of sports and everything went off with a good "bang" throughout the day. Many visitors from town were present at 1 o'clock to attend the formal opening. A colourful parade of the boys and girls of St. George's, in their red and white uniforms; of St. Michael's, in their gold and black uniforms; and of Coqualeetza, in their black and gold, the girls with smart mantles of white with the colours of black and gold embroidered on the front of their middies, was marshalled by Sergt.-Major Bain of Victoria and presented colours before Commissioner W. E. Ditchburn of Victoria. Mr. Ditchburn briefly addressed the group, wishing them success in their first meet, calling to their attention the desire of his department that good sportsmanship should prevail throughout and the hope that more schools would take part in coming years. Mr. Ditchburn, in charge of Indian schools, took the promise, and bespoke on behalf of the department at Ottawa their interest and good wishes in the event.

School Tradition

TRADITION is that which is neither law nor regulation, but the persuasive influence of the high ideals of the school, handed down unconsciously by outgoing to incoming students, to be imitated and passed on in turn. No school can be great without tradition—and no great school, or school with any pretence to worth or merit, can be without tradition. Some of the traditions Coqualeetzaans have striven to weave into the fabric of the school are:

Reverence for God's Word and all sacred institutions.

Loyalty to Canada, the Empire and the King.

"Play the Game," in classroom, playground and home.

"Do unto others as you would have them do unto you."

"Love Duty."

All necessary work is honourable.

Honour our Highdays and Holidays with the observation of all the beautiful, time-worn customs.

School Spirit

MISS E. MACKAY, B.A., Lady Principal

THROUGHOUT the Coqualeetza school year many things must operate to draw the members of the student body together. This year the games and sports, the fun and frolic have been shared by all.

The Academic and Vocational work of the different departments, if not the same, have been done under the same conditions. All inherit the school traditions. The same ideals of life, the Academic and Vocational guidance and preparation are placed before each student. In short, they foster the school health, or better still, the school spirit. This year the school spirit manifested itself not only in the hour of victory on the public occasion of winning the Olympiad Shield, but let us hope it manifested itself more potently in the tedious hours of study and in the work of the day, for these hours of study, these hours of work in Coqualeetza should be steps toward a particular trade or a particular profession.

In this 20th Century one must be fully equipped. Your school is a place of opportunity and we know from previous records and present ones that many students have realized it. The fact that much was expected of them, put them on their mettle, called forth that unselfish, intangible thing called "school spirit," which should be the stimulus to high endeavor.

Nine
Valedictory Address

OUR school has been like "Elfeland," joyous, happy. "Gradusteland" too, is interesting. As we look through a "Mystery Window" we glimpse "Knowledge" and "Success" standing quite aloof, while "Opportunity" knocks at the door. Over the cliff "Sins," "Temptation" smiles winningly. We wonder, do we fall? Experience gives a squeeze of hand for encouragement; introduces us to his "Light." A "Star," "Courage" sings cheerfully near by. But "Hope" comes gently to greet us. As she takes us to the "Alpine Path" we joyfully recognize two beautiful stars. They are "I live for the good that I can do" and "No backward step."

We've been called "Elves" at "Elfeland." The memory of our schoolmates, teachers and Principal will always inspire us. We sense a deep gratitude and will try to live worthily, for we take with us the high ideals and beautiful traditions of our school.

We wish the Principal and Staff every success and hope all their ambitions for us will come true.

We will have to choose the friends of our later life. Perhaps wisdom will not always guide us, but we realize there is One whom we can always trust, One who will share our troubles and joys alike and whom we can always love and who will always love us; our trust friend—God.

(signed) RUTH CASTLE,

Historical

1886—First Indian Day School organized by Rev. and Mrs. C. M. Tate, at Squahala.
1886—First Day School organized at the Mission House at Coqualeetza.
1887—Twelve children were taken in residence at the Mission House at Coqualeetza.
1889—First dormitory house built. Miss Helen was placed in charge.
1891—The Coqualeetza Home was destroyed by fire.
1893—A new building was erected. The office was completed in brick, with accommodation for one hundred pupils. The name was changed to Industrial Institute. Rev. C. M. Tate was made moral Governor.
1920—Mr. William C. Scott, after consultation with Rev. T. Ferrier and Principal Riley, decided the 1913 building had served its day and arranged for plans to be drawn up for a new building.
1920—R. Guerney (Esq., Assistant for the Indian Department), visited Coqualeetza, obtained data and approved plans for new school.
1921—The first unit of the new educational plant was commenced.
1922—(May 27). The Rev. S. D. Chowen, D.D., LL.D., General Superintendent of the Methodist Church, turned the first sod of the new building.
1923—Daily visits by Duncan MacKenzie, M.P., F.R.S.C., Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, laid the corner stone of the main building.
1924—New Coqualeetza formally opened October 21, Rev. G. H. Riley, Principal, and name changed from Industrial Institute to "Residential School."
1925—Coqualeetza took an important part in the great missionary pageant, 25th to 29th November, Wesley Church, Vancouver.
1926—First Coqualeetza Band.
1927—Coqualeetza established a record for Indian Art in design and carving at Vancouver Exhibition.
1928—Valerie Wells, student of Coqualeetza, awarded by the National Committee for the Diamond Jubilee Medal gold medal for drawing from Indians at Coqualeetza, on the subject "Indian."
1928—Lieutenant Governor Bruce and Miss Helen MacKenzie visited Coqualeetza and each planted a tree on campus in their honor.
1929—Robert Gray, King's Scout, First Coqualeetza Troop, went to the great Scout Jamboree in England.
1930—Visit of the Governor General Viscount Willingdon and Lady Willingdon. Each planted a tree on campus in their honor.
1931—First Indian Residential School Olympiad held at Coqualeetza to compete in athletics for Challenge Shield, donated by the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, to be contested for annually.
1931—Coqualeetza won the Department's shield at the first Olympiad.

GIRLS' BASKETBALL

The basketball season is over now and looking back, it has been quite successful. Although the girls' success has not been apparent in actual scores, I believe they have made good progress in basketball ability. We began practices late and had just one when we received a challenge from St. George's School, Lytton, for the first game. Although this was our first real game, we had never played basketball before, while the Lytton girls had been playing for several years. **Cadet Report**

CAPT. P. F. PIKE

The year 1930 was a very eventful time for the Coqualeetza Cadet Corps. It was the first time that the Corps won the handsome L.O.D.E. Shield for the greatest attendance at the Indian Residential School in B.C.

The promotion was made to Capt. A. U. Defries as an officer of the Provincial Chapter, L.O.D.E. It so happens that Miss Defries was accompanied on this visit by her husband the Right Rev. Archbishop. His Grace very kindly gave a three-minute address to the Corps on a few wise and effective sentences.

The regular winter training was carried out in the usual manner and the excellent work of springtime training took place. The Corpshad made good progress by the 16th of April when Captain MacKay inspected the Corps. He mentioned that he was well pleased with the appearance of the Corps and said that they were doing very well.

He highly commended Platoon Sgt. Wilson for the way he handled the platoon on drill and was pleased with the way the section leader, Platoon Sgt. Adams handled his particular sections. In all, the Corps did very well this season. Although the Corps is not as large as last year, every Cadet took a keen interest in the Corps and played his part well.

The Corps had a turn in the annual match. Barton won the special medal for highest man in the match. Cadet Gladstone and Cadet Watson each won a Second Class medal in the junior team.

A team was entered again this year in the Imperial Challenge Shield but the match has just been completed and the report will be sent to the Imperial Council.

At the last minute a team was entered in the R.M.C. Miniature Rifle match.

**Scout Report**

CAPTAIN PIKE, Scoutmaster

The Coqualeetza Troop started out very well this year with a new group of boys.

We hope another year may bring us more success. We have a new scoutmaster L. Beaz of the Chilliwack troop has been appointed a Commissioner for Chilliwack district so we will be a little closer to Headquarters.

Scouting meetings were held throughout the winter and good progress was made on tenderfoot and 2nd class work but there was no hike arranged due to the snow. "Scouting" was not there.

The Coqualeetza troop went to Vancouver for the Stampede. They visited Chilliwack and Chilliwack where they attended a jamboree picture showing scenes from the World Jamboree held at Birkenhead in 1929. The troop enjoyed it very much since the late troop leader, Robert Grey, represented Northern British Columbia at the jamboree. Robert Grey was Secretary of the Scouts there and it was the first opportunity the troop had the privilege of meeting him.

Early in the spring Coqualeetza was invited to a Scout display put on by the First Chilliwack Troop. We were very pleased and hope to have them as our guests next year.

Girl Guides

At a recent Girl Guide gathering in Winnipeg, Judge Haggard of the Juvenile Court said that there was no movement in the world at the present time more full of hope and girls than the Scout and Guide movement and so we are proud to be affiliated with this great movement. The Girl Guide Company has made good progress. Many of the Guides have become proficient in dog handling and all have worked assiduously towards efficiency badges.

We have had the privilege of encouraging leadership of our Commissioner, Mrs. A. Charlton, who has been an active worker throughout, but whose chief interest is in the welfare of the Guides.

We also regret the resignation of our Captain, Miss K. Clarke, who returned to her home in Vancouver after four years as Senior teacher. The events of the last day were hurried through as quickly as possible to allow time for the visiting tour to view the Fraser Valley and later to visit Harrison Hot Springs. TRIP TO LYTON

The Lytton Trip

Perhaps one of the most thrilling experiences of the year was the trip over the new Fraser Canyon Highway when the girls' and boys' basketball teams went to Lytton to play a return game with St. George's Residential School.

We left Coqualeetza at the early hours, everybody wide awake and keen for the day ahead. The experience was unique and that we made, we believe, the first bus trip over the new highway.

Never shall we forget the thrill of riding over a road that wound its way up and up until it became a mere thread along a mountain skyline. It amazes one to think how the Indians used to travel with horse and wagon, years ago, along the old Cariboo Highway which now remains here and there a mere trail clinging to the face of the mountain. To us the new road, which is very much wider and safer, offered supreme joy. When at last we reached a level stretch and breathed more freely a very real danger possessed itself.

A tree fell directly in the path of the bus. Seeing it fall the driver applied the brakes and just in time. It caught the front lamps of the bus, otherwise no serious damage was done and fortunately no one injured. So grateful for this averted disaster, we came to the famous Alexandra bridge. Our joy in crossing a new bridge was somewhat modified when we found that it was a toll bridge and our finances were depleted six dollars each way.

When we reached St. George's School we were welcomed by Principal and Mrs. Lett and after partaking of refreshments we went to the gymnasium where the games were played. Coqualeetza won the boys' games; Lytton won the girls'.

The bus returned at approximately 5:30 p.m., being on the "outside" of the road this time we were glad that it was soon dark so that we could not see the precipitous sides which fell away to the Fraser River 2000 feet below. Mile after mile we swung around the hairpin turns of the mountain range of which there are twenty-two to the mile. We all voted Mr. Cunningham a careful and skilful driver. By twelve o'clock that night we were all tired and happy and safely back at school.

CINDERELLA

Dainty Operetta Is Staged at Coqualeetza School

By J. H. BARKER

It has become a custom during the last few years at this season for the senior students at the Coqualeetza School to prepare and present a musical play or operetta for the entertainment and amusement of their juniors, who with a number of interested spectators, attend in order to appreciate the fare on offer.

On Tuesday evening a very dainty operetta was offered entitled, "The Maid and the Golden Slipper," by C. D. Richardson, based on the story of Cinderella, so well known and loved by young people all over the world.

The scenery, staging, costumes and makeup were admirable, the costumes especially being chosen with great care and attention to spectacular effect. The grouping together with the acting and singing of the different numbers would have done credit to any company having a much older experience.

Gwenne Watson deserves special mention for her sophistication and interpretation of the role of Godmother, as well as her charming singing and graceful deportment.

The step-mothers, Rosalind Watson and Doris McKeown displayed a very acceptable conception of their characters, and their performances were in their contemporaries' references to the difference between their own elegance and the poverty-stricken appearance of their step-daughter, Cinderella, who in the person of Edna Tate, gave an outstanding performance. The music was played by Misses Adams and Murray, doing the accompanying music with enthusiasm and applause of the audience.

The character of the Prince was enacted by Mr. Matheson with great nonchalance, his appearance on the stage being greeted with enthusiasm by the band of all the ladies at the ball, who on their part artfully endeavored to capture his attention.

The trying on and the departure of those who could not squeeze a foot into the tiny shoe, made a very amusing scene, and when Cinderella, unwillingly produced by the step-mother was found to be the possessor of the fortunate foot, and was ordered by the fairy godmother to go to the splendid ball dressed in the most magnificent costume, but with the stipulation that ever after happiness was considered complete. This, with the final chorus by the whole company brought the operetta to a triumphant conclusion.

Mention must be made of the characters of the stepmothers, adequately interpreted by Mercy Wesley, and the very captivating impersonation of Cinderella by the charming Miss Matheson, aged 9 years, whose bright little smile and quaint antics throughout were delightful.

The dancing and singing of the fairies and the lords and ladies, added considerably to the success of the evening, and the entire cast, including the pupils who attended, will have a number of pleasant memories to treasure in the days to come when they are far away from Coqualeetza.

The Rev. G. H. Riley, as principal is making a fine gesture in encouraging these young disciples to take part in such entertainments.

The songs were directed by Miss R. Clarke, Miss F. McKeown, Miss N. Campbell, with Miss D. Millson as accompanist, to whose untiring efforts the success of the musical portion is due. Miss F. Adams was responsible for the music of the ball. William on the stage was accompanied by Miss D. Millson accompanying with a pulsation of rhythm which carried the glee along with a nerve altogether refreshing.

Coqualeetza School Winner of Silver Shield and Cups

Mrs. C. Barber
Press correspondent, Chilliwack Progress and Vancouver Daily Province.

The three-day Indian school Olympiad held at Coqualeetza last week came to a happy conclusion on Thursday evening with the holding of a banquet in the large auditorium of the school. The gathering was attended by other guests and seventy-five Olympiad competitors and proved a fine finish to the three days' interesting and varied events.

The prizes were received by Principal and Mrs. G. H. Riley and Miss Ethel MacKay, lady superintendent of Coqualeetza, and all were delighted with the artistic arrangement of the tables, done in the three school colors and with pansies carrying out the gold and black of Coqualeetza.

Interest naturally centred round the announcement by Capt. Barry, inspector of Indian schools for the province, of the highest point winners. Coqualeetza proved to have distinguished herself in no uncertain manner by the winning of the coveted silver shield awarded to the school with the highest aggregate points. Affairs, Okanagan, and Comox Valley were the school winners the highest aggregate points, their number being 179; Lytton came second with 73½ points, and Alert Bay third with 59½ points. The result is particularly gratifying to the Sardis school as the training of the students is a part of the work done by the regular teaching staff.

The boys' cup for the greatest number of points was won by George Brown, Coqualeetza, and the girls' cup by Alice Strutt, Coqualeetza. The other first winners in the various events were given medals.

The presentation of prizes was made by Commissioner E. W. Ditchburn of Victoria, on behalf of the department. Mr. Ditchburn warmly congratulating the winners and remarking on the splendid sportsmanship exhibited throughout by all contestants.

Three toasts were proposed and responded to during the evening. "Our Guests" was proposed in an impressive address by Principal Riley, Rev. A. R. Lett, as chairman made an appropriate and congratulatory response. "The Department of Indian Affairs" was proposed by Rev. Anfield and was ably responded to by Commissioner Ditchburn. "The Municipality, City of Chilliwack and the Chilliwack Board of Trade" were grouped together in a toast proposed by Capt. Barry and spoken to by Mayor E. McIntyre.

A very pleasing gesture at the close of the banquet was the gift of a leather bound presentation copy by the boys and girls of the visiting teams to Principal Riley. In a few well-chosen words, Miss Margaret McIntyre of St. George's School, Lytton, made the presentation.

Mr. Riley thanked them, saying that all he had done had been a pleasure. He had enjoyed their presence every minute of the visit and he hoped the splendid feeling and the friendships formed amongst the students of the three schools would continue through life.

The beginning of any enterprise is always interesting. The principals of three Indian Residential Schools, namely, Rev. A. R. Lett, St. George's, Lytton, appointed chairman; Mr. F. E. Antfield, Sr., Michael's, Alert Bay, appointed secretary, and Rev. G. H. Riley, Coqualeetza, appointed treasurer met at the Indian Office at Vancouver, on November 16th, and discussed the advisability of inter-school sports. Coqualeetza Chapel Fund

"The Chapel"—as sketched from imagination by one of the Students, Percy Barton.

The above sketch by Percy Barton was made hurriedly. It is not to be taken as an exact picture of Coqualeetza's prospective Chapel, but to bring before us in a vivid manner the fact that the time has arrived when we should commence a campaign to raise the funds necessary for its erection. The objective is $110,000.

Sixteen years ago the Principal received $250 to be applied to some object for the benefit of the school. As there had been talk of the need of a Chapel, he opened a savings account in the First National Bank, and each month since then has added to it for a chapel service once a year on Graduation Sunday an offering has been taken for this purpose. The manual training class made an offertory box. This stands in the entrance hall of the school. Any who amongst viewers, the sick and pupils feel disposed to give in this charitable spirit. The Chapel is expected at last and each year we add to our deposit to the bank. The Chapel Fund now stands at $14,067.96. We have received a few voluntary subscriptions. For these we are grateful. Now the time is ripe for a campaign to raise funds. We urgently appeal to the graduates and ex-pupils for donations. We appeal to the Board of Directors to make this case the subject of an appeal. We appeal to the parents of the children attending Coqualeetza, and receive the real heart of the undertaking. We appeal to former members of the staff whose interest in the school has not waned. We appeal to friends of the native people.

During the year we were surprised to receive a gift of $100 from Miss Young of Cobourg, former boy's monitor, the deed of a building lot in South Vancouver overlooking the harbour, on which we are asked to realize, devoting the proceeds to the Chapel Fund. Miss Young's devotion and loyalty to her old school has always been a source of pleasure. I am sure, living here and there in the North, men who were under her care when they were boys, who remember her kind sympathy and splendid example with gratitude.

Notice of Gratification

It is very gratifying that at head quarters in Ottawa the authorities are alive not only to the mental welfare of the native boys and girls, but to their need for recreation. Mr. Russell T. Ferrier, the Superintendent of Education, who has always been an advocate of good athletics, has himself approved and interested the Deputy Minister in the Olympiad to such an extent that it was made possible, and we extend, as a school to the Department, our heartfelt thanks.

March 28th,

My dear Dr. McGill:

The Board of Home Missions of The United Church of Canada, at its annual meeting last week, passed the following resolution:

"Moved by Rev. K. J. Beaton,
Seconded by Rev. E. D. Braden,

"That we nominate to the Indian Department for the office of Principal-elect of Coqualeetza Residential School the Rev. R. C. Scott, B.A."

Rev. G. H. Raley, the Principal of Coqualeetza is reaching the age of retirement, and has intimated his intention of resigning in June, 1934. We felt that in such a large institution his successor should be with him for an academic year in order to learn the details of the work. It is our idea that Mr. Scott will be associated with Mr. Raley as Assistant Principal beginning with September of this year.

Robert Clyde Scott, B.A., whose name we submit in nomination for this important position, was born at Paisley, Ontario, in 1891. He is a graduate in Arts of the University of Toronto and in Theology of Victoria University. He has given seventeen years of distinguished service to the Church as the Commodore of our marine fleet on the coast of British Columbia, and is well and favorably known to all the Indian tribes between Cape Mudge and Alaska. His first appointment after ordination was to an Indian Mission and he has been intensely interested in their advancement ever since.

By temperament and training Mr. Scott is peculiarly fitted for dealing with the Indian people and his long association with them as the Captain of the "Thomas Crosby" has given him a very intimate knowledge of their psychology. He knows hundreds of the graduates of Coqualeetza personally, and in the recruitment of new pupils will undoubtedly have the loyal support of every graduate of this great school.

Mr. Scott is personally known to Hon. T. G. Murphy, the Minister of the Interior, and before bringing his name before our Board, I discussed informally with Mr. Murphy the fact that I intended to nominate him. I have known him
myself since we were class-mates in college and have no hesitation in saying that the appointment will be received with universal satisfaction throughout the United Church.

I shall be glad to receive your approval of this nomination, so that I may communicate it to Mr. Scott and to our British Columbia Conference.

Yours very sincerely,

Are We Doing Enough To Help the Indians?

By J. W. W.

Before the white man came to bother them, the original people of this province had a simple life, almost primitive. It was a simple life, but problems of the culture had grown, but problems of the spirit had grown, too. The white man had come, and what added even beyond these complications was the fact that the Indians were not the objects of praise or the water as they came out to meet us, but we were setting our feet upon their land.

We looked graciously on their innocence, the principle which prompted consistently in all our contacts has led to most of the troubles which have arisen.

The Indian was self-supporting. That "Support" may have been meager, comfortless, but it was there. For one thing, he fought only when he was strong enough, and because no one dared. For another, he was able to take care for himself; there was no need.

Taking from his soil his valuable assets, he became dependent. It was not long before the white man began to realize that the Indians were not merely a problem, but a threat. They were a threat to the white man's way of life. They were a threat to the white man's way of life.

The future of the Indian south is a serious problem for both educationalist and statesman. It is facing from many quarters today, and the late Dr. G. H. Bailey, late principal of the Columbia Indian School at Skeetch, where he has been developing a system of education and training in the country on the sound principles of the Christian religion.

Dr. Bailey was particularly fitted for this work. Born in Yorkshire of good family, his father being a prominent member of the Christian gentleman, he came to Canada in his teens with the record of an athletic, sporting youth. He was educated at Toronto in 1865, married in 1869 a lady who became his wife for life, and entered the ministry then undertaken, for he volunteered for missionary work among the Indians of the northern coast of British Columbia, the first mission being established at Skeetch.

In this isolated place, Dr. and Mrs. Bailey spent thirteen years. The young minister became a friend to the Indians, and Indians, to be known as "The Eldest Son," became a great friend to the Indians. He visited a small mission school there, organized the first fair held on the north-west coast of B.C.,

He died while still engaged in missionary work, and his death was a great loss to the Indians of the north-west coast.

LETTER NO. 44

COQUALSETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

November, 1935

To Our Graduates and Friends:

It is a pleasure to write you once more and bring to you news of the school, as well as to assure you of our deep interest in you.

School has settled down nicely for the short pull that remains to put studies and games and all across before Christmas. Of course we are not really at home until after Halloween, for, from the time the boys and girls get back, they look forward with great anticipation to that wonderful evening. This year, it seemed as though all past celebrations were undone. Four parties in all were held, the Primaries, Juniors, Intermediates and Seniors. How we did wish that you folks back home could have looked in upon us! In the afternoons the younger children enjoyed games in the Assembly Hall and then went to the dining room for their feast of good things. In the evening, softly shaded lights cast their spell over everything, through festoons of drapery in black and gold. Upon the walls, black cats played hide and seek among the big yellow pumpkins. Party dresses were the order of the day for the girls and they looked their best this year, so everyone said. The boys were on hand, neat and fit looking and one and all thoroughly enjoyed themselves. "Three Jolly Fishermen," "Crows and Cranes," and "Hares and Hounds" brought everyone into the spirit of the evening, and "The Ace of Diamonds" was, as usual, most popular of the Folk Dances. Musical Chairs, Apples on a String and Relay Races completed a fine evening's fun. In the Dining Room, special tables carried all sorts of good things to eat and big pumpkins grinned a welcome when the lights were turned low. Mr. Peake is "some carver"; ask the Intermediates and Seniors if he does not know how to cut a man's face in a pumpkin!

Founder's Day brought happiness too. Dr. White, ever welcome friend of the School, spoke of the early days and brought a message of cheer and encouragement on Sunday evening. On Monday evening the School enjoyed a real good picture show, and for supper beforehand, sat down to a very fine birthday supper. In the centre aisle, upon a table, stood the Birthday Cake, with its forty-six candles. These were set alight by Dolly Dick and Jean Little and these girls also extinguished them later, and then the cake was cut by Principal Scott. Miss Bailey has distinguished herself in preparation of these fine Birthday and Halloween suppers. Uniform kindliness, a motherly heart, efficiency in her work and experience make her just indispensable upon these happy occasions.

Sports are well under way, and although we miss Oliver Adams and others on the Football teams, still the boys are taking hold well. They have won one game and lost one so far, and the one they lost was to the best team in the League. We were proud of them, even at that, for they never quit playing right to the very last, and we look for a good return game with this team, when we are sure the boys of Coqualeetza will show them something. We have no Basket Ball team this year, but have a good one in the making for next year. We hope, this year to start Badminton for the girls.

A new departure has been the setting up of a Home Economics Kitchen, with Mrs. Morrison in charge. Through the interest of the Department of Indian Affairs, a grant sufficient to buy the stove and other equipment was secured. The room has been remodelled, an extra

FOREWORD

The year has come and gone, and the school that echoed and resounded with laughter and song, and at times just plain noise, stands silent and empty, save for the farm and garden workers and one or two others. How quiet it is in the hallways where the boys did their work but a short time ago, to the class rooms and to morning and evening prayers. And the days will soon pass and bring the time September the Third—when school will be back for another year.

Examinations are over. Of our High School Class of fifteen, five received first class honors, six passed with second and two with third. In these honors the Algonquin led easily with Fraser Valley pupils well behind, with Nass River and Bella Coola close up for third place; then came Queen Charlotte Island and Port Simpson. The results are significant awards and have given hope to both our candidates. Examinations in Public School Grades were very satisfactory.

Our Boat Building Department has been re-organized with Mr. Hadfieldstone in charge. He has proved himself a capable and successful teacher. Twelve boys have received an excellent training in boat and metal work. One 28 feet complete gill net and trolling boat and three row boats were built since Christmas. All work has been done with care and thoroughness. The boats are of good design, strong and durable, staunch, seaworthy and serviceable. The boys have shown good interest and have been given instruction covering all phases of boat work from building to outfitting and rigging. Two classes of boys have been registered with Mr. Frank Edwards in Motor Mechanics. The Principal and others who have "picked up" some of these classes have often wished that they might have had the opportunity which these boys are receiving. They get a good working knowledge of gas engines, starters, dynamos and generators, with practice on the same oil that goes with up-to-date boat and car equipment.

In Manual Training the boys under Mr. George Wilson have received valuable instruction in carpentry, boat building and in practical work. We fully expect our Manual Training Department to carry off the major share of the prizes at the Vancouver Exhibition again this year. Through the able hands of the teachers it is being conglomerated by having such capable instructors, and is indebted also to the Department of Indian Affairs for tools and equipment for this work, as well as for other tokens of loyal support.

In the Girls' Section Miss O. Ainslie and Mrs. Prest have given instruction in carding, spinning and weaving and have given training in the use of various machines. Embroidering and needlework on linens and upon blanket cloths of symbolic Native designs, have produced some really beautiful purses, runners, rugs, hangings, radio mats and throws. Three of these girls, who are proficient in this art, the girls and bearing Native designs, when displayed in Regina, encountered sale farther East, were promptly purchased there. This department is now open for native handiwork and the market is growing every year. Coqualeetza is strongly supporting this movement. Rev. Dr. Ralph and other traders have also become interested in opening new avenues of exchange for genuine native articles and it is hoped that real help will be afforded to pupils in making a living when they return to their homes.

Through the kindness of Mrs. Scott and the instruction of Miss Kay Mathers a special Home Economics Class was started. The Principal's residence was used each month, and the pupils covered twenty hours instruction in baking and cooking as done in a family of average size. At the close of each lesson, the recipes used were written out and given to the pupils for use at home when school was over. Plans are being laid for an extension of this work during the coming year and the work covered will be of great value to the girls in their future homes.

Coqualeetza has been fortunate also in having Mrs. Price as instructor in Music. Singing was taught regularly in the class rooms. It was a great treat to the children to go to sleep and then "wake up" and guess what their little friends had been singing. They thus learned to sing while playing a game. Individual students were tested, passed and encouraged. Miss Dolly Dick, passed the introductory examination in the Toronto Conservatory of Music. A recital was given in the Assembly Room by these students, and was much enjoyed by all present.

Best of all, the pupils have shown real interest in the religious life of the school. Eighteen boys and girls accepted Christ as their Savior and nineteen others re-dedicated their lives to God. We hope to keep in touch with the graduates who have left school this year as we do with the children who are now on holidays. Over thirty children are in our fine new camp near White Rock and join in activities according to parent and friend's wishes from the boy who spends his summer and friends at home. We look forward to the coming year with much anticipation.

REV. R. C. SCOTT, B.A.,
principal.
Circular Letter #3

COQUELEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

May, 1935.

To Parents, Graduates and Friends:

Easter has come and gone and the school year is rapidly hastening to a close. We are sure that the parents and friends of the School would like to hear just how we have been getting along since the winter left us eagerly awaiting the coming of the Springtime. Although long delayed, it has come - green grass and lovely flowers, with tree foliage almost cut complete, are the order of the day. In School games, football is over and soft ball and track events have taken its place. We have 4 soft ball teams organized among the girls and 4 among the boys. On Accession Day the girls turned down a very chivalrous offer on the part of the boys to play them "left handed" and said they would not accept any challenge until they were able to play the boys right handed, or any other way they might wish. A fine spirit indeed, and hence hoping the girls make the progress they look for. Athletics play a big part in School life and make for health and wholesome spirit among the children, as well as forming a very real part of the training for actual life when School is over.

But we have not forgotten the more important things either. It was a glad sight to see the boys and girls who came to the Assembly Hall, following a series of talks by the Principal, upon the Life of Christ, leading up to the sacrifice upon Calvary, for the sins of the earth; love overcoming evil in the sheer power and beauty of that Divine life, which gave itself freely and for us all, upon the Cross. Without urging and quite freely, of their own accord, 32 boys and girls handed in cards signifying their wish to become members of the Church upon profession of their faith in Christ, 18 others also signed cards, saying that they wished to rededicate themselves to His service. As the Principal was absent upon Conference work in the East, the reception of these boys and girls into Membership in the Church will take place a little later. Arrangements will be made for the pupils who wish to join the Anglican Church to do so and they shall attend classes conducted by the Rev. R.M. Searles of St. John's at Sardis. But whether it be the Anglican Church or the United Church, the emphasis is placed on the fact that it is THE CHURCH OF CHRIST which these pupils are joining. Our hearts are glad, indeed, at this response upon the part of our boys and girls. In the absence of the Principal in the East, on Easter Sunday Evening, all the senior boys and girls attended German United Church in Sardis, where a very beautiful Easter Cantata "The Resurrection" was given by the Church Choir and was much enjoyed by everyone present.

Accession Day has just passed and what a day it was! In the morning at 7:15, the entire School gathered about the flag pole and as the Union Jack floated out when two of our "Cub" Scouts pulled the halyard, broke out into the National Anthem. This was followed by prayer by the Principal, then, before marching back to the dining room for breakfast, three rousing cheers were given for the King and for Queen Mary. At 10:15, after finishing morning chores, everyone gathered in the Assembly Hall and listened in, to the Empire Broadcast. How wonderful it was to hear the King's voice and to hear him
Circular Letter #3.

May, 1935.

say to the children of the Empire, "THE KING IS SPEAKING TO YOU!" Every word was heard distinctly, as was each item of the wonderful program, when, one after another of the places in the far-flung Empire contributed its part. After lunch Soft Ball games held the interest of all. The first game was between the girls and the Staff. It was won by the girls by some two runs, but it was hard fought from the start. Later the senior boys played and after supper another game was played between two boys teams. But we nearly forgot the Jubilee cake, ornamented in its icing and trailing ribbons of red, white and blue, and resting 25 birthday candles, which, during supper, were set alight, with the cheers of the children. When they had burned down, the two boys who had baked it and the two girls who had iced it had the fun of blowing them out. One blast and every candle was extinguished. After the senior boys and girls proceeded to the back farm, where a big bonfire was set alight and around it arose the merry glee and song loud and clear. Under the capable leadership of Mr. Poole, and so it would have gone far into the night, but bed time was approaching and after ice cream had been served, all joined in singing around the dying fire, the appropriate words of the hymn "Abide with Me" fast falls the eveningside. Back through the moonlight we went to the school, where tired, but happy children were soon in dreamland, after a most wonderful day, which will live long in their memories.

And now in closing, let us say that Holidays are fast approaching, holiday agreements are coming in with every mail, but many are still out. Parents must let us know, when and where they wish their children to be sent for holidays, and fare money must be provided by them, best of all, now, for our School supply cannot pay the number of fares necessary to send all pupils home and the Department of Indian Affairs will not do so. If not sent now, then it must be sent later. Residential schools are doing their own, in the esteem of our parents, and those who have children whom they wish to send, should notify the Principal right away, or they may be disappointed and not be able to get them in. Ask your Indian Agent for the form of Application, have the children examined by your Doctor and ask the Indian Agent to notify the Principal also.

Bright sunshine, blue skies, singing birds, green lawns and lovely flowers are with us once more and will all help to make our last weeks of school enjoyable. All children who remain at school for the Holiday, will be taken to the Camp at White Rock for two months at the Seaside, where boating swimming, hikes, games and all that goes with a real Holiday, will be enjoyed by the children, under careful supervision.

With every good wish to all back home in the villages, from the pupils and members of Staff, I am,

Yours sincerely,

R. Scott

Principal
LETTER NO.2. JANUARY 1935.

To Parents, Graduates and Friends:

Let it be well on in January, but not too late to wish all our friends a very HAPPY AND PROSPEROUS NEW YEAR.

School life is settling down into its usual course after the many happy occasions of holiday time. If you could only have seen the School and the children! Parents and friends would have been delighted and many a Graduate would have liked to be back once again as a pupil. As a matter of fact we had ONE Graduate, Charlie Williams of Duncan, B.C., for a few days at Christmas time and other friends from Duncan and Kokiliah. For a week before Christmas our big Buick car, which some of the boys named "Very Ann" made from three to four round trips every day between the School and Chilliwack so that the pupils could do their Christmas Shopping. This was great improvement on going in on the Tram, and it was thoroughly enjoyed.

As Christmas approached the School became a hive of activity. The main corridor was adorned with long garlands of greenery among which nestled red berries which might well have grown there, so real did they look. In the main hall, on the one side a Post Office had been set up, with all the regular post office signs, "Mail Xmas Cards here", etc etc and in this were placed all parcels coming into the School for the Children. The afternoon of Xmas day they were all given out to the ones for whom they were intended by parents and friends. Across from the Post Office was a woodland scene. Two cottages nestled at the foot of what looked like tall fir trees. Bits of cotton wool upon the branches gave an appearance of a snow storm, and from the windows of the two bungalows came beams of light bringing at once the suggestion of warmth and Christmas cheer. In the foreground was a rink with what looked like a sheet of real ice, and upon it figures of the well known Maple Leaf Hockey Team playing another team—was it Coqualeetza? Stretching from the forest to the Post Office was an overhead illuminated sign wishing one and all who entered a Merry Xmas. One caught the spirit of Xmas as soon as he entered the building. Xmas Eve stockings were hung in long lines in the corridors upstairs. Outside of the dormitory of the little boys was a chair upon which was placed a glass of milk and a biscuit to refresh Santa on his way about the school. Believe it or not there were only a few crumbs of the biscuit left in the dormitory when the wee men got up and the glass of milk was empty. Puzzle—Who drank it? But the biggest joke of all was when the big boys all got up and made their beds and got dressed ready to come downstairs Miss MacGregor, watchful mother of them all, had to shoo them all back to bed saying it was only TWO O'CLOCK.

Bright and early everyone was astir and the wonderful day began. At Nine Thirty the Sacrament of the Lord's Supper was dispensed in the Assembly Hall and over one hundred of the Staff and Pupils partook with thanksgiving for the Heavenly Father's "Unspeakeable Gift". Noon brought a wonderful Xmas dinner, roast goose with plum pudding and all the trimmings. At 4 P.M. Santa Claus arrived in a sleigh drawn by four prancing steeds recruited from the "Cubs". Jolly and fat, and full of fun as ever, Santa soon made every child happy. With quick intuition one wee laddie said as Santa was giving out
the gifts: "It looks like Santa but it sounds like Mr. Peake", and he was dead right.

Supper time saw a big Christmas Cake—well over a hundred and fifty pounds—ready to be cut up and served among the children. By nine thirty at night all was quiet and tired but happy children snuggled down under the bed clothes and soon were off to the Land of Dreams.

On the Sunday evening before Christmas a very beautiful Pageant was staged under the direction of Mrs. McKenzie, Assistant Boy's Matron. It was called the "Bethlehem Manger", and one by one the different groups—the Wise Men, the Shepherds, and later those representing Learning and Youth and Motherhood—came to offer their gifts to the Infant Christ, and to acknowledge the debt each one owed to Him. It was all very beautiful and impressive. One was delighted with the naturalness with which the children took their parts.

Friday evening between Christmas and the New Year's, the High School boys put on a very fine concert. It was well carried out, and gave a lot of pleasure to the audience.

On New Year's Eve the Senior pupils gathered with the Staff in a Watch Night Service. A short address was given by the Principal stressing God's goodness during the past year, and in the period of silent prayer preceding the coming of the New Year, hearts were bowed before the Lord Jesus, and petitions for guidance ascended from every heart.

Later on the Seniors assembled in the kitchen and much noise with improvised cymbals of pot lids and big spoons finally gave way to the murmur of subdued voices as one and all enjoyed cake and cocoa.

New Year's afternoon the Primary children enjoyed themselves in a party at which games were played, and in the evening the Seniors held their usual Masquerade Party, any and varied were the costumes:

Marjorie Wilson gained the prize for the School Colors as "Belle of the Nineties": Carline Wilson was judged to have the best Comic costume Josephine Williams in a Scotch dress gained the prize for the most original make up. Harry Amos and Billy Young as "Mr. and Mrs. Sambo" gained great praise as a Negro Couple. Livingstone Adams distinguished himself in portraying a Chinaman, eyes and facial lines being well nigh perfectly done, and Gordon Robinson as a Diver showed well up in the list of well thought out costumes.

The day following in the afternoon the juniors had their party and in the evening the Intermediates—"Three Jolly Fishermen", "The Farmers in his Dell", The Grand old Duke of York", and a folk dance—always very popular—"The Ace of Diamonds" gave opportunity for lots of noise and song and romping jollity.

As the New Year draws upon us in earnest, let us give ourselves heartily to our work, so that the New Year may hold for us each one abundant cause for happiness and satisfaction. In School we are whether at Coqualeetza or having graduated and entered the School of Life in the village. Let us resolve each one this year to:

Build it well whate'er you do,
Build it straight and strong and true;
Build it clean and high and broad,
Build it for the eye of God.

Generally speaking, the little improvement which might result from a change of curriculum would scarcely compensate for the expense and trouble involved. It is better to follow the curriculum as provided by the various provinces. Even if there were a change, a curriculum suitable for British Columbia would not necessarily be satisfactory for the prairies, and it would be very difficult, if not impossible, to get one satisfactory to so many diverse native peoples such as is found in Canada.

The Commission has commended the start made in the preparation of books for Primary Grades in Indian Schools, and has recommended that this work be extended to cover the work of the first two years. If we are to accept the aim of the Commission, that of training the Indian pupils to Christian citizenship, and of raising them to our own culture, it would seem advisable at the very beginning to place before them books essentially ours in content.

Although a great number of children are "stalled" at Grade VI, it is evident that gradually but surely the standard of achievement is being raised; more pupils are completing higher grades and at a younger age. They have come to the stage when they might even resent a curriculum specially prepared for them, thus tending to widen the breach between them and the white child, and to augment the already existing inferiority complex. Even in Geography and History they show considerable interest, and it is rather a good thing to broaden their vision, for it is only by understanding the laws of cause, of cause and effect, and of geographical environment that they will come to understand the world in which they live, and thus outgrow their inferiority complex. We are of the opinion that the curriculum as laid down by the provinces is basically sound and broad, and that in general it should be followed.

We recommend that Receiving Classes and Grade I be kept in school all day, provision being made for suitable recreation periods.

The art of learning to speak the English language is acquired more in the departments than in the classroom. In the classroom there is invariably a restraint and self-consciousness owing to the presence of the other sex, and they find this ideal situation in the departments. The same thing applies to the teaching of the rules of health and cleanliness. The theory may come in the classroom, but the practice and checking up must be done in the department.

Regarding Composition, it is true that they make their own peculiar mistakes quite different from those of the white child, and these errors must be remedied by corrective exercises as the teacher sees fit. It may be one case in which a text, or work book of corrective exercises might profitably be undertaken, as the Indian child's mistakes and difficulties in composition are not identical with those of a white child.

Teachers should be sent books and material ordered from the Department on the requisitions, provided they have first been ratified by the Inspector. Even substitutes are a handicap.

All graduate pupils should be given a good self-containing dictionary.

There should be a similar recognition for school achievements as for sports. Too often Sports Day holds a very spectacular place with suitable awards, quite in contrast with the lack of recognition for scholastic achievements.
