My dear Mr. Crerar:  

Re: The Rebuilding of the Alberni School and the Utilization of the Coqualeetza School as a T.B. Sanatorium.  

I beg to acknowledge your letter of May 8th, in answer to my letter to you of April 28th, in which I enclosed a summary of what my colleagues and I understood were the decisions reached in the conference held in your office on April 25th, 1939. I am glad to know that the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch are of the opinion that the Memorandum which we submitted contained an accurate summary of the discussions which took place and the tentative agreement reached at that time.

I may say that your reply is quite satisfactory to us, with the exception of what you have to say in reference to our request for a definite statement that the policy of the Department will be to operate the proposed Sanatorium at Coqualeetza on a purely non-sectarian basis, giving equal privileges to all religious bodies, both Catholic and non-Catholic. My colleagues and myself are of the opinion that your letter does not give us at all in explicit terms the guarantee we must have if we are to carry with us our United Church constituency in British Columbia, and if we are to get approval of the whole idea from our Executive when it meets on June 12th.

It is hardly sufficient for you to tell us that in the operation of the Sanatorium you are going to cooperate with the Provincial Health authorities and that it will be conducted in the same way as the hospital now in operation at Qu'Appelle. Quite frankly, we have had reports that some of our people in Saskatchewan have not been satisfied that the administration of the Qu'Appelle institution has been entirely free from sectarian bias. To be perfectly candid, I am already receiving letters from United Church people around Coqualeetza to the effect that, since the Coqualeetza School has been under Protestant auspices for so long, the
appointment at any time of a Roman Catholic medical superintendent or matron would cause trouble, and would give the impression that the whole institution had been turned over to that Church.

In view of all these circumstances, we feel that we are not unreasonable in asking that an assurance very much more definite and explicit than that contained in your letter of May 8th should be given us in writing.

Since I wrote you on April 28th, another point on which we want assurance was raised by my colleague, Dr. Dorey, in his letter of May 3rd to Dr. McGill. It had to do with the effect which the establishment of a large T.B. Sanatorium like Coqualeetza would have upon the number of Indian patients which are now being treated in our United Church hospitals in the northern part of the Province of British Columbia, at Hazelton, Fort Simpson and Bella Bella. Two of these hospitals had additions made to them in recent years, to the cost of which the Government contributed, with the understanding that a certain number of beds would be reserved for Indian tuberculosis patients. Since there seems to be some doubt about the future policy in this matter, we must have it cleared before any final consent is given by the United Church to the use of Coqualeetza as a sanatorium.

We are very anxious, indeed, to have these matters cleared up before the meeting of our Executive early in June, so that, if possible, we may give you a definite answer at that time.

Looking forward to hearing from you in the near future,

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

(sgd.) R. B. Cochrane.

of British Columbia who are adherents of the United Church. In the meantime I can assure you that if it is necessary to provide additional accommodation at Bella Coola, Cape Mudge and Kitamaat, this provision will be made at the earliest possible date. Dear Dr. McGill:

Since leaving Ottawa yesterday afternoon, I have been turning over in my mind certain questions which arose during the course of our conversation yesterday morning.

You will remember that Dr. Moore discussed a policy for dealing with tuberculosis, which had in mind isolation rather than treatment of a considerable number of people who might not be considered eligible for treatment in a sanatorium. I got the impression from him that this rather large group of people constituted a menace to the success of any campaign for the eradication of tuberculosis amongst the Indian people. As I understand it, Dr. Moore has in mind the placing of this group of people in some institution where they would not get the medical care and attention that they would receive in a sanatorium. I presume that this would be on the basis that cases were more or less quiescent or possibly pretty nearly hopeless. In any event, you will remember that he raised the question of the cost per day of the care of these people, pointing out that $2.75 was altogether too high for that type of care.

You will, I am sure, realize that I am not presuming to offer any opinion as to the advisability or otherwise of the plan proposed by Dr. Moore - that, after all, is a matter for the medical profession; neither am I making any criticism of Dr. Moore's suggestion that the cost ought to be brought down from $2.75. As I said at the time, we ought to study whether we can cut down the cost of hospitalization per patient per day. However, in the course of the conversation, Dr. Moore outlined - or seemed to outline - his proposal as something like this:

He would take all T.B. cases that offer any hope of cure and place them in the proposed new Sanatorium at Coqualeetza, and in this institution he would make provision for as many of these cases as it is likely the Government can pay for. This would leave for care by our Hospitals at Fort Simpson and Hazelton only those cases which ought to be segregated and for which Dr. Moore thinks care should be provided at a rate considerably below the $2.75 which is at present paid.
May I repeat that I am not in a position either to judge of the practicability or feasibility of this plan, nor am I offering any criticism, but I feel I ought to write to you and say that, in view of the fact that this may seriously affect the revenues of the two hospitals mentioned, and may indeed very seriously impair their usefulness, we feel that, before we can recommend to our Executive that we acquiesce in the plan already outlined for Coqualeetza, this phase of the matter, which is rather new, should receive consideration; and that we feel that, not only should it receive consideration, but that unless we can come together on this in some way, there will be very grave doubt in the minds of the members of the Executive of the Board of Home Missions as to the wisdom of going any further with the negotiations regarding Coqualeetza.

Perhaps you will be good enough to discuss this with Dr. Moore and let us have your considered judgment in the matter. To my mind it is very important that this aspect of the whole matter be cleared up, as it may seriously affect the amount of money which we shall have to put into the operation of our hospitals. You will realize that we want to co-operate in every way possible with your Department, that we have every sympathy with the campaign which you are waging against tuberculosis, but that naturally we must look ahead some distance in such matters as these.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I am sending forward herewith, for your information, copy of a memorandum received by the Minister from the Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church.

You will note that this memorandum contains a summary of a discussion that took place at the Minister's office on the forenoon of April 25, 1939. The Minister has acknowledged receipt of this memorandum and intimated to the United Church authorities that he is in substantial agreement with the conclusions outlined in the communication.

The opinion was expressed at the conference that Inspector Barry and Captain Scott could, if they got together, reach certain definite conclusions with respect to the classroom accommodation that should be provided in addition to the new school at Alberni, consisting of two units with accommodation for 200 pupils, and an improved day school at Ahousaht. It was intimated that Mr. Scott had a rather intimate knowledge of Indian homes in the northern districts of the province and would be in a position to state definitely the approximate number of Indian children for whom accommodation at residential schools should be provided. It is just possible, of course, that in certain cases there may be lack of agreement between him and Captain Barry. Such cases might be referred to the Indian agent for his opinion.

It has been decided to proceed with the construction of the Alberni Residential School just as soon as plans can be prepared and tenders advertised. This building will consist of two distinct units - a dormitory unit and an educational unit with four classrooms, to provide for 200 pupils, and full basement accommodation. In the meantime and until certain adjustments are made the Ahousaht and Coqualeetza Residential Schools will be kept open and in operation. It is the intention of the Minister, however, that the Coqualeetza School should be equipped and used as a sanatorium at the earliest possible date.

MEMORANDUM ON CONFERENCE RE COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

A delegation consisting of Dr. Cochrane, Dr. Dorey, Captain Scott, and Mrs. Loveys met with the Minister and the following officials,- Dr. Camsell, Dr. McGill, Mr. Hoey, Dr. P. E. Moore, and Mr. C. W. Jackson, on April 25, 1939. The delegation presented the Memorandum which had been prepared and left copies with the officials. After a lengthy discussion, the delegation from the United Church understood that the following tentative agreement was reached:

1.- That the Department would proceed immediately with the building of a school to provide for 200 pupils,- this school to be in two units; (a) A residential unit, to provide dormitory, dining room and other accommodation for the 200 resident pupils; and (b) a second unit to consist of four classrooms; together with full basement - basement to be used for manual training, and possibly a gymnasium; and the four class-rooms to provide for the educational needs of the children housed in the dormitory.

2.- The erection of this building is to proceed as soon as possible, but, in the meantime, children will be accommodated at Coqualeetza. The Department officials agree to give careful study to the figures presented in the Memorandum, at the earliest possible moment, and are to satisfy the officials of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church that the Department will make adequate provision for the education of our children -

(a) In a new school at Alberni.

(b) In an improved day school at Ahousaht, to provide for fifty children at that point; the appropriation for this new improved day school to be included in the estimates for the fiscal year 1940-41.

(c) In additions to other day schools at Bella Coola, Cape Mudge and other points.

(d) By the erection, also, of an improved day school at Kitamaat.

3.- If, while the erection of the new Alberni School is being proceeded with, it is impossible to make provision for the full number of United Church children as suggested, the Department will transfer as many pupils as may be necessary to Edmonton,- this accommodation at Edmonton to be temporary.

4.- The Department will, on taking over Coqualeetza, operate it as a Sanatorium - that is, free from control -
control or supervision by any of the churches or denominations; but provision will be made for chaplain service or religious services by Roman Catholic and non-Catholic Churches on an equal footing.

5.- That during the time of transition between Coqualeetza and Alberni, the Department will keep closely in touch with the Secretaries of the Board of Home Missions and will not take any step with regard to the transfer of pupils without consultation with the United Church representatives.

6.- That, if the Department furnishes the delegation with a written statement, agreeing substantially with this statement now submitted, the Committee will ask the Executive of the Board of Home Missions, at its next meeting, and the Woman's Missionary Society, to agree to the proposal.
Ottawa, May 3, 1939.

MEMORANDUM ON CONFERENCE RE COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

A delegation consisting of Dr. Cochrane, Dr. Dorey, Captain Scott, and Mrs. Loveys, met with the Minister and the following officials—Dr. Camsell, Dr. McMill, Mr. Hoey, Dr. P. E. Moore, and Mr. C. W. Jackson, on April 25, 1939. The delegation presented the Memorandum which had been prepared and left copies with the officials. After a lengthy discussion, the delegation from the United Church understood that the following tentative agreement was reached:

1.- That the Department would proceed immediately with the building of a school to provide for 200 pupils, this school to be in two units: (a) A residential unit, to provide dormitory, dining room and other accommodation for the 200 resident pupils; and (b) a second unit to consist of four class-rooms; together with full basement—basement to be used for manual training, and possibly a gymnasium; and the four class-rooms to provide for the educational needs of the children housed in the dormitory.

2.- The erection of this building is to proceed as soon as possible, but, in the meantime, children will be accommodated at Coqualeetza. The Department officials are to give careful study to the figures presented in the Memorandum, at the earliest possible moment, and are to satisfy the officials of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church that the Department will make adequate provision for the education of our children—

(a) In a new school at Alberni.

(b) In an improved day school at Ahousaht, to provide for fifty children at that point; the appropriation for this new improved day school to be included in the estimates for the fiscal year 1940-41.

(c) In additions to other day schools at Bella Coola, Cape Mudge and other points.

(d) By the erection, also, of an improved day school at Kitamaat.

3.- If, while the erection of the new Alberni School is being proceeded with, it is impossible to make provision for the full number of United Church children as suggested, the Department will transfer as many pupils as may be necessary to Edmonton,—this accommodation at Edmonton to be temporary.

4.- The Department will, on taking over Coqualeetza, operate it as a Sanatorium—that is, free from control or supervision by any of the churches or denominations; but provision will be made for chaplain service or religious services by Roman Catholic and non-Catholic Churches on an equal footing.

5.- That during the time of transition between Coqualeetza and Alberni, the Department will keep closely—
closely in touch with the Secretaries of the Board of Home Missions and will not take any step with regard to the transfer of pupils without consultation with the United Church representatives.

6.- That, if the Department furnishes the delegation with a written statement, agreeing substantially with this statement now submitted, the Committee will ask the Executive of the Board of Home Missions, at its next meeting, and the Woman's Missionary Society, to agree to the proposal.

My dear Mr. Crerar:

A recent letter from Principal Scott, of the Coqualeetza Residential School, gives an example of the kind of think which makes the local United Church people around Coqualeetza very anxious about the influence of the Roman Catholics if the Coqualeetza School becomes a Sanatorium.

Mr. Scott, after talking about the proselytizing tendencies of the Roman Catholic Church in his area and mentioning the case of two or three children who were sent to St. Joseph's Hospital in Victoria for treatment, adds these few sentences, which I want to quote just as they came to me:

"It is interesting to note in this connection that Dr. McQuarrie informed me that this institution was not Catholic, but a Departmental one. He showed me the sheets which are sent to him to be forwarded to the Department for payment of hospitalization service, and they were not headed at all as being connected with St. Joseph's Hospital. I said to him, 'It is in connection with St. Joseph's Hospital' and he replied, 'Oh, the Sisters are running it for the Department'. Now this is a clear indication of what will happen at Coqualeetza."

Now, I am not a bigoted Protestant and I do not sympathize very much with the anti-Roman Catholic feeling which seems to dominate the souls of many of our workers among the Indians. I am, however, sending this personal letter to you to explain what we are up against when we try to quiet the fears of our British Columbia people and get this matter settled in a way which will be helpful to
the Department and to the Indian children concerned. You see Scott fears that McQuarrie's statement to him means that if the Sisters are running the Sanatorium at St. Joseph's Hospital in Victoria "for the Department", it will not be long until they will be running the proposed Coqualeetza Sanatorium for the Department. His fears are doubtless groundless, but the words of Dr. McQuarrie and the situation in connection with the tuberculosis department of St. Joseph's Hospital do not help very much to allay the suspicions of Scott and his United Church friends in British Columbia.

As I told you in my last letter, I am satisfied with your assurance that the proposed Sanatorium although in an area where Roman Catholics are largely in the majority - will be entirely non-sectarian in its management and will give Protestants equal privileges with Roman Catholics. I might as well confess, however, that we are having a great deal of difficulty in convincing our British Columbia friends that this will be so, and if the situation at St. Joseph's Hospital is as Dr. McQuarrie informed Mr. Scott - well, it just makes it hard for us to persuade our friends on the Pacific coast that the Roman Catholic domination will be felt in the proposed new Sanatorium.

I am still hopeful that our Executive, when it meets on the 13th of this month, will give its approval to the negotiations which we have been carrying on, but I want you to know that our task as executive officers has not been an easy one.

With very kind regards,

Believe me,

Sincerely yours,

Memorandum:

Doctor McGill,

My attention has been drawn to a request, addressed by Reverend R. B. Cochrane, D.D., to the Honourable the Minister, for an assurance that the establishment of a sanatorium for Indians at the Coqualeetza School will not seriously embarrass the financial operation of the hospitals operated by the United Church at Hazelton and Bella Bella, and presumably, at Bella Coola and Fort Simpson.

So far as I can judge, such an assurance can be safely given. Of course, if the funds at our disposal for medical work should be drastically reduced again, as they were by 20% to 25% in 1932 and 1933, our tuberculosis work would have to be correspondingly curtailed, and, being more controllable than the treatment of more acute conditions, it would probably suffer more than its share of reduction. This is a possibility that cannot wholly be forgotten, but need not be unduly feared.

Otherwise, it seems probable that the accommodation at Coqualeetza will all be required for the tuberculosis to be found in the southern part of the province, and in any case, I do not think anyone would seriously propose to move tuberculous Indians from northern to southern British Columbia, a distance of five hundred or six hundred miles from their homes. I would not advise it, from a professional point of view.

I would...........
I would like to suggest two reservations in respect to the future of these United Church hospitals, as tuberculosis treatment institutions. The Department has a greater or less capital investment in all, and their revenue is and will continue to be largely from the care of Indians.

First. It might become necessary to request that the rates for the care of tuberculous or any sick Indians be adjusted to provide for operation at about actual, economical cost.

Second. It might become necessary to request that the Church provide medical and nursing staff with thorough training in the diagnosis and treatment of tuberculosis, and otherwise to conduct the hospital on an effective sanatorium basis. That is to say, if the hospitals are to provide care for tuberculous Indians, the Department is entitled to ask that the care shall be of the best kind.

Mr. Jackson spoke on the telephone of a reported impression that Captain Scott had received from Doctor McQuarrie, to the effect that St. Joseph's Hospital at Victoria, B.C., was a Departmental hospital, or at least so regarded. There must be a misunderstanding somewhere. That hospital is a public institution, operated by a religious order. It accommodates Indian patients under exactly the same conditions as very many other hospitals in Canada do. The Department has no investment in it, no control over its management, and no preference for it over any other hospital in Victoria.

E. L. Stone, M.B.,
Superintendent of Medical Services.

Re: The rebuilding of the Alberni School and the utilization of the Cocualeetza School as a T.B. Sanatorium

Dear Dr. Cochrane:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 11, in which you ask from me a more definite and explicit assurance that the Cocualeetza school, if taken over by the Department, would be operated as a T.B. sanatorium on a strictly non-sectarian basis.

In my letter to you of May 8 I stated: "The policy is that this sanatorium (Cocualeetza) should be conducted as a government institution in the sense that the hospital in operation at Cu'Appelle is conducted". The institution at Cu'Appelle was built by the Government and is operated as a government institution. I have not at any time received a complaint with respect to either the sectarian bias or efficiency of the institution. In fact, I find it difficult to understand how sectarian bias could develop in an institution conducted in the sense that the Cu'Appelle hospital is conducted.

The school at Cocualeetza is a government-owned institution, and should it be decided to operate it as a sanatorium, provision would be made for its operation in the regular parliamentary estimates. Under existing legislation -

Reverend R. B. Cochrane, D.D.,
Secretary, Board of Home Missions,
The United Church of Canada,
299 Queen Street West,
Toronto 2, Ontario.
legislation, the position of superintendent would be advertised by the Civil Service Commission and the appointment made by that body. I have no hesitation, however, in assuring you that the institution, if taken over, would be operated by the Government on a basis that would aim at giving equal privileges to all religious bodies, both Catholic and non-Catholic. I have sufficient faith in the judgment of any Minister who may be in charge of the Department to give this assurance.

The ravages of tuberculosis are very much in evidence amongst the Indian population of British Columbia and this applies particularly to Indian children of school age. The leaders of the United Church in British Columbia have on more than one occasion in recent years reminded us that Indian reserves in that province are rapidly becoming a health menace to the white population. When, in response to these representations, a survey was made of the situation, we were advised by the provincial health authorities that no beds were available for Indian patients in the provincial institutions. It is a matter of urgent necessity, therefore, that sanatorium treatment be provided for Indians at the Pacific coast if a serious attempt is to be made to save the Indian children. If the Coculaetza school cannot be taken over, an attempt will have to be made to secure from the Government the funds necessary to build a sanatorium in the Vancouver area. The need for such an institution in this area is undoubtedly one of the most outstanding needs of the Indian service.

It is my intention to secure from the Superintendent of Medical Services his comments on your reference to the three hospitals - Hazelton, Port Simpson and Bella Coola - mentioned in your communication. These comments will reach me in due course. In the meantime I fail to see how the operation of the Coculaetza school as a sanatorium would differ in any sense, so far as the hospitals -
hospitals you have in mind are concerned, from the operation of a sanatorium that might be built by the Government in the Vancouver district.

I have attempted to keep in mind throughout these negotiations the plight of the Indian children afflicted with tuberculosis and the best ways and means of providing them at the earliest possible date with sanatorium treatment. I feel confident that, if this objective is kept in mind, a solution satisfactory to all parties concerned can be worked out with respect to the education of the Indian children of British Columbia on the one hand and the operation of the hospitals in the northern sections of the province on the other.

Yours sincerely,

RESOLUTION ADOPTED BY THE EXECUTIVE OF THE BOARD OF HOME MISSIONS OF THE UNITED CHURCH OF CANADA, AT ITS MEETING, JUNE 12TH, 1939.

"RE PROPOSAL THAT COQUALEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL BE TAKEN OVER BY THE DOMINION GOVERNMENT FOR USE AS A SANATORIUM FOR INDIAN TUBERCULAR PATIENTS."

"After hearing the statement of the Secretary in reference to the negotiations with the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources, and also in regard to the correspondence with the representatives of the British Columbia Conference, the Executive resolves to approve of the handing over of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School to be used as a Government Tuberculosis Sanatorium, when the Secretaries are satisfied that the following essential matters are safeguarded:

"(1) That adequate provision is made for the education of United Church children, now in Coqualeetza, in a new and larger residential school to be erected in the immediate future at Alberni, and in improved day schools, or additions to existing day schools, at such places on the British Columbia coast as the Secretaries may think necessary.

"(2) That, during the transition period, and as long as necessary, some of the United Church pupils from British Columbia are accommodated in the Edmonton Residential School.

"(3) That we have adequate assurance from the Department that the proposed Sanatorium shall be conducted on an entirely non-sectarian basis.

"(4) That the Department consents to name the new school the 'Coqualeetza Residential School at Alberni.'

"(5) That the date at which Coqualeetza shall cease to be used as a residential school shall be a matter of consultation and negotiation between the Board of Home Missions and the Department."
Mr. Charles Gamsell,
Deputy Minister of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I shall be glad to put your letter before the Executive of our Board, which meets on Monday next, when a final answer will probably be given to the Department regarding the proposal to use the Coqualeetza Residential School in the future as a tuberculosis hospital for Indian patients.

June 9th, 1939.

My dear Mr. Camsell:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 6th, in reply to my letter of the 3rd, asking about the effect of the possible establishment of a sanatorium at Coqualeetza upon the United Church hospitals in Northern British Columbia. I have read with interest Dr. Stone's memorandum which you enclosed. I think, as you suggest, it covers the main points I have raised in my letter. I realize, of course, that the amount of work you can do as a Department depends upon the annual amount made available by the Government.

I am glad that Dr. Stone states that it would not be advisable from a professional standpoint to move tuberculosis patients from the North to the South in British Columbia, and that he would not, in any case, advise it. The two reservations which he makes are not at all unreasonable, and I am sure that we as a Board of Home Missions of the United Church will do all we can to provide the best possible care for any tuberculosis patients from amongst the Indian children or adults of Northern British Columbia.

As I have told you in another letter, the whole matter of our attitude in regard to Coqualeetza will probably be decided at our Executive on Monday next.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

HBC.MLT

Re - Coqualeetza Residential School

My dear Mr. Crerar:

The Executive of the Board of Home Missions, at its meeting last week, dealt with the proposal that Coqualeetza Residential School be taken over by the Dominion Government for use as a Sanatorium for Indian tubercular patients. I am enclosing the resolution adopted by the Executive in regard to the matter. I think it requires very little comment.

The Secretaries cannot give a final answer until we get a report from Captain Scott in reference to the matter referred to in Clause (1) - that is, until Captain Scott and Captain Barry have been able to consider together, as they were directed to do, the placing, either at Alberni or Edmonton, or in improved day schools on the coast, of all the children who are now in Coqualeetza. I have a letter from Mr. Scott, saying he has not been able to get in touch with Captain Barry, because the latter has been visiting schools in the North. He thinks, however, that they ought to be able to have the conference the end of this month or early in July.

As far as Nos. (2) and (3) are concerned, you have already given us adequate assurance that you will meet our wishes in regard to these two matters.

We shall be glad to have your consent to the requests contained in Clauses (4) and (5).

We are just as anxious as the Department is to get this matter finally settled. I believe this is in the best interests of both the Government and the Church. You will see from what I have written that the final decision, as far as we are concerned, rests now with the Secretaries of our Board, and that we are waiting to be satisfied about Clauses (1), (4) and (5) before agreeing to the proposal in the name of The United Church of Canada.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

(sgd.) R. B. Cochrane

Re: Coculaletza Residential School

Dear Dr. Cochrane:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of June 23 and also copy of a resolution adopted by the Executive Committee of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, attached thereto.

I can see no objection whatever to the suggestion that the new school to be established at Alberni be known as the Coculaletza Residential School. I can readily appreciate the desire of the United Church missionaries in British Columbia to retain the name, and it is just possible that they have in mind certain advantages that may result from attaching the name "Coculaletza" to the new building.

It seems to me quite reasonable that the date at which Coculaletza shall cease to be used as a residential school should be decided between the Board of Home Missions and the officials of the Department. It is my hope that Captain Scott and Inspector Barry will find it convenient to meet at an early date and make a careful survey of the needs of the -

Dear Major MacKay:

I have to refer to a Departmental letter from the Superintendent of Welfare and Training dated May 4th 1939 with reference to the future distribution of the pupils now attending Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, and in particular to the two final paragraphs of that letter.

The wishes of the Department were adhered to and conferences arranged with the Rev. R.C. Scott in my office on July 3rd and 6th, when the particulars surrounding the life of each child, home conditions, health etc., were discussed in detail.

It is with considerable pleasure that I am able to report that the Rev. R.C. Scott and I found little difficulty in reaching agreement on the suggested distribution of these Indian children. Our actual working papers are not being forwarded to the Department but placed on file in Vancouver should there be any need to consult these records in the future.

I am forwarding herewith the Statement of Proposed Distribution of the children. Every child now at Coqualeetza has been dealt with and the disposal suggested in each case is the very best possible for the child. The statement is signed by the Reverend Principal, but I am of course in agreement with its contents, and suggest that such statement be considered the joint work of the Principal of Coqualeetza and myself.

I would ask that the suggestions placed on Page 12 be considered in their relation to the below mentioned recommendations which include the needs of the various Agencies in British Columbia for the next four years, as such needs can be met by the erection of Indian day schools, or additions to existing day schools, or replacements.

While I am well aware that it may not be found possible to carry out in its entirety the whole of the yearly building programme suggested here, my recommendations are made as a result of a fairly thorough knowledge of the conditions in the various villages and in direct response to Mr. Hey's own suggestion, so that the Honorable the Minister will be able to see at a glance the locations where new schools or additions to schools are considered necessary from a professional point of view.
Recommended Building Programme

The educational needs of the Indians in B.C. would be met by the following Building Programme which has been spread over the present and three succeeding Fiscal Years.

The various projects have been arranged in their relative order of importance, as far as this may be determined at the moment, and such a relative order may be applied to the projects suggested for each Fiscal Year as well as the more general order suggested by the year itself.

Fiscal Year 1939-40 (Present Year)

Project 1. The erection of a two room Indian Day School with teachers' residence at GILLIKANAX in the Skeena River Agency. This school would be administered under the Anglican Church.

Project 2. The erection of a four room consolidated Indian Day School without teachers' residence near DUNCAN in the Cowichan Agency. This school would be administered under the auspices of the Catholic Church. Cowichan Indian Day School would be absorbed.

Project 3. The erection of a one room Indian Day School, with teacher's residence at BOOTHROYD in the Lytton Agency. This school would replace the old Boothroyd Indian Day School, and be Anglican.

Project 4. The addition of a second classroom to the present ALERT BAY Indian Day School to provide for the expected increased attendance to a total of about 80 in September-October 1939. This is an Anglican school. The second Division might be accommodated in a rented hall for the first year, Kwawkewlth Agency.

Project 5. The authorization of the employment of a third teacher at the present MASSETT Indian Day School, where a room is available in the school building and could be fitted up at little cost. The school here operates on an eight months basis and is administered under Anglican auspices, Queen Charlotte Agency.

Fiscal Year 1940-41

Project 6. The erection of a one room Indian Day School, without teacher's residence probably, at ALQUAHAH, in the West Coast Agency. This school would be administered under the auspices of the United Church of Canada.

Project 7. The addition of a second classroom to the present Indian Day School at KINCOLITH where there will be about sixty pupils in the winter of 1939 and eighty or more the following year. This is an Anglican school in the Skeena River Agency. A temporary hall might be used at first.

Project 8. The erection of a new Indian Day School with a teacher's residence at KITAMATA in the Bella Coola Agency. The present Indian Day School there is the property of the United Church of Canada and is crowded with the children from the Kitamaat Indian Residential School so that the village children do not get the attention they certainly deserve. The present school should be used exclusively for the children from the Kitamaat Indian Residential School of which it forms almost part by being located on the same property. The children suggested to be returned to Kitamaat from Coqualeetza make the provision of a village school at Kitamaat very necessary.
Project 9. The erection of a one room Indian Day School with teacher's residence at CLO-OOSE in the West Coast Agency. There are between thirty and forty children of school age at this point for whom it will be difficult if not impossible to find accommodation in the proposed new Indian Residential School at or near Alberni. This school would be administered under United Church auspices.

Project 10. The addition of a second classroom to the present Indian Day School at KISPIOK in the Babine Agency. This school is administered under the United Church of Canada. There are now far more children in attendance than can be taught at one time by the Missionary.

Project 11. The erection of a new Indian Day School at HARTLEY BAY to provide increased accommodation and replace the very old school at that point. The present school is administered under the auspices of the United Church of Canada and the school is located in the Skeena River Agency. No residence would be required.

Project 12. The erection of a new two room Indian Day School without teachers' residence at HAZELTON to replace the present overcrowded school conducted in an Anglican hall. This school should not be under the auspices of any one Church as Anglicans, Roman Catholics and Salvation Army children attend. The school is in the Babine Agency.

Fiscal Year 1941-42

Project 13. The erection of a one room Indian Day School on one of the Ohlat Reserves on BARKLEY SOUND in the West Coast Agency. There would be some thirty to forty pupils if a suitable site was chosen for an eight month a year school. The people move mainly between two villages. Though most are members of the United Church of Canada there are some Roman Catholics and it is uncertain just which Church should suggest a teacher or administer the school. This could be decided later. There would not be sufficient room at the proposed Indian Residential School at Alberni for these people and they might not wish to attend such a school. They were much opposed to a school at Alberni when I made my survey of the Barkley Sound area. A teacher's residence would be required at this school.

Project 14. The erection of a new Indian Day School at KITKATLA in the Skeena River Agency to replace a very old day school. No teacher's residence would be required. The teacher is the Anglican Missionary.

Project 15. The erection on Indian Reserve of a new Indian Day School at Shalalth in the Lytton Agency to replace the very old log school, Seton Lake Indian Day School, at that point. This school would be under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. No teacher's residence would be needed.

Project 16. The erection of a new Indian Day School, without teacher's residence at ENDEBEE to accommodate the twenty to twenty five children without education at that point. This school would be under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church and would be in the Okanagan agency.

Project 17. The addition of a second classroom to the present Indian Day School at CAPE MUDGE in the Kwakwewlth Agency. The school is under the auspices of the United Church of Canada. There is a teacher's residence there now.

Dear Parents and Friends:

Again it is my pleasant duty to give an account of life at Coqualeetza during the first two months of the new term. By the end of the third week in September the school was filled so that class rooms and departments have gone on happily and satisfactorily in good time.

Thanksgiving was observed in due form. There were special delicacies in the dining room topped off with Pumpkin pie. On the Monday afternoon a picture show was given in the Assembly Hall and this was repeated in the evening for the girls and boys in the Preventorium. On Sunday we had as our special speaker, the Rev.J.H. White,D.D., who gave a fine message which was listened to with interest by each boy and girl.

On Saturday, October 21st, Founder's Day was observed with fitting ceremony. In the dining room the school Birthday Cake adorned with its fifty-one candles, was the centre of attraction. Little Doris and Betty Sepass, the youngest children in the school were too bashful to attempt to blow out the candles so Muriel Collinson and Myra Kelly were given the honor. After the Principal had set the knife into the cake, members of staff cut it up and served the boys and girls with generous pieces. Staff members too, received their piece, and staff and pupils alike voted it just right.

On Sunday evening, a unique service was held. Mrs.E.A.Wells, who was teacher and later Matron in the school, forty-six years ago, spoke to the boys and girls. With her on the platform were Mr.Wm.Newby, who fifty-one years ago remodelled the home of Rev. and Mrs.C.M. Tate to make room for a dozen Indian girls and boys who formed the first class in Coqualeetza, and Mrs.Harry Uslick and Dan Milo, who as children, were members of it. Other honored staff members and pupils of the school were Mr.C.M. Pearson, Farm Instructor forty-six years ago; Chief Albert and Mrs.Cooper and Mr.A. Lewis. It is doubtful if any other community in British Columbia can produce a like number of pupils and staff members who live within its boundaries after more than half a century. Mrs.Wells was very happy in her reminiscences. Just to show that boys were boys in those days, she told of a little chap coming to her one day crying and saying that the boys were teasing him. After a pause he said they had been calling him names. Well, surely that had not hurt him, but it evidently had, for he blurted out between sobs, "they called me a Scotchman" as we have several Scotch members of staff, the joke was enjoyed immensely. Mrs.Wells held the interest of young and old, and the service was clearly one which had definite influence for good upon all. The congregation of Carman United Church united with us for the occasion and the Rev.H.T. Allen, their pastor, and the Rev.J.H. White,D.D., took part in the service. Our fifty-first birthday will long remain a pleasant and helpful memory. None of those present will soon forget the impression which Mrs.Wells made as to the consecration of those pioneer workers, and their deep interest in the Indian people.

Once again we are indebted to the Department for an X-Ray Clinic. Dr.G.S. Kincaide, of the Provincial Chest Clinic, spent two days with us and all doubtful cases were either fluoroscoped or X-rayed. A splendid record of good health was shown in that out of 123 pupils examined, only one was found to have any active disease; one other had a touch of pleurisy and a third was simply in need of special care, but had no actual trouble of any kind. The fact that the Clinic was held so early in the term was much appreciated, and most fortunate in making possible proper treatment for the one case before any actual breakdown had taken place.
have discharged eight patients from the Preventorium this Fall. Two girls who had reached the age for discharge, went home and two girls and four boys came back again to school. These pupils are fit for normal life again, but will still receive extra care until they are back to vigorous health. In the "Pre" we have had for the past eight months, a teacher-nurse who lives each pupil instruction in classroom work so that they come back to school well up in their classes. She also teaches handicrafts and many interesting and useful articles are turned out, - caps, socks, sweaters, dresses, rugs and fancy work are made by the girls and the boys are becoming expert Totem Pole carvers. We greatly appreciate the honor which Coqualeetza has had in pioneering the work of healing boys and girls who had the beginnings of chest trouble, and feel that the money expended by the department has been a fine investment. Too much praise can not be given to the doctors who have advised this treatment and for the generous way the Indian Affairs Branch has co-operated with them. Miss Mackay who has been in charge of the "Pre" from the beginning, has made herself much beloved by the boys and girls who have been her patients. Not one of them but will be able to live in better health because of the training they have received. Mrs. Vance, who gives sewing instructions, has worked wonders with the children as a fitter helper with Miss Mackay in this very important work. A Graduate of the School is employed as assistant housekeeper and twenty girls each year receive practical training in the care of the sick. Thus in time, a force of intelligent trained young people will bring the good news of how to control and heal Tuberculosis to their home villages and show how it can be done.

And now a word about Halloween. Who can think of Halloween without visions of black cats, witches, pumpkins with funny faces, yes and of pumpkins made into delicious pie? We had them all at Coqualeetza this year. In the assembly hall long ribbons of black and orange trailed from corner to corner and from light to light, and around the walls witches with peaked bonnets riding astride their broom sticks and black cats, looked down on happy boys and girls who filled the Hall with merry laughter for two days, afternoon and evening, as they carried through a programme of games and folk dances. The "living alphabet" was one of the best of the former. Girl and boy captains called out the "letters" to spell the words which were announced and the first side lined up to spell the word, correctly won.

Soon it will be Remembrance Day when all the School will gather to pay tribute to the memory of those who laid down their lives in the Great War, and together we shall bow in silent prayer that God will help us to be worthy of their sacrifice, and He will overrule the present conflict to bring ever nearer His Kingdom, which is "righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit". Meantime, every one has settled down to work in earnest in Class Room and Departments, in Manual Training and Boat Building and in Navigation Classes, which begin this week in Junior and Senior divisions.

We often think of parents and friends, and do not forget to ask God's blessing upon them from day to day, as we gather for morning and evening prayers. As Staff and pupils, we shall do our best to work for all that is good and worthwhile in the opportunity which is ours in Coqualeetza.

Yours sincerely,

R.C. Scott
PRINCIPAL

My dear Dr. McGill:

Re - Coqualeetza and Alberni

The Executive of the Board of Home Missions, at its meeting on Friday, November 24th, had before it once more the matter of the use of the buildings of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School for a tuberculosis sanatorium, together with the arrangements for rebuilding the school at Alberni and taking care of the children now in Coqualeetza at Alberni and in day schools up the British Columbia coast. After considerable discussion, the following resolution was unanimously adopted:

"Whereas The Indian Affairs Branch of The Department of Mines and Resources, in a letter from the Minister, Honorable T. A. Crear, dated February 21st, 1939, expressed a desire to take over the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, to be used as a tuberculosis sanatorium; and

"Whereas the Secretaries have reported that, as a result of interviews and correspondence with the officials of the Department, all the matters under discussion have been settled and the interests of the United Church safeguarded; and

"Whereas the Department is now erecting a new residential school at Alberni, which on completion is to be administered by the Board of Home Missions;

"The Executive resolves:

(1) To give formal approval to the proposal of the Government;

(2) To give the Secretaries power to carry on any further negotiations necessary with the Government in regard to the date of the closing of the Coqualeetza Residential School and the opening of the new school at Alberni, and any other questions in connection with the whole matter.

(3) To nominate for the principalship of the Alberni Residential School the Rev. R. C. Scott, B.A., now Principal of Coqualeetza."

My colleagues and I are still of the opinion that it would be in the interests of all parties concerned that the first publicity given to these changes should be through a joint
statement from the Indian Affairs Branch of The Department of Mines and Resources and the Board of Home Missions of the United Church. We should be glad to have you consult with the Minister in regard to this as soon as he returns from Great Britain. If he should think that a joint statement is not wise, we would suggest as second best that a statement from both offices should be issued simultaneously - on the same date, if possible.

While there is no immediate need of a statement such as I have suggested, we do not think it should be delayed too long. It would be fairer to Mr. Scott, and everyone else, if in the not too distant future we could inform him that the Government has accepted his nomination as Principal of the Alberni School. It would give him a chance to make plans, to consult with the Government officials and to visit Alberni in connection with the farm lands, the administration of which we are taking over from The Woman's Missionary Society.

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

REG.MLT

Project 9. The erection of a one room Indian Day School with teacher's residence at CLO-005E in the West Coast Agency. There are between thirty and forty children of school age at this point for whom it will be difficult if not impossible to find accommodation in the proposed new Indian Residential School at or near Alberni. This school would be administered under United Church auspices.

Project 10. The addition of a second classroom to the present Indian Day School at KISPIOX in the Babine Agency. This school is administered under the United Church of Canada. There are now far more children in attendance than can be taught at one time by the Missionary.

Project 11. The erection of a new Indian Day School at HARTLEY BAY to provide increased accommodation and replace the very old school at that point. The present school is administered under the auspices of the United Church of Canada and the school is located in the Skeena River Agency. No residence would be required.

Project 12. The erection of a new two room Indian Day School without teachers' residence at HAZELTON to replace the present overcrowded school conducted in an Anglican hall. This school should not be under the auspices of any one Church as Anglicans, Roman Catholics and Salvation Army children attend. The school is in the Babine Agency.

Fiscal Year 1941-42

Project 13. The erection of a one room Indian Day School on one of the Ohist Reserves on BARKLEY SOUND in the West Coast Agency. There would be some thirty to forty pupils if a suitable site was chosen for an eight month a year school. The people move mainly between two villages. I would ask that the suggestions placed on Page 12 be considered in their relation to the below mentioned recommendations which include the needs of the various Agencies in British Columbia for the next four years, as such needs can be met by the erection of Indian day schools, or additions to existing day schools, or replacements.

Dear Parents and Friends:

Once again it is time for our Mid-Winter letter telling of the school and its life since we last wrote. We began our Christmas activities early this year - December 13th - when 187 children were taken to Chilliwack in school buses and private cars to a special matinee showing "The Wizard of Oz", that great children's story. It was a wonderful experience for most of the girls and boys, and helped to create the spirit of Christmas. Just how well they remember what they saw was apparent to staff members for many a day afterwards, and came out at the time of our senior party later on.

Term examinations this year were pleasing to both teachers and pupils, and showed that the boys and girls were doing real work in their class rooms.

Christmas decorations were, if anything, the best yet. Wall plaques made by the Manual Training class, gave interest and tone amid the long festoons of greenery which adorned the walls. At the front of the Assembly Hall stood a large Christmas tree resplendent in lights and ornaments. Over at the Preventorium, a smaller, but equally lovely tree awaited the coming of Santa Claus.

In the midst of such stimulating and cheery environment, the School Christmas Concert was given on December 19th. A cantata entitled "When Santa forgot the South" was presented, and the way in which the boys and girls took their respective parts gave great credit to the staff members who had spent time and energy in training them. In fact, the concert this year was declared by common consent to be the "best yet" and that is saying something, for Coquitlam concerts have always been good. The theme of the play made clear what fun and happiness there is in forgetting self and helping others less fortunate.

During all the time, from Monday the 16th until Saturday the 23rd groups of pupils were taken by car into Chilliwack to see the Christmas windows, and to do a bit of shopping - a privilege long awaited. It was very gratifying to see how so many of the girls and boys thought of others in spending their money.

And so the days passed until Christmas Eve, when long rows of stockings were hung on each side of the corridors outside the dormitories of the younger pupils. And strangely enough, some rather large and equally long stockings appeared, which rumour had it, were for staff members who still found delight in that fondly remembered act of Christmas Eve. Or was it the boys and girls who played tricks on them. Anyway, these stockings were there, let the truth be told, and it was a happy lot of boys and girls and their overlords who emptied their stockings with delight on Christmas morning, along with many an expression of happiness - and of course much that was just plain noise, but the sort that goes at Christmas and helps to make it what it is. This done presents were for the time being laid aside, or carried along secretly and the entire School gathered in the Assembly Hall at 7.30 for a short Christmas Service. The old Christmas hymns were sung with heartiness and the story of the first Christmas was read. A very brief address on the meaning of Christmas, especially in view of the war, laid emphasis on the Angel Song which has kept ringing on in spite of war and trouble and its music would still be gladdening the hearts of men when the guns had ceased their thunder and the nations would accept the Prince of Peace and lay the Government upon His shoulder" who had redeemed them all. Prayer for our own King and Queen, our people and for all peoples, and especially for boys and girls away from home or who had lost their parents and homes owing to war, led all hearts in joint supplication for God's blessing and made a bit more real the meaning of Christmas.

Christmas dinner was served at noon on Christmas Day. Every boy and girl sat down to the tables, and staff members waited upon them. Through a very well organized effort, heaping plates of turkey, vegetables and later of plum pudding were served, hot and lots of it. This is the first time I ever knew an Indian lad to say, with a rather sleepy sort of smile, "No thanks, I've had enough" when asked if he would have more turkey. After the children were finished, the staff sat down to their own dinner, and here again there was an abundance of good things for Christmas, and again more smiles and "No thank you's".
At 4 P.M., Santa Claus arrived, and this year was in a particularly happy mood. He walked up and down the laundry roof, just outside the Assembly Hall, so that every boy and girl could see that he had just "arrived." After coming in, he gave a very nice little talk and distributed with the help of staff members, the many presents sent in by parents and friends, or given by the school, so that each boy and girl had something with which to remember his visit. Before he left he had the smaller boys and girls sing "Away in a Manger" for him, and now they did sing! I did wish that the parents could have heard them.

As New Years Day this year came on Monday, and the week previous had been a rather strenuous one, it was decided to hold the New Years parties on the 26th and 29th of December, leaving the week following New Years free for the resumption of classes.

On Thursday afternoon the Primaries had their party followed by the Intermediates the same evening. Next day, in the afternoon the Juniors had a good time together and then in the evening the Senior Party, always a masquerade at New Years, was held. The winners this year were voted to be better than those of the last, and the judges had a hard time deciding as to who were the winners in each class.

After parading before the judges in the Assembly Hall, the entire party led by Principal and Mrs. Scott wound its way through corridors and up the stairs to the first floor. Here through delighted lines of children row upon row in nighties and pyjamas, the procession passed, first through the Girls' Side and then through the Boys' and down stairs again to the Assembly Hall. The judges, after further watching of the characters and their costumes, finally decided as follows.

Job Paul as Stanley Livingstone, won first prize for the best dressed boy. Job had seen the picture, "Stanley and Livingstone" a few days before and he turned out in cap with gold braid, frock coat gray trousers, wing collar and bow tie, moustache and side burns, heavy eyebrows and with face wrinkles like Mr. Livingstone had, and in his hand a Bible held in the exact way the picture showed Livingstone to have held it when reading. From the picture Job had gleamed such sentences as "I shall remain until my work is done; I shall remain if necessary until I die." Velma Pearson as the "Outdoor Girl" won first prize for the best dressed girl. Attired in skiing costume, she was easily a leader among the girls. To Chester Benson went first prize for the best comic costume. He reproduced the "Scarecrow" from the "Wizard of Oz" to perfection, even to the wobbly legs which refused to carry him at times; with straw sticking through his cap and from here and there in his clothing he well deserved the prize. Myrtle Gray, after a close race, was awarded the prize for the best comic costume among the girls. She appeared as a "Chimney Sweep" and particularly, as a girl from a place where they have no really big chimneys, she deserved credit for the correctness of her attire, even to the soot. In the most original class, Henry Paul as "Carpenter" drew first prize among the boys. Doubtless the greatest number of tools and the complete facial disguise helped a lot. Pauline Jones' attire, in a costume made from advertising, skirt, blouse, top hat and all, won general approval as first among the girls.

The remainder of the evening was spent in games and folk dances, and ended up with the usual fine supper at 10.30 P.M., after which "Many thanks and good night" was wished their host and hostess by each girl and boy before retiring.

Sunday evening, fitting New Years services were held, and the choir rendered appropriate selections. On Monday a grand New Years dinner was served at noon, and basket ball games enjoyed in the afternoon. A good picture show in the Assembly Hall brought the happy day to a close, and now for nearly two weeks, classes and departments have been under way. The health of the school is excellent, and the entire school is organized into four teams, the Ramblers, Royals, Rovers and Rangers, each one under captain and vice-captain intent on winning highest place.

Staff and pupils join in wishing you each one, a very Happy New Year, and may much blessing attend you through all the days.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

So many letters are coming to hand, and there is so much uncertainty in the minds of many people about the change which will take place for Coqualeetza next September, that I feel a statement should be made about it.

In March, a year ago, the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources at Ottawa, which is responsible in all matters affecting the welfare of the Indian people, wrote to our Board of Home Missions, through its General Secretary, the Rev.R.B. Cochrane, D.D., asking that the School be given over to the Department for use as a Sanatorium for the care of Tuberculous Indians. This request was placed before the Home Missions Committee of the British Columbia Conference, of the United Church of Canada, by Dr.Cochrane that same month. A Committee was appointed, representing the Conference, the Presbytery, the Board of Home Missions, and the School through the Principal. A statement was prepared which was placed before the Board of Home Missions at its next meeting. The Home Missions Board appointed a Committee consisting of the Rev.Dr.Cochrane, the Rev.Dr.Dorey and Mrs.Loveys who represented the Woman's Missionary Society, and the Principal of the School. This Committee went to Ottawa and interviewed the Officials of the Department with regard to the proposal. During a very frank and earnest conversation between this Committee and the Departmental officers, answers were given to four leading questions which were proposed by our Committee, namely:

1. Who was behind the request for the School for use as a Sanatorium?
   To this the direct answer was made, that Dr.Stone, Director of Medical Services for the Department, was the one who was planning the change. Now everyone who knows anything at all about Dr.Stone, knows that he is heart and soul given up to planning and working for the betterment of the health of the Indian people, and that he is competent in every way to do this. Consequently our Committee felt that the proposal was genuinely directed to accomplish that much to be desired end and deserved serious consideration.

2. Was it to be a bona fide Sanatorium, giving up to date scientific treatment, surgical and otherwise?
   Here again the answer was a decided "yes".

3. Who was to control the Institution?
   The answer was that the Department would control it. This point has been further discussed in greater detail and the answer of the officials at Ottawa has been
very satisfactory. In other words, Coqualeetza will become a Government Sanitorium. Patients of every denomination will be admitted and will be given the best possible scientific medical care.

4. What was to be done with the pupils now at Coqualeetza? As a result of the discussion of this point, the Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, Captain G.H. Barry, and the Principal of the School, were asked to go over the School Roll and make suggestions as to the disposal of the pupils now in school. A statement was prepared and submitted to the Board of Home Missions, the British Columbia Committee and to the Department at Ottawa. This report it was understood, was suggestive and would likely have to be gone over again by the time any change in the School might take place, as the pupilage was always changing from year to year. On the whole, the basis suggested was satisfactory both to the Church and to the Department. Further, the Department agreed that if our Church would give them Coqualeetza for use as a Sanitorium, a school for 200 pupils would be built at Alberni. This School is now in process of erection.

Who would be allowed to go to the new school? The main features of the proposed settlement of pupils now in Coqualeetza were as follows.

1. Pupils having good homes and who have a Day School in their home village, should go home and attend Day School.

2. Pupils now at Coqualeetza who have no Day School in their home village should be allowed to go to the new school at Alberni.

3. Pupils now in Coqualeetza who had lost one or both parents or who had not good homes to go to, would, on the recommendation of their Indian Agent, be allowed to attend the new school, or some such residential school as might be agreed upon.

Will all parents and guardians of pupils now in Coqualeetza, or who have children whom they think should be allowed to go to the new school at Alberni, please see their Indian Agent AT ONCE. Give him all the facts about your children and why you think they should be allowed to attend this school. This is the only way to get them in.

Dear Major MacKay:

Thank you for your kind enquiry as to my health in the last paragraph of your letter of April 29th last. In reply I am pleased to say that I got a good report from Dr. New the specialist at Mayo Clinic who has been in charge of my case. I told him that folks in our part of the country thought that when a man had to go Mayos, it meant he was about done for, just as folk generally thought of having to go to a Hospital in the early days. I explained that it was not fair either to the church or to the Department to allow some statement on my prospects of health, to be delayed too long.

Dr. New then said in answer to three definite questions which I put before him in writing:

1. There was nothing malignant about the throat condition which has been troubling me, and never had been.
2. That my voice would, in the end be as good as before, "if not better."
3. That the condition was a most persistent one, comparable to some extent to "twitch grass" in a field. He said that there was "not half, no not one quarter the trouble there this time that there was the last time" but added immediately after saying that he thought "this time was going to fix me up", that he wanted to see it again in a month's time.

That is disappointing, but I see nothing else but go through with it especially after getting such an encouraging report, and after having gone to expense of time and means thus far. I do hope that this will be the finish of indicated treatment, and that I shall, by the end of the school term or before, be able to talk again somewhat normally.

I shall ....
I shall lay plans from now on, to go down about May 24th, and shall be back before Sports Day, the main event before School Closing. Last time I was eight days in Hospital and 5 days in the hotel before he would allow me to come back. This time I was only 5 days in Hospital, and only one day in the hotel after discharge. Thus, I hope to be down and back with a minimum of time this next time. Conditions at the school are very good, and I trust that it will be alright for me to go down once more in accordance with the wishes of my Physician.

Regretting very much the loss of time, and thanking you again for your interest and assistance, I am,

Yours sincerely,
"R. C. Scott"

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I returned from Rochester Minn. yesterday morning and have been hard at work trying to get correspondence caught up.

I am glad to say that I was only 5 days in Hospital this time and 1 day in the Hotel, as compared with 8 days in Hospital and five days in Hotel last time.

I also brought away a good report. I told Dr. New that when a man had to go to Mayo's, up in our country he was thought to be done for; very much the same as folk used to think of the reason one went to Hospital, when Hospitals were first opened.

I told him it was unfair both to the church and to the Department of Indian Affairs to go much longer without a definite decision on the condition of my throat.

He said, in answer to three definite questions which I wrote down for him:

1. There definitely was no malignancy, and never was, but a very stubborn sort of inflammation of the chords.

He also said that there was not "one half, no not one quarter of the trouble there this time as compared with the first time" I went down.

2. He said that my voice "would be as good as ever, if not better", and that I would be able to talk again.

3. He also said that he wanted to see me the middle of this month again, or in one month after this last time.

This latter was a disappointment, but since they have no equipment for handling such cases in Vancouver, what else can I do?

Consequently, I shall prepare from now on for another trip, which I trust will be the last one, and try to be back in good time before our annual Sports Day, which will be toward the end of the first week in June.

I make all arrangements ahead for financial and other oversight, and things have gone very well. I am deeply indebted to members of Staff who have stepped into the breach nobly. Mr. Peake has been a member of staff for over 13 years, and knows the work and is thoroughly reliable. He takes over for me.

I trust this will be agreeable to you. I have already written
Commissioner MacKay, and am writing Mr Daunt today also.

Dr New told me the morning after the second operation that he thought "this time" was going to fix me up. He added immediately "but I want to see you in a month's time".

It was the difficulty, being a mere layman, in reconciling these two statements, along with the number of cancer of the Larynx cases, which made me feel I simply must get a decision on my case. I had three such cancer cases in the same room with me in the five days I was in Hospital, and it rather got on my nerves.

Dr New said that the condition might be likened to "twitch grass" in a field, stubborn but definitely not malignant. He had said the very first time, that there was "nothing bad" found when they operated, but the presence of these cases in such apparent numbers made me wish for a plain statement.

I appreciate greatly the willingness of the Department and the Board of Home Missions to allow me these unavoidable leaves of absence. My general health has improved vastly since the first operation, and I am feeling fit apart from my voice. This however, I shall not use until I am given permission by Dr New. I explained the need for being able to talk if I am to assume the duties of the new school, and carry this one to a successful conclusion, and he gave me to understand that I would be well able to do so. Consequently I shall hope to make a final trip, leaving here about the 24th of the month, and getting back just as fast as physically possible.

The diagnosis this time was "Contact ulcer" instead of "Laryngeal Tumor" as it was the last time. This in itself showed an improvement.

Thanking you in anticipation, I am,

Yours sincerely,

So many letters are coming to hand, and there is so much uncertainty in the minds of many people about the change which will take place for Coqualeetza next September, that I feel a statement should be made about it.

In March, a year ago, the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources at Ottawa, which is responsible in all matters affecting the welfare of the Indian people, wrote to our Board of Home Missions, through its General Secretary, the Rev.R.B. Cochrane, D.D., asking that the School be given over to the Department for use as a Sanitorium for the care of Tuberculous Indians. This request was placed before the Home Missions Committee of the British Columbia Conference, of the United Church of Canada, by Dr.Cochrane that same month. A Committee was appointed, representing the Conference, the Presbytery, the Board of Home Missions, and the School through the Principal. A statement was prepared which was placed before the Board of Home Missions at its next meeting. The Home Missions Board appointed a Committee consisting of the Rev.Dr.Cochrane, the Rev.Dr.Dorey and Mrs.Loveys who represented the Woman's Missionary Society, and the Principal of the School. This Committee went to Ottawa and interviewed the officials of the Department with regard to the proposal. During a very frank and earnest conversation between this Committee and the Departmental officers, answers were given to four leading questions which were proposed by our Committee, namely:

1. Who was behind the request for the School for use as a Sanitorium?
   To this the direct answer was made, that Dr.Stone, Director of Medical Services for the Department, was the one who was planning the change. Now everyone who knows anything at all about Dr.Stone, knows that he is heart and soul given up to planning and working for the betterment of the health of the Indian people, and that he is competent in every way to do this. Consequently our Committee felt that the proposal was genuinely directed to accomplish that much to be desired end and deserved serious consideration.

2. Was it to be a bona fide Sanitorium, giving up to date scientific treatment, surgical and otherwise?
   Here again the answer was a decided "yes".

3. Who was to control the Institution?
   The answer was that the Department would control it. This point has been further discussed in greater detail and the answer of the officials at Ottawa has been
very satisfactory. In other words, Coqualeetza will become a Government Sanatorium. Patients of every denomination will be admitted and will be given the best possible scientific medical care.

4. What was to be done with the pupils now at Coqualeetza? As a result of the discussion of this point, the Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia, Captain G.H. Barry, and the Principal of the School, were asked to go over the School Roll and make suggestions as to the disposal of the pupils now in school. A statement was prepared and submitted to the Board of Home Missions, the British Columbia Committee and to the Department at Ottawa. This report it was understood, was suggestive and would likely have to be gone over again by the time any change in the School might take place, as the pupilage was always changing from year to year. On the whole, the basis suggested was satisfactory both to the Church and to the Department. Further, the Department agreed that if our Church would give them Coqualeetza for use as a Sanatorium, a school for 200 pupils would be built at Alberni. This School is now in process of erection.

Who would be allowed to go to the new school? The main features of the proposed settlement of pupils now in Coqualeetza were as follows.

1. Pupils having good homes and who have a Day School in their home village, should go home and attend Day School.

2. Pupils now at Coqualeetza who have no Day School in their home village should be allowed to go to the new school at Alberni.

3. Pupils now in Coqualeetza who had lost one or both parents or who had not good homes to go to, would, on the recommendation of their Indian Agent, be allowed to attend the new school, or some such residential school as might be agreed upon.

Will all parents and guardians of pupils now in Coqualeetza, or who have children whom they think should be allowed to go to the new school at Alberni, please see their Indian Agent AT ONCE. Give him all the facts about your children and why you think they should be allowed to attend this school. This is the only way to get them in.

From the foregoing I am sure it will be plain that our Church could not rightfully hinder the Department's desire to do something badly needed for the health of the Native people. Good health is the foundation of all that is worthwhile, and without it, education and natural ability are badly handicapped. Authorities state that the death rate from Tuberculosis among the Native people can be cut in half within a very few years by proper methods and cure. The committee felt, as did many
Individuals, the writer among them, that while it was a great sacrifice to give up a school with such a glorious history, and about which tender memories cling in hundreds of hearts, still progress could only be made through sacrifice. Consequently, our Church is glad to co-operate with the Department so that a larger benefit may come to the Native people. This move means too, that the Native people must do their share. There can be no more sending of children to residential schools just to be rid of the responsibility of caring for them at home. All parents who can do so, must see that their children attend the Day School regularly. Far too much indifference and easy going habits are to be found among our Native people in this respect. When the matter of attending school is concerned, many parents say, "Oh, it is just whatever they want to do." That is utterly wrong, and very harmful to the children. It is the parent's duty to guide children and to enforce what is best for them. The Committee of the Church took great pains to tell the Department that Day Schools were not yet one hundred per cent effective, but it realized that further progress could only come where the Native people really got behind their Day School, and saw that the children got to school. Laziness and failure to get up in the morning in time to get the children off to school on the part of the parents is a rotten foundation on which to try to build a better village life.

In all cases where parents really cannot take care of their children, and where a child really needs the care of a residential school, it is felt the Department will make such care possible. The same is true where certain pupils show signs of being able to use higher education or where such pupils ought to have a chance at practical training which can best be given at a residential school. The writer has never been refused permission by the Department for such advanced training when he could set forth good reasons for its being provided. It should be said too, that the Department is planning more and better Day Schools as a part of this entire programme.

In the transfer from Coqualeetza to Alberni, the Principal and most of the staff will be included. Pupils will, in the new school, be under the care of the officials and teachers whom they have come to know and trust at Coqualeetza. The same care for them and the same interest in their welfare will continue at Alberni.

Let each of us go forward in prayer and in loyalty to duty wherever the pathway may lead, knowing that any sacrifice made by the Church or by any person for another's good, will be used of God for much blessing. Coqualeetza has already shown what can be done to prevent and to cure Tuberculosis. Will you, as parents and friends, follow her now in this bigger attack upon this terrible foe of both Native and White peoples.

Yours sincerely,
