Dear Mr. Hoey:

I regret to say that Dr. Large of Vancouver, when I saw him a couple of days ago asked me to go back to Mayos for a final check up.
Dr. Large says the chord shows no sign of further ulceration, and that the inflammation is practically gone, but that there is a small "tag" of membrane which may be in need of removal. He assures me that if they decide to take it off, it will be a simple operation compared with the first one, and that they may decide that nothing further is required, but he wishes me to go in order to be sure.
Dr. New, the Throat Specialist at Mayos told me before I left that it was possible a "knob" might be left which would have to come off and that he would like to see me about the 15th of April.
In looking over the letter from Dr. Cochrane in this connection I note that he said I was to go back again if it proved necessary. I presume that you will be agreeable to this. I shall make the same arrangements for the conduct of the school as before, and am sure everything will go along alright.
I am hoping to get clear of this trouble so as to be ready for the extra work which always begins to come in connection with the school as 24th of May and final closing time draws near. Hence, I would like to leave on Monday night next, and shall be back just as soon as I can possibly do so.
Everything is going well at school just now, apart from some sore throats which seem this year to have hit the Staff. The health of the children has been remarkably good.
Taking you in anticipation, and advising you that I have already informed Commissioner MacKay, I am,

Yours sincerely,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In conversation with Major MacKay, Commissioner for Indian Affairs for B.C., yesterday when on a visit to the School, I mentioned the fact that I was planning to send a farmer over to Alberni at the end of this month, and asked him if he thought I were wise in doing so. He said that he could not advise me definitely that the new school would be completed, and asked me to write you saying that he had advised my doing so.

I know perfectly well that much hinges upon the attitude of the new Parliament toward the entire scheme, but as one school, at least will have to be run, it would be a matter of choice as to which one would be conducted. Of course, if funds are not forthcoming for both the "San" and the School, it might be less expense just to allow the new school to wait, and keep on operating this building as a School. Doubtless all this is within the purview of the Department officials.

You will see, however, that if a decision is made rather suddenly to open up over at Alberni, and I have made no provision for hay, grain, or supplies (garden), it would be a bit awkward, not to say expensive, to have to buy everything of that kind, or even to have to freight it over from here, which would be next best.

I could, of course, send a man over anyway, and all that was raised would be to the good, especially in view of war necessities. I did not like to do this without informing you of my intention.

While not in the least intending this letter as even a suggestion that the Department take any responsibility in such a venture, still if you could give me any lead as to the chances of our moving or not, it would be helpful to me in deciding what ought to be done.

The whole question of the farm here, and the produce from same, will have to be taken up later. Meantime as we are all organized here for work, I am going ahead and shall crop this place, but leave off such items as tomatoes, for instance, which would not be harvested until after the student body returned, in September, and they might not be here. Grain and potatoes will be put in as usual, also garden stuff.

Thanking you for your kind attention to this, I am,

Yours sincerely,

PRESS RELEASE

Announcement was made today by Rev. Dr. R. B. Cochrane, Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, that the Coqualeetza Residential school at Sardis, B.C., will be turned back to the government to be used in the future as a sanitarium for tuberculosis patients. The building has been used by the United Church of Canada as a school for 200 Indian children. The change was made at the request of the government who are seeking to eradicate tuberculosis from Indians.

Assurance has been given by the Canadian Indians Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources that accommodation for the majority of children now being educated at Coqualeetza would be provided in a new enlarged Government school at Alberni (to take the place of the school burned there two years ago.) This new school is now under construction.

The Board of Home Missions of the United Church of Canada, after consultation with church officials and other interested parties in B.C., and after prolonged negotiations with the Department of Mines and Resources, has accepted the proposal of the government, whose approval has been given to the issuing of this statement.

Rev. R. C. Scott, B.A., now principal at Coqualeetza, who for many years was in charge of the mission boat "Thomas Crosby", has been appointed to the principalship of the new Alberni school.

Dear Mr Hoey:

I am writing from Vancouver and I have had a bit of a shock.

For some months I have been taking throat treatments from Dr Gordon Large of this city. The first time he operated was last July, when he removed what he called a Singer's "Node" from my larynx. It healed pretty well, but left what he called rough edges, which he took off two weeks ago last Saturday.

I saw him again last evening, and he told me that if he were I, he would go at once to the Mayo Clinic. He said that although the "node" was not "malignant," still "something" was keeping the chord from healing. He said that none of the throat men in Vancouver had the instruments to do more than he had done, and that the only thing was for to go as soon as possible, to the above clinic. He said he would write the doctor whom he wished me to see, and that he would ask that I be "put through" as quickly as possible. He said, I would not need to be away for more than "a couple of weeks."

Consequently I came in this afternoon and have seen both Mr Daunt and the Commissioner. Commissioner McKay said he had no authority to grant me leave, but that he strongly recommended it be granted and asked me to write you as I am doing and ask that you wire me permission to be absent from the School for two, or if necessary three weeks.

It is quite a shock to be advised as above, especially now when I wanted to be able to carry on during the proposed change in the status of the School. Dr Large seemed to think that if I had the proper attention right away, it would be possible for me to do so. Hence my letter.

I would greatly appreciate it if you would wire Mr Daunt permission for me to go, as I would like to leave on Friday night.

I shall place Mr Peake, our Boys' Overseer, in charge. He has been at the school for more than ten years, and is thoroughly competent to carry on. Miss Wilson will co-operate in the office, and things will go on well I am sure. I have been away as long as the time proposed, several times, when visiting reserves in the interest of the School and of graduates.

Hoping you will grant the permission, and thanking you in anticipation,

I am,

Yours sincerely,

February 3rd,

My dear Mr. Hoey:

You will remember that when I was in Ottawa a few weeks ago, I discussed with you, and also with Mr. Crerar, the desirability of an announcement being made simultaneously by the Government and by The Board of Home Missions of The United Church of Canada in regard to the Coqualeetza and Alberni situation. I understood both Mr. Crerar and yourself to agree that my proposal was a reasonable one. I have, however, heard nothing from either of you since in regard to the matter.

I am enclosing a draft of what I think might be the kind of brief statement to be issued. I should be glad if you would let me know what the Department thinks about issuing something of this kind at the same time as it is given to the press by our office.

I suppose it might meet the situation - and perhaps it is the quickest way to get action - if your Department were to send me a letter, authorizing us to make such a statement as I am sending with this letter. I might then add a sentence to the effect that the statement is issued after authorization has been secured from the Department.

Will you be good enough to give your personal attention to this at the earliest possible moment. The Board of Home Missions has taken over, as you know, the administration of the Alberni property, and also of the School, from The Woman's Missionary Society, and Mr. Scott will have to visit Alberni in the very near future. We think that this statement ought to be given publicity before he goes, so that everyone will understand that he is there as the new Principal.

Thanking you for your co-operation in this and all other matters in connection with Indian education,

Believe me,

Very sincerely yours,

RBC.MLT

Enc.
SUGGESTED STATEMENT RE COQUALEETZA
to be issued simultaneously by the Government
and The Board of Home Missions of The United
Church of Canada

In connection with its fight against tuberculosis, The Indian Affairs Branch of The Department of Mines and Resources more than a year ago approached The Board of Home Missions of The United Church of Canada, with the request that the Coqualeetza Residential School at Sardis, B.C., be turned over to the Government, to be used in the future as a sanitarium. Assurance was given that accommodation for the majority of the children now being educated at Coqualeetza would be provided in a new, enlarged residential school at Alberni (to take the place of the one which was burned there two years ago), and that the rest could be placed in improved day schools or additions to existing schools at various points up the Pacific coast.

After consultation with church officials and other interested parties in British Columbia, and after prolonged negotiations with the Department, the Board of Home Missions of the United Church has recently accepted the proposal of the Government.

The Alberni School is now in course of erection and will be ready for use at the opening of the fall term. The Government, on the nomination of the United Church, has appointed to the principalship of the new Alberni School the Rev. R. C. Scott, B.A., now the Principal at Coqualeetza, who was for many years in charge of the mission boat, "Thomas Crosby."
STATEMENT by Mr. R.H. Carter, Farm Instructor, Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.

Inspector Barry. I have been instructed to investigate certain reports with reference to the alleged ill-treatment of children at the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.

I wish to warn you that your statements will be taken down in writing. They will then be read to you, and you will be given the opportunity to satisfy yourself that what has been written is what you said. You will then be asked to sign the statement. Is that satisfactory?

Mr. Carter. Yes.

Question. (Inspector Barry) What is your name?
Answer. (Mr. Carter) Raymond Henry Carter.

Ques. What is your address?
Ans. Sardis, B.C.

Inspector Barry. One matter to be investigated is your alleged treatment of an Indian boy, Joe Hans.

Ques. Do you remember a certain night in March when there was some trouble with Joe?

Ans. Yes.

Ques. Were you on duty that night?
Ans. Yes.

Ques. What did your duty consist of?
Ans. The general control of the boys before prayers.

Ques. What happened that night?
Ans. I was trying to line the boys up to go into prayers. The custom is to line the boys up in two rows. I gave the order for them to fall in two deep. They were slow. I tried to hustle them into place. While I was doing this practically everything that I said was mimicked by Joe Hans and Henry Paul, two senior boys. I asked
them to be quiet, several times. They paid no attention to me at all, so I told Joe that if he would not keep quiet, I should have to take measures to make him keep quiet. He said, "Do you think you can do it?" I said, "Yes", and then I slapped at him.

Ques. Did you tell Joe that you would make him hit the dust?
Ans. No.

Ques. Did Joe dodge your slap?
Ans. Yes.

Ques. Did you fall on the ground?
Ans. Yes, I lost my balance and fell on my hands.

Ques. What did Joe do?
Ans. He ran upstairs.

Ques. When did you next see Joe?
Ans. I saw Joe after prayers, sitting in the window of the Senior Teacher's class-room.

Ques. What did you do next?
Ans. I was outside on the fire-escape, and Joe slammed the window shut and put the night latch on. Mr. McLaughlin, the Senior Teacher, told Joe to open the window, which he did. I then told Joe to come up to Mr. Peake's, (the Boys' Supervisor) office.

Ques. Did Joe follow you?
Ans. Yes.

Ques. What happened then?
Ans. I reasoned with him, and Joe admitted that he was wrong and that he deserved a strapping. I gave him six straps on his seat.

Ques. Did you have Joe remove his pants?
Ans. Yes.

Ques. Did you strap Joe on his bare seat?
Ans. No. He was wearing underclothes.

Ques. With what did you strap Joe?
Ans. I used a strap that is kept in Mr. Peake's office.

Ques. Was this strap a piece of harness or trace?
Ans. It might be. I could not swear to it. I do not know where it came from.
Ques. Is the punishment you describe the common form of punishment administered in the School towards the boys?
Ans. I do not know what the other members of the staff do, but that is what I used.

Ques. (Captain Scott) Is that the only form of punishment given to the boys in the School?
Ans. No.

Ques. (Captain Scott) Are other forms of punishment used before strapping is resorted to?
Ans. Yes.

Ques. (Inspector Barry) Have you given corporal punishment to the boys of the School on other occasions?
Ans. Yes.

Ques. Have you made the boys take their pants down when you strapped them?
Ans. Only on one other occasion.

Ques. How long have you been employed as Farm Instructor at the School?
Ans. I have been in charge of the Farm department for some two years. Before that I was Assistant to Captain Peary, Farm Instructor, for about a year and a half.

Ques. Since you have been in charge of the farm, how many times have you punished boys in the way you describe?
Ans. Just twice.

Ques. Are you permitted to give corporal punishment to the boys without first referring the case to the Principal?
Ans. No.

Ques. Did you refer this case of Joe Hans to the Principal?
Ans. No. The Principal was not here.

Ques. Did you refer the case to the Acting Principal and Boys' Supervisor, Mr. Peake?
Ans. Yes.

Ques. Did Mr. Peake give you permission to punish Joe Hans?
Ans. Yes. He added, "Now is a good time to do it."

Ques. Have you ever punished boys by having them eat soap?

Ans. No.

Ques. From your knowledge have you ever known the eating of soap to be used as a punishment in the School?

Ans. No.

Inspector Barry. Mr. Carter, it is only fair to you to permit you to make any statement you wish. This will, of course, be taken down and added to the record.

Ques. Was Cecil Perkins, Assistant Farm Instructor, at Coqualeetza from about February 1st to the end of March, 1940?

Ans. No. He was here only during the month of February.

Ques. Was Mr. Perkins in the Coqualeetza boys' basement playroom at the time of the Joe Hans incident?

Ans. No.

Ques. Are you quite sure that Mr. Perkins was not present?

Ans. No. He was not present.

Statement from Mr. Carter.

I consider Mr. Cecil Perkins was a highly unsatisfactory farm assistant. He neither did his work properly nor did he attend to his team. He often told the boys stories during hours of work, and thereby interfered with the progress of the farm work. Mr. Perkins told me that he would have to get a strap for the boys up in the dormitory over the Manual Training shop, of which dormitory he was in charge. A few days later he told me that he had a good one.

Ques. Do you wish to add anything with regard to your own treatment of the boy Joe Hans?

Ans. Yes.
Statement. Joe Hans had previous to the incident mentioned threatened to give me a licking. He is a big boy of about sixteen years of age, and has been very annoying all the year.

I feel that I should not have attempted to slap Joe on that occasion in the basement.

R.H. Carter

Witness.
STATEMENT by Mr. E. Peake, Boys' Supervisor, Cequmleetza Indian Residential School.

Inspector Barry. I have been instructed to investigate certain reports with reference to the alleged ill-treatment of children at the Cequmleetza Indian Residential School.

I wish to warn you that your statements will be taken down in writing. They will then be read to you, and you will be given an opportunity of satisfying yourself that what has been written is what you said. You will then be asked to sign the statement. Is that satisfactory?

Mr. Peake. Yes.

Ques. What is your name?
Ans. Edward Peake.

Ques. What is your address?
Ans. Sardis, B.C.

Ques. What are your duties?
Ans. I am the Boys' Supervisor. I have held this position for five years. Previously I was in charge of the gardens.

Ques. Do you remember trouble occurring between Mr. Carter and Joe Hans one evening last March?
Ans. Yes, but I do not remember the date.

Ques. On that occasion were you in charge of the School?
Ans. I do not remember. I was in charge of the School during the absence of Mr. Scott, but I do not remember the date of the incident.

Ques. Did you give Mr. Carter permission to administer corporal punishment to Joe Hans?
Ans. I do not remember. If this was the incident that happened at prayer time, I did not give any permission, as I was out.

Ques. Did Mr. Carter ask you for permission to punish Joe Hans on that occasion?
Ans. No.

Ques. Are you quite sure he did not ask you for permission?
Ans. Yes. I am quite sure he did not.

Ques. Is it part of your duty to administer corporal punishment to the boys?

Ans. Yes.

Ques. Have you on occasion administered corporal punishment to a boy without first obtaining permission from the Principal?

Ans. Yes.

Ques. If corporal punishment is administered to a boy, what instrument is used?

Ans. A strap which has been used at the School for many years.

Ques. Is the strap mentioned by you a regular rubber school strap?

Ans. No. It is a leather strap, about 18 inches long, about 1½ inches wide and not more than half an inch thick.

Ques. Is this strap a harness strap or part of a trace?

Ans. No.

Ques. Have you ever punished boys by having them eat soap?

Ans. No.

Ques. To your knowledge has such a punishment ever been given at Cequaleetza?

Ans. No.

Ques. Are you quite sure that such a punishment has not been given?

Ans. Quite sure. It has, however, been the custom for many years to require boys who use foul language to wash out their mouths with soap and water. There was an occasion early this year, when certain boys had been instructed to wash their mouths out. Among these boys was one new boy. The others, as a joke, suggested to him that he would have to bite a piece of soap off and chew it. He came to me with the soap in his mouth. I immediately told him to spit it out, and assured him that the boys had been playing a joke on him and that, of course, he did not have to eat it. He did not eat it.
Ques. Did you ever warn Cecil Perkins against making statements to Departmental officials, with regard to matters at the School?
Ans. No. When Mr. Perkins' time was up, during the absence of the Principal, Mr. Scott, and while I was acting as Principal, I received permission to re-hire him for another month. When I asked him if he would stay, he requested an increase in salary, which I declined, as I had no authority. Mr. Perkins told me that he could cause a lot of trouble by talking. I told him that only a person with a small mind would think of such a thing, and that the Departmental officials would be too broad-minded to consider such things. He did not state what he proposed to say to them. Our conversation was quite friendly throughout.

Ques. Did you tell Mr. Perkins that those who carry tales to the Departmental officials make more trouble for themselves?
Ans. No.

Ques. Did you tell Mr. Perkins that the Department realized that they were producing results and were satisfied to continue?
Ans. No.

Ques. Was Mr. Perkins' work satisfactory when he was on duty in charge of the boys?
Ans. No. He did not maintain the dignity of a member of the Coqualeetza staff.

Ques. How many times during the present academic year have you found it necessary to use corporal punishment in the case of the boys?
Ans. Several times. During the last five years we have hardly ever used the strap in the punishment of boys, because we did not believe in corporal punishment. The policy of the School has been to avoid corporal punishment except when such is absolutely essential. In place of corporal punishment, the children lost certain privileges. This year we have had a number of serious offenses committed by the boys, such as theft and the breaking into of locked rooms and premises around the school, and a recent case in which two boys entered a girls' dormitory. A number of boys
were involved in each of several cases of unlocking doors and suitcases. In these cases each boy was strapped.

Ques. Who administered these corporal punishments?
Ans. I did on most occasions, but the Principal has first given his permission and in fact been present.

Ques. Were the boys' pants taken down?
Ans. They slipped them down themselves, but the strap was not given on their bare seats, except in possibly one case.

Ques. How old are you?
Ans. I am thirty-seven years of age, and have been about twelve years at Coqualeetza, and was previously in charge of Boy Scouts and Troop packs, in fact, ever since I was a school boy.

Edward Peake

Principal
REV. R.C. SCOTT, B.A.

Sardis, B.C. June 24th, 1940.

Re Joseph Hans, Pupil of this School, and Ray Carter, Farm Instructor:

I. I beg to say that Mr. Perkins who was for two months Assistant Farm Instructor, as from February the 1st last, told me about Mr. Carter having "made a pass" at Joe Hans in the Senior playroom; I sent for Mr. Carter, and found that he had, after great provocation, made a "slap" at Joe Hans, that Joe had dodged the blow, and had gone off upstairs. I made it very clear to Mr. Carter, that he done a most unwise thing, and that such actions were not conducive to discipline. I gave him to understand that there should be no more such occurrences. He admitted that he had been wrong, and was sorry for it.

Mr. Perkins did not tell me of the occurrence until after friction had been occasioned between him and Mr. Carter. Perkins was quite inefficient in his work with the horses and on the farm, and Mr. Carter, who is a good farmer, presented both the example he set the boys, and in particular, the poor care he gave the horses.

2. There is absolutely no truth in the statement that boys are forced to "eat" soap as a punishment. On a very few occasions boys have been advised, after using bad language, that they ought to "wash out their mouths".

3. No boys running away: only one boy actually ran away from the School. He was Claude Davidson, and his case was reported to the Indian Agent and to the Commissioner. He was afterwards expelled. Two other boys were out overnight, but came back of their own accord when they found they were hurting only themselves.

4. The use of the word "Penance" in describing what Mr. Perkins found when he came to the School, is quite wrong. It is not customary to use corporal punishment in the school. For five years there has been practically none of it. Instead, we have punished boys by the taking away of privileges such as not being allowed to go to Picture Shows, or for walks on Saturday afternoons. Even these instances were for rather serious disobedience. There has been such an instance before Mr. Perkins came, and the boys were still under loss of privileges for having pilfered fruit from store rooms in the school, and from the basement of the Principal's Residence. In this case, I also made certain of the boys who were ring-leaders, work on Saturday afternoons. I state this to show that we used other methods of dealing with these boys, rather than corporal punishment. There was no "trying to escape" from the school as Mr. Perkins would try to insinuate.

5. No punishment, corporal or otherwise was administered in such a way as to cause even minor harm to any boy. One boy was asked to report to the nurse, in order to see if he needed any treatment after being strapped, but this was found to be unnecessary. His hands were red, and a bit swollen, but were already beginning to mend, with no treatment at all. Corporal punishment is used only for such misdemeanours as stealing, or for conduct toward girls which was wrong. The boy above mentioned, (in this paragraph) had gone into a Girls' dormitory, and while he had not done further wrong, still it was a serious thing and had to be punished.

Re: Joe Hans

6. Even before Inspector Barry came, and following my conversation with Mr Carter about having tried to "Slap" Joe Hans, I gave Mr Carter to understand that such conduct would not be tolerated. I also informed him that I felt it would be better for him not to come to the new school. Since talking with Captain Barry, I shall make that quite clear, and I shall not take Mr Carter to Alberni as a member of the staff of the new school. He lost his temper, and that is something which a staff member must not do, even under provocation.

7. I would like to say, that the conduct on the part of the boys which has necessitated corporal punishment was due to two things:

(I) because of the fact that I was away so much in getting treatment for the throat trouble which has afflicted me this last six months. While Mr Peake gave good service, still the knowledge that I was away was not conducive to good conduct on the part of a few boys who took advantage of the situation.

(2) Because of the attitude of Mr Perkins. This I feel was one of the big factors. He had no idea of discipline, nor of his responsibility to other staff members for co-operation in his work as Farm Assistant, and while in charge of the boys. Within a week of the time he came he brought in a poem he had written about the boys' successes, "this is our task" etc etc. I explained as judiciously as possible, that his responsibility was not the writing or poetry, but the carrying out of his duty to me and to the boys in the light of the school rules. Indian boys and girls do not need to be told a thing outright, and they vividly sensed that Mr Perkins was "befriending" them, and that the rules of the school were strict. Consequently, while previous to his coming no criticism had been directed against the school, or any member of staff, the attitude of Perkins undermined authority. He would tell the stories when he ought to have been directing their work in the fields, and neglected his work in other ways, in order to show them that the Prairie Indians had made him a "chief" in recognition of his contribution to their welfare. In fact he knew nothing at all about Indian boys and girls, and seemed to set himself up as being quite above doing the ordinary work of a Staff member. I had to allow him to stay on for another month, even after giving him notice at the end of his first month, that his services were no longer required simply because I found I had to make another trip to Moyes, and could not on the spur of the moment bring in a completely new staff member. At the same time I warned Mr Peake, that we would be "lucky" if I got off without rather serious undermining of discipline, as I felt that Perkins was not suited to the work of having charge of boys. I had, however, taken him off the farm work proper, and had given him work in the orchard, and hoped that he would get along there without making trouble. This unfortunately, to my mind, was without avail.

8. I have listened to the evidence given before Captain Barry and believe it was given in a straightforward manner, and was true.

Dear Major McKay:

In accordance with the instructions contained in your letter 15/19/6266 of the 21st instant, I held a preliminary enquiry at the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, where the complaints contained in a letter from Mr. Cecil Perkins to you, dated June 20th, were thoroughly investigated.

A list of members of the present Coqualeetza staff whom Captain Scott intends to employ in connection with the operation of the new school at Alert Bay was first obtained. This has been attached to the proceedings.

The contents of Mr. Perkins' letter mentioned above, were carefully outlined to Captain Scott, who was also informed that you had instructed me to enquire into the charges made.

Captain Scott arranged for the necessary members of his staff to appear before me for interrogation, and the services of Miss Talbot, stenographer, Coqualeetza, were placed at my disposal. All persons examined were warned that their statements would be taken down in writing, and that they would be later requested to sign such statements on verification of same. Captain Scott was present throughout the whole of this preliminary enquiry and was of considerable assistance to me.

A signed statement by Captain Scott, as Principal of the Coqualeetza School, is also attached to the proceedings.

I am perfectly satisfied that there has been no ill-treatment whatever of the boys as alleged. The statements of Mr. Cecil Perkins are, in my opinion, a very highly exaggerated account of two or three instances that undoubtedly happened during the time he was at the Coqualeetza School. In my opinion there is no need whatever for any further investigation or enquiry into this matter.

I have advised the Reverend Principal that it would be well in future to limit the infliction of corporal punishment by requiring that definite permission must first be obtained, either from him as Principal or in
his absence from the Acting Principal of the School.

I would further advise that in future any such corporal punishment be given with a regulation school strap made of rubber. The actual strap used for years at this School was specially made for the purpose; is not part of a harness trace as suggested, but is, in my opinion, rather too thick, especially for the punishment of the smaller boys.

I trust that the results of the investigation carried out today will be satisfactory to you, and that there will be no need for the Department to take any further action in the matter; particularly so as Captain Scott has given me his assurance in writing (see his statement attached) that Mr. Carter, against whom the main charges were made, will not be employed as a member of the new Alberni School staff.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In the interests of better treatment of Indian Children I wish to report the following incidents which happened while I was employed at Indian Residential School at Sardis.

It is part of the duties of the Farmer, Engineer and Assistant Farmer on alternate nights to line the boys up in the basement for roll call previous to them marching into the assembly hall for prayers. On the night in question which was in the latter part of March, Mr. Carter the farmer had that office or duty to perform. The boys were slow in taking their places and at last Mr. Carter addressing one of the older pupils Joe Hans with the remark that he (Mr. Carter) would make Joe hit the dust. At the same time striking at the pupil with his fist. The boy dodged the blow and the momentum caused Mr. Carter to fall on the floor of the basement. Had the blow landed it could easily have seriously injured the boy. Joe left the line up and hid on one of the fire-escapes. After prayers Mr. Carter discovered Joe in the Senior Teachers room and proceeded to administer a severe thrashing. This was done with a section or piece of a harness trade after the boy had been made to take down his pants. This is the common form of punishment employed in the school towards the boys.

I informed Mr. Scott of this incident and registered my disapproval of such action. In the following days the boys used the phrase "I'll make you hit the dust" incessantly and it did much to disrupt the discipline.

I also protested to Mr. Scott that Mr. Carter was not a fit person to supervise the boys as he was antagonizing them and causing them to attempt run-aways. In the first few weeks on one occasion two boys left the school and were away the most of the night. Cold foggy weather forced them to return. When I arrived at the school many boys were still working out penance for attempted breaks for escapes.

On...........
On another occasion one evening in March when I was about to tell stories to the children in one of the younger dormitories I found a number in the lavatory eating toilet soap. This soap is the same color as Lifebuoy and is used extensively by the school. They had each been ordered to eat half a cake as a punishment for swearing. I made them stop and go back to their dormitory.

During the course of a conversation with Mr. Peake about the end of February, he warned me against carrying tales to the department as he said others had tried it and only made more trouble for themselves. The department realized he said that they were producing results and were satisfied to continue.

Yours truly,

"Cecil Perkins"

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I do not think you have been directly informed as to my recovery of speech, and in view of the sympathetic attitude which you and other Officials at Ottawa took, I feel that I ought to express my deep appreciation.

I am glad to say that I have been talking now for over two weeks. Dr. New, at Mayo, asked me to report to Dr. Paton in Vancouver, as Dr. Large had been called out for Military service. I did so, upon my return from the last operation at Rochester, and was delighted to be told that I might talk.

I think that Dr. New's decision, that my voice would be as good, if not better than ever, is likely to be fulfilled. I have no sense of strain when speaking in ordinary conversation, and am sure I shall be able to speak in public again, as soon as the chords have got back into training, as it were.

However, I shall exercise great care, and again wish to thank you for the way in which I was allowed to go for treatment when necessary.

Although it will be a big task, I am looking forward to doing my best at Alberni, and feel glad of the opportunity to be of service.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Establishment of an Indian day school at the Coqualeetza Hospital, Sardis, B.C.

In view of the number of children of school age that will be receiving treatment at the Coqualeetza Hospital, it is considered advisable to provide two teachers for their instruction. This practically amounts to establishing a new day school and consequently I believe it will be necessary to secure an Order-in-Council in order to comply with Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act. I, therefore, attach Memorandum to Council.

When the Acting Superintendent of Medical Services visited British Columbia recently the question of engaging teachers was fully discussed with all interested and it was decided that such action was extremely desirable. Dr. Moore included a recommendation to this effect in the report which he submitted following his visit to Coqualeetza.

With the exception of the salaries of the teachers and the supplying of the necessary text books and other small school supplies, it is not anticipated that there will be any heavy expenditure as most of the teaching will be done in the wards in which the children are located, thus obviating the necessity of setting up classrooms equipped with desks etc.

It is proposed to pay a salary of $75.00 a month to each of the two teachers.

Director.

The other copy of Form N.D.T.1 is to be retained on file by the employer when available at any time for inspection by officers of this Division.

If Form N.D.T.1 is not completed by the employee, the employee is to be regarded for tax purposes as a single person without dependents. It will accordingly be apparent that it is unnecessary for single persons without dependents to complete and file Form N.D.T.1.

Dear Sir:

With reference to filling the vacancy for a teacher at Coqualeetza Indian Hospital, created by the retirement of Mrs. L. Wilson, I would advise that considerable difficulty has been experienced in securing another teacher possessing the qualifications needed for this somewhat specialized position.

Recently Mr. Commissioner MacKay and Dr. Barclay interviewed a Miss Mary Nixon of Chilliwack, an Anglican, with First Class B.C. Certificate and handicraft experience, and the Commissioner expressed himself to the writer as being very satisfied with her fitness for the position. However, I am now informed by Dr. Barclay that she is now receiving a salary of $40.00 for a ten month term and is practically certain to receive $900.00 on her return to duty, owing to recent general increases in teachers' salaries in this Province. I would also point out that the demand for women in industry and government employment at higher rates than is prevalent in the teaching profession is already beginning to bring resignations among our teaching staff, their higher standard of education evidently making them desirable employees.

The problem is now that in order to secure Miss Nixon's services we must ensure her of a salary practically equivalent to that likely to be received by her if she remains with her present school. Discussing this with Dr. Barclay, he suggests that she could be allowed $5.00 per month in lieu of one meal at the hospital, which is their usual allowance. Dear Sir:

Re.: Miss Surges, Teacher.

I have discussed with Miss Surges the matter of her nationality and would like to submit the following information:

Her paternal great-grandfather was born in Bavaria. Her grandfather was "brought up in the United States," although she is unable to state whether or not he was born there. Her father is an American Citizen, at present living in Seattle.

Her maternal grandfather was German-born, but became a naturalized American Citizen. Her mother is American-born, but is now a naturalized British Subject, residing in Vancouver.

Miss Surges was born in Vancouver, but for a few years lived in the United States. This, I believe, was when she was a teen-age girl. On one of her trips to the States she says that the American Immigration authorities accepted her as an American Citizen, but when she came to return to Vancouver, the Canadian authorities accepted her as a Canadian Citizen. She is rather upset over the situation that has arisen in connection with her status and has expressed the intention that, if legally she is an American Citizen, she would like to take out British naturalization papers.

Miss Surges appears very interested in her work here and, pending the settlement of this matter, I would ask that the Department permit her to carry on this work.

If there is any further information needed that I can obtain I will be glad to hear from you again.

Yours very truly,

Major D. M. MacKay,

While in Ottawa recently I had a very interesting discussion with Miss Moody regarding our vocational work. I mentioned to her that although the amount of work seems to be gradually increasing we are still finding it very difficult to keep our finances in a fluid state. We have tried to extend our retail outlets but returns from these are sometimes a bit slow coming in and we are also up against the necessity of carrying a certain amount of stock on hand until it can be sold, which stock has already been paid for to the patients.

Since at times we have had as much as $250 or $300 tied up in stock or in outstanding accounts there seems no doubt in my mind that we require additional aid to properly finance this department of our hospital work. Dear Miss Moodie,

Replying to your letter of March 12th regarding beads for vocational work I think that under the circumstances we would be glad indeed to receive even the $25.00 worth of beads suggested in your letter and just as soon as we can sell some of the quantity of completed articles that we have on hand I think we should be able to pay for an additional quantity ourselves.

For your information and interest we are sending you under separate cover a small assortment of some of the beaded lapel novelties that we have been making here, literally by the hundreds. This has been going on of course for between two and three years and there has been a very wide sale in and around Vancouver and in smaller quantities farther afield. For quite a long time they proved very popular at Whitehorse while the Americans were in there in large numbers. At this time of year however, our markets seem to have dropped off and our small working capital is all tied up in stock. I am trying to place these articles in some new locations in Vancouver and Victoria also in the Hudson Bay Store in Edmonton and Saskatoon. I wrote to the General Purchasing Agent for the C.N.R. in Winnipeg some time ago but have had no reply from him.

The price we charge here, which in a sense is the "wholesale price" is shown on the sales slip enclosed with the articles. We have found that the mark-up on the gauntlets is usually 15¢, on the chief's and squaws (which we sell at 90¢ per pair) it amounts to 20¢ or even 35¢. The moccasins usually mark-up 15¢ or 20¢ depending on whether they have been fur trimmed or not.
Since these are lapel novelties you can understand why we desire the brighter colours as they are intended to harmonize or contrast with women's garments. A certain number of the dark or paisley beads can be used when mixed with the brighter colours. Mrs. Robertson, the teacher, who is in charge of this work here has enclosed a pair of the dolls made with the dark colours and you can see that they are far from attractive. We can always use the white seed beads and also black for the head dress of the chiefs but we necessarily have to have reds for the faces. Red is one shade that we have the greatest difficulty in getting.

You mentioned pussy-willow and acorn designs and I expect you mean that these are on leather. We have had no experience with this here but perhaps you might draw a sketch of what you mean. Our dolls and moccasins are perhaps not original here at Sardis but as far as I know they are not being made in any quantity anywhere else in B.C. so that we have pretty well monopolized the market.

We would be very glad to have your impressions about the work and any suggestions you might care to make. I might say, incidentally that our patients receive all but 5¢ or 10¢ of the wholesale price shown besides which we supply the beads to them for nothing when they are given to us and at cost when we have to buy them.

W.S. Barclay

W.S. Barclay, M.D.,

Re: Miss McGrand.

I was rather dismayed to note the contents of your letter of November 18th, file 107-3-5759, and I have tried to check the situation here.

Actually, it seems that we have practically no information on file on Miss McGrand either before she came or even since her arrival. Your file reference to her age as being 50, is probably the result of a verbal conversation with myself when I expect I quoted Mrs. Robertson as saying that she believed Miss McGrand would be about the same age as herself; namely, "around 55".

I have enquired from Mrs. Robertson as to what she knows further about this matter and it appears that Miss McGrand retired on superannuation (in Saskatchewan I believe) some four years or so ago. Correspondence that developed between Mrs. Robertson and her own cousins or perhaps between Mrs. Robertson and Miss McGrand, evidently included a statement from Miss McGrand that she felt too active and energetic to wish to continue in retirement. One must naturally assume that the retiring age was 60, so that her official age as now reported is probably correct.

It seems to me that the Archbishop was under some obligation to check on this matter before her final nomination. Altogether the matter has now resolved itself into a most unfortunate situation. Miss McGrand came all the way from New Brunswick, I believe, at her own expense. Since no Catholic nomination was forthcoming from last Christmas until well after the school term began this fall, I think the Department can ill-afford to take the stand at this time that her services must be dispensed with.

In reply to your memo 869-1 of 13 January '50, we may advise you that the Coqualeetza Indian Hospital, which formerly accommodated something over 200 patients has, following the fire in November '48, been rehabilitated to the extent of now accommodating 100 patients more or less. I have the honor to submit the following memorandum of matters connected with Indian Institute work at Chilliwack B.C. and respectfully recommend the same to the favorable consideration of the Superintendent-General.

A few years ago an Institute for Indian Girls was erected at Chilliwack by the Canadian Missionary Society of the Methodist Church and was maintained by them until recently with very excellent results. As you are doubtless aware a grant was made by the government in aid of the building and also a subsequent annual grant in aid of maintenance. A few months ago the building was accidentally burned, but a number of the pupils were taken into the adjacent mission house.
House, and since then a temporary building has been erected for school purposes, so that there has not been much interruption of the work of the Institute. The building was insured and the loss is but slightly aught on furniture and personal possessions of teachers.

The burning of the building (known as the Cogwaltza Home) raised the question of more extended efforts in the future. A conference was held between representatives of the General Missionary Society of the Methodist Church and the Canadian Missionary Society, the result being an agreement to carry on Institute work corporately for both boys and girls. A site of 20 acres has been purchased about a quarter of a mile south of the Sandis Post Office, being a portion of what is known as the Webb Farm, and instructions have been given.
given to T. Cooper Esq., architect,

My Dear Mr Sifton,

There are one or two matters in connection with the Indian schools, &c., in British Columbia, to which I venture to call your attention. For a number of years we have asked for a grant of $500 for the Boys' Home at Port Simpson, but hitherto it has not been granted. It seems to us that it is a very reasonable request, and I sincerely hope you will see your way to include it in the estimates for next year.

A still more urgent matter is the question of a residence for the Principal of the Coqualeetza Institute. You are aware that only a small amount was received from the Government for land and buildings, and that the greater portion of the cost has been borne by the Missionary Society, which is indirect contrast with the experience of all other Institutes in British Columbia. But there are other and yet stronger reasons for action in the present instance. In the building as originally planned no provision was made for the Principal's accommodation, and he and his family have been subjected to a great deal of inconvenience which, however, they have very patiently borne for the sake of the work; but new circumstances are such that it would seem imperative that something should be done. In a private letter received from
the Rev Mr Hall he details the reasons for pressing this request at the present time, and if you desire I will send you his letter. There is at the Coqualeetza Institute an Advisory Committee of persons in the neighborhood, and in considering the whole question they strongly recommend the immediate erection of a house for the Principal, and have mentioned the sum of $2,500 as the amount which in their judgment would be required. If anything can be done it is important it should be done at once, and if you can see your way to put the above, or some other, sum in the estimates for next year, we would in the meantime advance the money, if necessary, and take our chances of the item being voted by Parliament. I understand that the local member, Mr Morrison, has enquired into the matter and gives it his support.

The reasons are principally three on the grounds of which I would urge my request upon the favorable consideration of the department.

Dear Bro:

I am in receipt of your favor of the 1st Inst enclosing copy of a communication from the Indian Department in which information regarding the present location of the principal's quarters within the building is asked for. I have had the sketches of a plan of the different floors of the Institution, showing the way in which the space is divided, prepared by the carpenter, and forward them by this mail.

These sketches will show that we have absolutely no accommodation in the Institute but Bed rooms. We have no family room and the bed room accommodation is distributed, and found in whatever corner a room can be found, even if it has to be by partitioning off a corner from a pupils dormitory or by occupying a room which had previously been used for a hospital. By rights the room occupied by our little girl ought to be reserved still for Hospital purposes, as well as the neighboring rooms now occupied by the cooking and sewing teachers, for the reasons that one should be occupied by the nurse, and there might easily be more than one invalid at a time; and besides the sick ones occupying these rooms would be in quieter quarters and farther removed from...
the other pupils, rendering the spread of contagion less likely to occur. In the original plan of the rooms these were all intended for hospital rooms, and were so marked by the architect. Indeed it would seem that it was not intended when the building was planned that the principal would live in the building, and the best way to relieve the congested condition of things in the building is to move the principal and his family out. If I were to begin to speak of the disadvantages to which the principal and his family have been subjected during our nearly eight years occupancy of the building or rather residence in it, I would be tempted to refer to many things that perhaps had better borne in patience than mentioned, especially if the remedy can be had without exposing them to the light of day. It is enough to say that there can be no family life where every thing is in common - rooms, sitting room and meals. If there were a suite of rooms where the family might be by themselves and have their meals apart, and not be brought into contact with the pupils whenever they stir out of their bedrooms, nor be subject to the constant noise of all that is going on on all sides from morning till night, nor have to guard our little girl every hour of the day through the halls from the unnameable indignities of boys of lustful and beastly passions, then might continued residence in the building be regarded as a proposition to be entertained. But in fact, except in the case of Mount Elgin Institute I am not aware of any Institute where the Principal and his family reside in the building. I see that
your letter from the department speaks of it being the policy of the department that the principal should reside within the school, and that departure from this policy can only be sanctioned on the strongest possible grounds. This sounds strange to my ears.

I have visited Brandon—it is departed from there; I visited St Pauls near Winnipeg—it is departed from there; I visited Elkhorn—it is departed from there; and when I was at St Pauls the department had just taken it over from the Episcopalian denomination, and the principal's residence had just been completed; had not as yet been occupied; Elkhorn had also been taken over from the same denomination but that policy was not in force there. It looks as though it were a policy that is not much practised. I omitted to mention Regina, which also I visited and stayed over night in the home of the principal. Mount Elgin is no doubt ideal in the matter of the relation of the principal's household to the institute, as supplying a home to the family and at the same time residence to the principal within the building. But that was arranged for when the new institute was planned, and I suppose added somewhere between five and ten thousand dollars to the cost of that Institute.

But we have to do now with remedying a condition of things not provided for at the beginning.

I am sorry for the delay which the department hoped would not be necessary.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

With reference to additional accommodation required for the Principal and his family at the Coqualeetza Home, B.C., I beg to state that an addition can be made to the building at the rear of the right wing, without materially impairing the architectural effect of the structure.

If the proposed addition is about 23 feet square, and one story high, the cost will be in the neighbourhood of $1,000. If two stories high, the cost will be about $1,500.

I may here mention that additions to buildings are objectionable in several directions. A lot of money is necessarily spent in rearranging part of the interior of the main building. The new part, almost invariably, settles unequally with the main building, causing unsightly cracks and openings, and the rearrangement of the interior of the addition can not be made as convenient and suitable as it would have been done if erected at the same time as the main building.

If there are not other objections with regard to the advisability of the Principal's quarters being located within the main building, the amount suggested, namely, $1,500., would be more satisfactorily spent and better value obtained if a separate building were constructed.

Chief Surveyor.

The Coqualeetza institute is not the property of the Department. It was built on land belonging
to the Methodist Missionary Society by them out of funds provided by themselves supplemented by a grant of $5000.00 from the Department.

The plans submitted by Dr Sutherland provide for a commodious dwelling containing six bedrooms and a wing for office accommodation.

Dear Brother Ferrier:

Your letter of September 3rd, to hand, with enclosures from the Dunham Co., and the copy of a letter from McDowell & Mann. These, I am returning to you herewith.

With reference to the Dunham system, I can only say our experience of its operation in the severe weather we had, was not satisfactory at all. You have the facts of the case, and we suffered much more that I cared to represent when you were here last, giving only sufficient details to convince you that some remedy should be affected before another winter.

With reference to the letter from McDowell and Mann, it is perfectly true that when he was here we had steam on both boilers, and fired up in such a manner as to raise the pressure and obtain heat throughout the building and an equal distribution in all the radiators. It is true we use a quantity of slab wood when the weather is not very cold. We also used cordwood, good, dry, hard, when the weather was not extreme. But when the extreme weather came with the gale of wind from the North, we used coal only; and there was no shortage. Night and day, without cessation, we tried our best to maintain steam, but failed to get the radiators heated in some parts of the building, other than along the top. We had no difficulty with the radiators on the west side of the house. That part of the building was very comfortable throughout.

I do not consider that the test which was made by Mr. Mann on a warm day with no wind, is a criterion of the trials to raise steam that we had in zero weather in a wind with a velocity of forty-five to fifty miles an hour. That must have had a great influence on the circulation of the vapor in the radiators. My impression is that the cold wind blowing onto the radiators through the opening caused by the shrinkage of the window frames, caused condensation to take place so rapidly, that the water had hardly time to escape through the Dunham valves, before, in some cases, it froze. That, however, is only the opinion of a man not a steam expert. From simple observation that appeared to be the case. Then, from the return pipe, after the water comes through the trap near the boiler, there is only a fall of a foot and a half to two feet, I should judge. This would be about three pounds pressure to open the valves before the return water enters the boiler. The fall is very slight, and might have some effect. It has been suggested to me that a small pump driven by a one-horse power motor, attached to the return pipe would draw off the water and prevent a vacuum. This seems feasible.

I am enclosing a copy of a letter received from Mr. Excel, who inspected the boilers and machinery yesterday. This letter was entirely unsolicited. Mr. Excel is a man whose father, I found, had been a friend of Captain Oliver's in Scotland. In acknowledging the letter I shall inform...
him a copy has been sent to you. The change suggested, I have no doubt, could be made at comparatively small expense. I would not, however, suggest it until we had further tried the present system, which, I feel sure, unless the boilers are too small, ought to operate satisfactorily.

In my judgement, no amount of radiation, or a high-pressure steam boiler, will offset the shrinkage of the woodwork from the brickwork around the windows on the north and east sides of the house, and I would advise this be the first step taken as a remedy, and its affect carefully noted. This would be no experiment.

I have not yet heard from Mr. Orr on the matter.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. C.H. Beley,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

My interest in the boiler plant of your fine School was only whetted during boiler inspection today, through knowing the difficulty you had in properly heating the buildings last winter, and you will pardon perhaps an interest which is not merely idle curiosity.

In your capacity as Superintendent you cannot possibly know all technical details entering into a system of steam heating, and while I am debarrred from advising you on the matter, by reason of my official position, perhaps you will overlook a zeal for engineering perfection, so far as perfection may be obtained.

After a careful survey again on the ground I can only reiterate my comment of last winter that the cast iron heating boilers as installed are unsuited for the installation. They are wasteful of fuel and are undoubtedly undersized to cope with weather conditions as frequently occur at Sardis.

This can only be shown as true by thermometric test of furnace and flue gases, as well as an evaporation test, but I am drawing on twenty-six years of comparative experience to base my conviction.

What you really require, is a steel return tubular type of boiler set up in a standard brick setting, (for fuel and operating efficiency), in place of the very inefficient type of steam generators now in use.

You do not require to purchase such a boiler, brand new, I may say there are a number of suitable boilers available at reasonable prices, such boilers are discarded when we cut the pressures below those ordinarily used for power purposes, that is, to ninety
pounds and under. As you require only about two pounds to operate the Dunham Heating System, almost any boiler in reasonable condition and inspected for, say, even fifty pounds would suit your purpose for a long number of years, given the care exercised in the operation of the Institution. I make this suggestion in all sincerity, and feel sure you can approach your authorities to sanction a change which must surely result in a satisfactory service, and reduced fuel bill, both of which must be a desirable end in the calculation of all concerned.

The actual apparatus designed to transmit heat throughout the building appears to function properly, but I regret, indeed, as a mechanical engineer, I cannot so remark on the heat generating apparatus.

If I can be of assistance to you, and to your wards, through you, I shall be happy to render any service which may be for the common good.

Very sincerely,

S.H. Excell,
Inspector of Steam Boilers &
Machinery.

Dear Sir:

RE- COLQUALERTZA INDIAN SCHOOL.

Further to ours of July 2nd, in this connection, we have made a thorough investigation regarding the difficulty which your Department has had in the Heating of the above Institution, and we are now convinced beyond any doubt that the Dunham Heating System and Equipment that has been installed in the School, functions in a very satisfactory manner.

When the addition to this heating system was installed, early in 1924, some difficulty was experienced in getting proper and free circulation through the system and as a result, of this difficulty, the Dunham Company sent their Chief Engineer from Toronto who paid two visits to the Institution and with the contractors made slight changes in certain connections necessary to remedy the difficulty. The system was then thoroughly tested and our records show that its performance was entirely satisfactory.

Upon receipt of your letter of June 26th, the writer went to Victoria to interview the contractors who had made the installation and was advised that their Mr. Mann, reached the school from Victoria in less than 36 hours from the time he was advised last Spring of the trouble you were having. He immediately asked the Resident Engineer to fire up the system which was done in the Engineer's own way. After he had fired for a period of 3 hours with one boiler, he had still low pressure showing on the gauge, and yet every radiator in the building was hot all the way across the top with a depth of from 4 to 6 inches. Mr. Mann then succeeded in having the other boiler brought into action and fixed in such a manner as to show a slight pressure on the gauge, at which time the steam was turned on to the system and it was found that the entire system down to the last radiator heated perfectly which in itself is proof conclusive that the Dunham Heating system was functioning as it was intended to do.
Rev. Ferrier,

For your information we asked Mr. Mann to state his experience in writing which he did under date of July 10th, and we are enclosing herewith a copy of his letter. We did not forward this information to you until we could discuss the matter with the Rev. Raley, which we succeeded in doing yesterday.

I went over this letter with Mr. Raley paragraph by paragraph and he states that what the letter says, is the absolute truth.

In conversation with Mr. Raley yesterday, he advised that the cold wind blowing in around the windows created a condition so unbearable that he was not only compelled to move his own study, but also the children away from this exposure and that he had covered up these windows with blankets for protection against the cold. We therefore, got the impression that you may find it necessary to put storm windows on this building in order to make it comfortable as the radiators under these windows are almost bound to freeze up if his plant is not properly fired to create the necessary slight boiler pressure, while it would be impossible for them to freeze if the plant were in generally sufficient volume of steam to get the circulation up through the system.

We have taken a good deal of trouble to gather all the facts regarding this matter, not only for our own satisfaction but also for your information and we trust that your Department may see fit to equip this building with such protection as will enable this heating system to give the service for which it is intended, and if there be any further information or assistance we can give, we shall be very glad to hear from you at any time.

Yours truly,

C.A. DUNHAM CO., LTD.,

Dear Sir:

We received your letter of July 2nd enclosing copy of letter from Rev. Perrier, Sup't of Methodist Indian Schools. The writer was out of town, hence delay in answering.

We received note from Rev. Perrier dated April 7th advising system was at fault. Our Mr. Mann left immediately by ferry and was at Sardis on Good Friday and did following: He found system was working as perfect as that style of heating can be and showed Rev. Riley accordingly. The only reason why this system is not "perfect" is because it is necessary to put fuel in the boilers.

Mr. Mann found every radiator in building hot across top no pressure at boiler and one boiler cut off. This showed that circulation or distribution of steam to all radiators was equalized and proved system was installed correctly. Mr. Mann, through Rev. Riley instructed the man in charge of boilers to raise steam. In his own way, he fired one boiler, raising steam in three minutes and no pressure. Only when under pressure did he light up the other boiler. Three minutes after valves were opened pressure rose and soon every radiator in building became hot right down to the trap.

Rev. Riley stated that he had never seen the system heat like that before.

Mr. Mann found the grate bars in one boiler burnt out. That tells what kind of firing plant has received.

We were informed slab wood was used at times during winter.

The trouble is either the man attending to firing in not allowed to burn enough proper fuel or he will not fire properly.

They may have the idea that the second boiler is there to be a relief when the first boiler becomes tired.

Rev. Perrier states "the heating" of school was very unsatisfactory. As this includes the firing, he is correct, but the heating system is absolutely unsatisfactory. If pressure is maintained, it is absolutely impossible for condensation to remain in radiators and freeze.
If steam supply is maintained in radi, condensation will run off by gravity as returns are open to atmosphere through air eliminator and return trap. If steam merely enters radi, and condenses a vacuum will form and condensation will be held at bottom of rad and may freeze.

We are sending this letter in duplicate so you may forward one to your head office.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Orr,

I am sending you the correspondence which has taken place between the Co. A. Dunham Co., Ltd., and myself, re the heating system for the Coqualeetza Institute. When you have read this you might return it to me in Toronto, if it reaches there before the 3rd of October, otherwise send it to Brandon.

Dear Sir:-

In further reply to your letter of October 5th., re storm windows. We will undertake to paint the sash of the storm windows.

If the Department thinks it advisable we will install them. To supervise the careful fitting however of these windows and the hanging of them is something that requires a professional carpenter.

In the long run I think it would pay the Department to engage Mr. Patten, the man who has built the Technical Building at Five dollars ($5.00) per day, I would advise this. We will provide the services of another man who is handy and careful. Also we can furnish all the boys who would be helpful in the undertaking. The windows however must be hung snugly to keep out the cold. Otherwise the effect is lost.

We should be pleased to do the work but I think a good carpenter would insure 100% efficiency.

Yours very truly,

COQUALEETZA:

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable Charles Stewart.

I beg to advise you that when the new Coqualeetza Institute was built in 1925 the Principal thought that it would not be necessary in their climate to install storm windows, and they were, therefore, not provided. Since the building has been occupied, however, it has been found that with a strong N.E. wind blowing it is very difficult to properly heat the building. The Reverend Principal has requested that storm windows be provided for the north and east sides of the school building, also for the north and east sides of the new technical building, which was erected this year, and the north and east sides of the principal's residence. Dear Sir:

A few words of explanation are necessary:

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th ultimo, enclosing receipts for expenditures you have incurred at the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School. I would point out that these accounts cover a period of six months and are in the main unauthorized by the Department. I regret that it is necessary to recapitulate the general instructions contained in letters directed to you under cover of April 7, 1922, March 10 and August 4, 1923.

You should secure authority before incurring expenditure, other than for minor repairs to buildings and mechanical plant. The Department must insist in this connection, as otherwise there would be no check on our expenditure. Accounts for minor repairs should be forwarded at least once each quarter. In an earlier letter, I suggested that you deal with one lumber firm and one hardware firm only, for a stated period. Materials which can be strictly considered repairs to plant should be included on the firm's monthly or quarterly statement. The accounts should be in duplicate and should not be paid by school cheque, but should be certified, if correct, and forwarded to the Department for payment. Cheques will then issue direct to the firms. In other words, you should not pay accounts and then approach the Department for reimbursement.

When you have special authority for expenditure, the accounts in relation thereto should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department separately, under a covering letter quoting the authority. Dear Sir:

I beg to make application for a supply of playground equipment for the use of the pupils of Coqualeetza Residential School, along the lines indicated by the Department.

The footballs sent us last year (July 22/25 was the date of the last requisition) were very helpful. The supply however, is exhausted long since, and we have purchased at least ten. On the surface one might remark - isn't that rather extravagant? It is not, considering the number who use the balls and the condition of our campus. We have three teams and they are all keen. The playground is gravelly, and the cases and seams cut quicker than on grass or sandy fields, which to some extent accounts for the extra balls used. We play from September to March, right through the rainy season which is also hard on the leather. We have very little snow and but little frost. If it were possible for you to send us ten footballs - that would be an increase of two over last year - we should appreciate it very much.

We should also like two basketballs. It is two years since we received any from your Department.

You will be pleased to know we were very successful in the last League Games. Our boys played with men throughout, beating the Chilliwack High School, the Chilliwack United Players, and Chilliwack City. They won the Championship Cup.

The Department's action in providing footballs, basketballs, etc., has been helpful to the betterment of the health, the improvement of the physique, and the recreation of the Indians.

The latter part should have read "Competitive estimates have been obtained, and the lowest estimates brings the cost of the 12 yards of concrete fence (matching the old fence) to $150.00, and the remaining 133 yards of strong wire fence with posts and gates will cost $200.00.

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT

The United Church Inspector of Indian Residential Schools writes from the Coqualeetza Institute that certain improvements are urgent at this institution. When the Estimates were being prepared, it was represented that a henhouse and a hogpen should be erected and that approximately $500 was required for repairs. These items were allowed, but other requests were noted for future estimates.

A total of $1800 is available for improvements at this school, and, in view of the recent letter of the Rev. Mr. Ferrier, I am satisfied that practically $1,000 should be expended for repairs and only one of the small out-buildings erected this year. Therefore, I wish to recommend that the Rev. Principal be authorized to undertake the following improvements:

Painting and repairing 3 outdoor dormitory buildings .. $300.
Painting and repairing the old Barn .. .. .. 300.
Flooring and decorating Principal's residence .. .. 280.
New front fence .. .. .. .. 200.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In my inspection of this institution I would like to draw your attention to the following needs by way of repairs and buildings:

(1) The construction of a Hen-House and a Hog-Pen. I have reason to believe that these have been included in the estimates for this institution, but up to date Mr. Raley has not received official notice to go on with the work.

(2) When in Ottawa I drew the attention of the Department to the Three Buildings, two of which were formerly used for dormitory purposes, and one a small cottage that was used for a farmer's home, which have all been placed side by side, contiguous to the north-west corner of the playground. The estimate for putting these in repair and painting was $300.00.

(3) The Old Barn, which was removed from the present barn site to the rear of the stables and barn, is not at all in keeping with the rest of the buildings, and needs folding doors to close it in, a floor, and a coat of paint outside. The cost of this, for material, will be about $300.00.

(4) The Principal's Home is in need of a new floor in the parlour, living room, and Front Hall. This should be of the best British Columbia fir. The cost of the flooring (nails and material) will be about $100.00. There are two bedrooms and the front hall that should be re-decorated - the cost $100.00. The Principal's home should be painted outside,-the cost of the material will be in the neighborhood of $80.00.

(5) A New Fence is a necessity on the front of the property next the public sidewalk, at each end of the present cement fence. The length of the newly required fence is 133 yards. Then it will be necessary to move the gateway further north to meet the needs of the new building, and to continue the cement fence up to that point - 12 yards in all. Competitive estimates have been obtained, and the lowest estimate brings the cost of the 12 yards of concrete fence (matching the old fence) to $150.00, and the remaining 133 yards of strong wire fence, with posts and gates to $200.00.

All these items should be attended to in the present fiscal year, and in order that they may be properly executed immediate authority should be given to the principal. I would appreciate it very much if this can receive the immediate attention of the Department, and the Principal notified accordingly.
I have requested the Principal to get plans for the Hog Pen and the Hen House, and to prepare an estimate of the cost of the same, sending this information to the Department. These buildings will not be extensive. I have suggested a Henery 100 feet long, and 14 feet wide, which will give ample accommodation for about 300 birds. The Hog Pen will only be large enough to meet the needs of about four brood sows and twenty-five or thirty pigs. This is about the usual number required for this department of farm operations.

Yours very truly,

T. Ferries

Dear Mr. Orr:

If you remember when we were building the new barn at Coqualeetza in 1923, I drew the attention of the Department to the necessity of finishing the interior. I wanted the ceiling to be put in the cow and horse stables, as without that ceiling there was rather an unfinished appearance about it. Without the ceiling I mentioned the fact that the herring-bone work and joists would catch a lot of dust and stuff where vermin and spiders could flourish. We had on the walls a covering of tongued, grooved and dressed fir. I suggested that the cow stable and horse barns should be ceiled with the same class of lumber as we had put on the walls of the barn, namely first quality tongued, grooved and dressed fir. I also wanted two coats of paint put on to the walls of the barn as an interior finish. I could not think of whitewashing this fine lumber.

The Department, however, felt that there had already been as much money as was possible at the time put into the new barn, and we were satisfied. We have kept the place clean, sanitary, and disinfected it from time to time with sprays.

A contingency, however, has arisen, upon which we have to take action. The Department of Agriculture for the Province have half-yearly T.B. tests, and at the last test a week ago, two of our cows were re-tested,-the first we have had. Of course they had to be destroyed, and the barn disinfected. We have gone through it entirely, using a spray of formaldehyde, and the Inspector instructed that we must white wash the barn, or paint it. I asked him if he would give me time to communicate with the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, to whom the barn belongs, as to what would be best for us to do, whether to put lumber on the ceiling and paint it, or just simply whitewash over it. I would strongly recommend the Department to have lumber put on the ceiling, and two coats of paint put on the walls and the ceiling. This can be done in the cow barn for approximately $200.00. We would do the work ourselves. If it was painted the paint could be washed without any trouble and the ceiling and paint would certainly add a finish to the inside of the barn which it lacks.

If you would kindly consider the matter and let me know your decision as soon as possible I shall be much obliged. If we do not paint, of course, we will have to spray with whitewash, which I do not like to put on to the dressed lumber already on the walls of the cow stable.

Thanking you for your interest,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal, which calls for departmental expenditure of approximately $1300. Funds will be available, following your requests, for the erection of a farmer's residence, the purchase of the corner lot and house and the finishing of inside store rooms at the school, if Parliament allows the items that are now in our Estimates. Dear Mr. Orr:

You will be pleased to know the improvements allowed by the Department are now complete with the exception of the hog pen and henery. These we are ready to commence, and inasmuch as the next month will be very suitable for us to undertake building, I am sending you, under separate cover, a sketch of the hog pen for your approval. Any alterations you think wise should be made, would you kindly embody them.

Enclosed herewith is a list of material we shall require. Last year Rev. T. Ferrier wrote me advising that I write to Ottawa and get official authority to purchase material and send also a sketch of the structures.

We are in great need of these buildings. The old hog pen we are using is not a credit to us and altogether out of harmony with the other farm buildings which are now a great credit to the Department. We are still using the hog pen which was built twenty or more years ago. I shall be pleased if authority could be given for the purchase of this material. All the work can be done by the management, with the exception of the wiring for the electric lighting.
