Dear Sir:

In April last, Mr. Dubberley, the assistant inspector of electrical energy, completed an inspection of the wiring of the Coqualeetza Residential School, and drew attention to the following:

"All metal non-current carrying parts throughout this building are to be permanently and effectively grounded."

I wrote to Messrs. Raynes and Horie, contractors, and asked them to advise me why this was not done when the building was erected. Messrs. Raynes and Horie replied "that they worked to the specifications and under strict supervision of the Government.............everything was in order when the work was completed."

After hearing from Mr. Horie, I wrote the inspector of electrical energy asking him to define more clearly what was required which he did. I gathered that the inspection and requirement was on account of a change in the Provincial Act since the building was erected. I immediately called for tenders from the two electricians at Chilliwack for "effective grounding" to meet the requirements.

Both came and inspected the work to be done and interviewed the inspector in Vancouver. After much delay and correspondence the work was finally given to Mr. S. Pugh whose tender in writing was $33.60. The other electrician was Mr. Marsh.

This was not referred to the Department before this work was done on account of the difficulty of getting satisfactory date and a written tender, and then when the tender was given, it was difficult to get the electrician, who is a busy man, to do consecutive work.

If in order I shall be obliged if the Department would favorably consider payment of the enclosed account.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

June 17th, 1929.

W.M. Ditchburn, Esq.,
Commissioner, Department of Indian Affairs,
Victoria, B.C.

Dear Sir:

Would it be possible for you with the help of the Department to make a small grant to Coqualeetza's Annual Field Day. We have senior, intermediate, junior and primary competitions, fifty-five events in all, three prizes in each event making 165 prizes not including cups, shields and medals, the prizes correspond to major and minor events in value.

If you could authorize a grant of $50.00 it would be most helpful, however the amount would have to be left to your judgement. Our boys and girls are exceedingly keen on athletics and are very sportsmanlike in their conduct. We cannot but show in the most practical way possible the Department is deeply interested.

You will be pleased to know our senior association football team won the Timberland Championship Cup for the Lower Fraser Division. Our second team won the Junior League Championship Cup and through the seasons games were not beaten. It would not be necessary to wait to get the cheque from the Department at Ottawa if we could have your personal interest in the matter.

Thanking you for your past favours and in anticipation

Yours sincerely,

G.H. Raley,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing copy in duplicate of account from Messrs Crane Ltd., for Grate Bars for Sectional Boiler at Coqualeetza Residential School, Sardis, B.C. I should be grateful if the Department would consider payment of the same.

The renewed bars were found to be necessary, the old bars toward the front of the boilers were burnt out. This is not to be wondered at seeing that they have been in operation for six years.

As the boilers are stationary fixtures and part of the building, they would naturally come under the item of expenditures of "Building and Repairs."

I might say in explanation this request should have been made before the expenditure was undertaken and no doubt would have been only the new engineer
insisted upon the necessity of new grate bars being placed before the cold weather. On account of the unusual severity of the winter and a couple of serious cases of illness in the Infirmary we have had to keep the boilers going day and night.

Trusting this explanation is satisfactory and that the Department will relieve the school of this item of expenditure,

Yours very truly,

G. H. Haley,
Principal.

October 30th, 1929.

Russell T. Perrier, Esq.,
Superintendent of Indian Education,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

It is necessary to build as soon as possible in connection with the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School a garage of sufficient dimensions to hold three cars 30' X 16' with three windows and three double doors.

The cost involved would be-

| Item                        | Cost   |
|-----------------------------|--------|
| 35 sacks of Cement          | $35.00 |
| Lumber, shingles, doors and windows | $45.00 |
| Hardware                    | $30.00 |
| Paint two coats             | $35.00 |
| Lighting                    | $37.00 |
| Water                       | $45.00 |
| One skilled carpenter       | $70.00 |

Total ... $397.00

To justify ourselves making this request, let me state that our manual training in the technical arts is necessarily developing and to our woodwork and blacksmith departments we have added a course in mechanical engineering including the gas engine. There are hundreds of gas motor boats used for fishing purposes owned by Indians in British Columbia. A large number of which are owned and operated by families represented at Coqualeetza. It is obvious this vocational training is more necessary for the boys of the coast villages and reserves than farming and horticulture.
especially helpful will it be for the boys of the V and VI grades who will not be able to go to the Technical High School in Vancouver and it will not be nearly so costly.

To the present time we have housed our cars in the Technical Building on the ground floor one part of which is devoted to blacksmith work. The building was originally designed for this extension in mechanical work; when the time was opportune to commence. This part used as a garage is now needed for the original design of the building.

We have three cars to take care of. One used by the Principal and the general work of the school, another by the nurse and field matron and the farm instructor who has been with us for six years has a car. No garage is rather a serious need and if the Department would assure a grant of the amount necessary I would build it at once at a safe distance from the other buildings, adequate in size and in keeping with the general plan of the school plant.

While the training in building this unit will be helpful to the boys one skilled carpenter should be employed.

Trusting my explanation is satisfactory and adequate to convince the Department of the wisdom and absolute need for such a building.

I am

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

G. H. Raley,
Principal.

Dear Sir:

I do not know what funds will be available for Coqualeetza Residential School, Sardis, this year but trust the amount necessary for the building of a farmer's residence will be authorized.

I might remind you the Department voted Three Thousand Dollars last year and gave permission at the Missionary Society of the United Church of Canada to have that amount applied to the purchase of a house and grounds five acres in the orchard belonging to Dr. White adjacent to the Department's property at Coqualeetza Residential School.

The purchase of the property valued at $7500.00 was unanimously recommended by the presbytery in British Columbia. The General Board in Toronto while in sympathy with the resolution and recognizing the advantage of securing the property for school purposes, on account of insufficient funds had to lay the matter over.

A few days ago I attended the British Columbia Missionary Committee to urge the grant be made this year. The Superintendent of Missions and the Chairman of the Missionary Committee both advised me that the fund was inadequate, so regretfully, in view of more urgent claims I thought it unwise to press the matter.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6423, file 860-5, part 2)
The co-operation of the church and the Department for several reasons was approved and advised by the Rev. T. Ferrier, Inspector of Indian Education for the United Church of Canada and the late Mr. R.H. Cairns, Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia. In endeavouring to obtain the necessary amount from the church I canvassed every influential approach possible.

I hope the Department will now authorize the work to proceed on the $3000.00 basis.

Thanking you for your interest,

Yours very truly,

March 31st, 1930.

Dear Sir:

There are some rather pressing needs which have on previous occasions been brought to the notice of the Department and which I should like to stress - some of which might be authorized this year.

GYMNASIUM. Since coming to Coqualeetza the need of a gymnasium has been felt for obvious reasons. Since we doubled our pupilage the need has been more keenly felt. We excel in our outdoor athletics. As however there is at least one half of the school year when outdoor games cannot be indulged, it is rather a serious situation. It will cost about $8,000.00 to construct the building in harmony with the general plant.

GREENHOUSE. This a unit of the original plan of the new school adopted by the government in 1923. You will remember the lowest tender for the greenhouse was $5000.00. This was more than the Department thought should be spent for such a purpose. I have made an estimate with a contractor and find that a greenhouse of the same size can be built for $2000.00 by using a wooden frame instead of iron. A year ago we lost over $1000.00 geraniums and this winter we lost 1500 plants besides much valuable garden stuff we were trying to save for bedding out this spring. On account of the large grounds and extensive gardens we have to maintain, we are handicapped for lack of this necessity.
2.

THE MAIN BUILDING of COQUALEETZA. It is now six years old and requires an expenditure of $2000.00 over-hauling plumbing and electric light systems, motors and machinery. Floors in the boys' and girls' play-rooms should be relaid. To save the floor surfaces the corridor should be revarnished and the wood work in certain parts re-painted. While the building has been kept very carefully, deterioration through lack of small annual expenditures is the last thing the Department would wish to see.

Thanking you for your favourable consideration.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

G.H. Raley,
Principal.

Reverend Sir:

I note that the plumbing and the electric light system, etc., should be overhauled at the present time, and, while a large expenditure cannot be approved in this connection, I may say that the most urgent repairs will be considered favourably, if you indicate just what is needed, with an estimate of the cost.

SARDIS, B.C.

August 13th, 1930

A. F. McKenzie, Esq.,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I beg to apply for a Grant towards the cost of transportation and camp expenses on behalf of the pupils of Coqualeetza Residential School, who have not the privilege of returning each year to their homes for holidays.

Last year we were crowded out of Ocean Park where we have camped for fifteen years, and had to seek another site. Through Mr. Indian Agent C. C. Perry we found an excellent place on the fringe of Kitsilano Indian Reserve, adjoining Kitsilano Park. Our expenses coming to Vancouver were somewhat heavier than in previous years. We remained a month at the sea-side, and the children no doubt derived inestimable benefit from the change. We have had also to purchase this year a small boat for their pleasure. I would recommend the Department increase the grant to $300. This is a very moderate request.

As you know the children from nearly all the other schools return to their homes for holidays, and the school is so much in pocket, the Department allowing for each child the per capita for the regular holiday. In our case nearly forty children do not return home, and we have to keep them, and are under that much more expense than schools where no children remain for holidays. Would you kindly consider this, and if possible allow for this year the grant of $300.

Thanking you for your interest,

Yours very truly,

G.H. Raley
Principal

In explanation of these accounts, I would not send them if the school could afford to pay them out of the grant we receive. Also, I believe you will consider them quite a legitimate expense.

No. 1 - The screens put on the windows when the building was erected have outlived their usefulness and needed renewing, especially on all windows of the basement floor.

No. 2 - The material had to be purchased rather hurriedly on account of the visit of Viscount and Viscountess Willingdon, and their party. Before making the purchase I explained over the phone the situation to Mr. Daunt, the Indian Agent, and while he could not authorize the purchase he advised it. It was the only thing to do under the circumstances, inasmuch as there was not time to spare for communication with Ottawa. The Chilliwack store had to send to Vancouver for it, and it required a skilled man to cut and lay the linoleum.

I am confident you will agree that the visit of the vice-regal party was one of those rare occasions when the prestige of the educational work of the Indian Department...
in British Columbia was at stake. The school went to some expense renovating, decorating and putting the yards, grounds and lawns into their trimmest appearance so that the setting of their visit and inspection should produce the most agreeable effect possible, and lastingly impress the pupils for whose benefit the visit was arranged. There will be only expense in connection with the visit I am asking the Department to consider payment of. The old linoleum by the constant wear and tear and the tramping of many feet daily to and from the class rooms and assembly hall, was worn and needed to be renewed. SARDIS, B.C.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Superintendent of Education,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I do not know whether I am working through the right official channel or not when it comes to requisition for major necessities in the line of building in writing to you. I know however that you will kindly have the matter of this letter placed in the proper branch.

Our wants are so numerous I have decided to list in order of importance and urgency, trusting that as many as possible will meet with the favor of the Department and find their way into the estimates. Nearly all of these items have from time to time been discussed with the Inspector of Agencies Colonel Pragnell, and also with Mr. Daunt.

BOWMAN COTTAGE. Moving the Bowman cottage, purchased by the Department last year, to a suitable location on a concrete foundation and making other improvements suggested in my letter of August 15, 1930. The Department asked me, letter #153-0-9 dated Ottawa August 23, 1930, to postpone this work till next year. $480.00

WOODSHED. As early as 1923 we made a requisition for a woodshed. Building the new school and other important items have placed this item in the background. We are however feeling the need of it as we use wood for fuel as well as coal in the buildings outside the main building. We use wood in the kitchen and bakery, and principal's house and technical building where wood furnaces are installed. The proposed shed would be 60' X 25' on a concrete wall 4' with new wood saw. Cost approximately $600.00
Mr. Ferrier - 2 -

GYMNASIUM. This matter has been brought to the notice of the Department nearly every year for the past twelve years. The need is constantly felt and since we occupied the larger building and doubled our pupilage, it is constantly a matter of regret we have not such a building for use for physical training, gymnastics and games when outdoor games cannot be indulged. I have been led to believe that we would not have to wait much longer before the situation would be relieved and a gymnasium, which is recognized as necessary, would be built. $8,000.00

INCINERATOR. Incinerator 2' 9" X 6'. Iron, firebrick with concrete base. We have, of course been burning our refuse, all paper, rags, dust and dirt of which it is natural a large quantity is swept up every day. This is not allowed to accumulate anywhere in the building. We have not yet had a very satisfactory way of disposing of it by burning. We have used extemporaneous incinerators in the hope of obtaining a permanent one. This would be built of firebrick and iron. $75.00

CONCRETE YARDS, BOYS' ENTRANCE AND GIRLS' ENTRANCE. During the Fall and Spring this is very rarely dry. It would require $300.00 girls' side, $300.00 boys' side, to make a sufficiently large yard so that the girls and boys on their respective sides would be able to line up without getting their feet wet. $600.00

PLAY GROUND EQUIPMENT. The stationary equipment and fixtures for outside games do not represent a heavy monetary investment, yet it should have immediate attention, inasmuch as we have not only to provide recreation for the short period allowed in public schools in the cities but we have to provide for the hours when the pupils are not at some duty or in the classroom. I would recommend equipment identical to that in use in the Vancouver city public schools, to consist of swings, see-saws, slides, sand bins, standards for vaulting and leaping and parallel bars and other apparatus. For the Junior boys and girls it is necessary to have a concrete small wading pool. Estimate for boys $250.00; for girls $250.00. $500.00
ELECTRIC BREAD CUTTER. I have examined these extensively as they are used for slicing in nearly all institutions where they serve at a meal 100 or more people. We have revolving knives. There is always danger of the children slicing their fingers. We have had two or three cases of rather serious cuts from this type of cutter. Then, unless the knives are kept in perfect condition they drag the bread rather than cut it. We have not found this satisfactory. The electric slicer is what we should be using. The cost is - - - $125.00

FARMER'S COTTAGE. The grant of $3,000.00 was made for this purpose in 1928 and negotiations were entered into with the Missionary Society for a grant of $4,500.00 with which to purchase the residence and property of Dr. White. This property joins the school and would have been a splendid acquisition. Believing the Missionary Society would interest itself in the project, some delay was caused pending the decision and while they approved of the scheme, the condition of the fund would not allow a grant to be made for the purpose. I might say the British Columbia delegation to the Missionary Board were all in favor of this grant being made by the Missionary Society. However, it was too late for us when the decision was given unfavorably, to think of building, consequently the grant lapsed. We referred to this matter in the Spring and I received a letter from the Acting Assistant Deputy #153-0-5 April 9, 1930, stating that a note had been made of the matter for future estimates. I would suggest a re-vote and ask that $3,500.00 be granted for this purpose $3,500.00

TERRAZO FLOORS. Terrazo floors for basement and lavatories to replace the San San laid down when the building was erected. This material was evidently not laid satisfactorily, consequently it is worn into holes, cracks and peels off. It is found in a good many places it was not laid to a sufficient thickness. We understood it should have been. The marble chipped floor we have in the dining room has proved very satisfactory. This matter, I believe, was taken up by Inspector of Agencies, Colonel Pragnell.
COVERED PLAY SHEDS. The large amount of rain in the Coast district of British Columbia makes it necessary to have a covered playground of ample dimensions to accommodate a large number of children. Otherwise, from November to March they have very little continuous play out of doors. It is not wise nor advisable that during the wet weather such a large number of children should be confined to the play rooms of the school. They are satisfactory for short periods but when it rains days at a time the difficulty of recreation is a problem unless they can get outside. These covered playgrounds would consist of a roof, supported and strongly braced, and a floor, with sides and walls to the North and East. Each would cost $750.00. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - $1,500.00

GREENHOUSE. This is a unit passed in the original plan of building the Coqualeetza School. The lowest tender then for this was $5,000.00. I have made a careful estimate with a contractor and find it can be built at half the price of the original tender. By a few changes in the structure, my estimate would be - - - - - - - - - - $2,000.00

STEAM WANGLE FOR LAUNDRY. - - - - - - - - $1,200.00

TRACTOR. Tractor for farm work with the necessary equipment, plough and disc harrow. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - $1,441.00

FRONT GROUNDS AND DRIVE. To hard surface the circular drive from the main road in front of the building and put coping around the main lawn would be a great improvement to the front of the building. This could be done for - - - - - - - - - - - - - - $1,500.00

Should you require details regarding any or all items I shall be glad to furnish any information I have. It is understood it will be impossible to get all our needs at once but as we have had only one large item outside the plant, we are hoping it will be possible to get the gymnasium this year.

Thanking you for your interest.

Yours very truly,

INSPECTION REPORT, NEW WESTMINSTER AGENCY (NO.1).

COQUELEETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I went over the school with the Principal, Rev. Raleigh. The school was not quite full. I found that the floors are going in the wash rooms and will have to be relaid shortly. The kitchen wants a steam-heater in it. The present twenty gallon cooking pots used as steamers are too heavy, cumbersome and possibly dangerous for the children and cooks to lift. An ironer is badly needed in the laundry. This, I understand has been promised. The clothes drier is far too small and a pull out cupboard one should be installed as at other schools. This is more than necessary here owing to the amount of wet and rainy weather. An electric bread slicer would also be of great use. Keys to locked doors in this school should be boxed in glass fronted boxes and placed near the locked doors in case of fire, and fire axes placed beside the fire escape doors in case of their jamming in frosty weather. This has been done at most other schools.

I examined the barn and found same clean. There were twelve cows milking, Guernseys. The pig pens were kept nice and clean. I noticed that the school has a good potato crop.

Geo. S. Pragnell.
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Dear Sir,

After going into the requirements carefully for the renovation of the electrical equipment for the different buildings in the Inst., I am able to give you the figure of Seventy Dollars and thirty cents to cover the supplies needed, work necessary to install same and repairs where such can be made. Your worst trouble is in the suspension fittings. These have been fitted with a single lock nut and bushing to a ceiling plate, which practice is not sufficiently rigid. I have allowed in my price for taking these down for rethreading so that these can be doubly locked in position. To merely tighten the present holder would be temporary work.

I would suggest, where there are no beams on the ceilings, the fitting be dispensed with altogether, replacing it with a ceiling plate fitted with a receptacle and a wire guard screwed to the ceiling. This would prevent any recurrence of the present trouble.

Should you decide on this course, my prices covers either the repair of the present fitting or installation of this cover and receptacle where the fittings are needing repairs, but does not cover the guard suggested. I might suggest that the motor on the rough mixer should be thoroughly cleaned; apparently it is in good shape but very dirty, which will lead to serious trouble if allowed to slide. To take this down and clean would cost $5.00.

I also notice The Thor Ironer is out of commission. It is not possible to give any figure on the repair of this without taking down and could only be repaired on a time and material basis.

Enclosed please find a list of repairs necessary.

With reference to the matter of the annual inspection of heating plants at the various residential schools in British Columbia, the Department has during the past several years been having these plants inspected by the Provincial Inspector of Boilers and certain fees have been paid therefor.

Reverend Sir,

Mr. Inspector G. H. Barry, in a report on his recent inspection of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, recommends that two lengths of fire hose, each 50 feet long, be supplied, one to be for use on each side. He states that the present supply of hose will not take the water to certain areas unless several lengths are joined together. The Department will approve of your arranging for the purchase of these two lengths of fire hose - each 50 feet long and of the same size as the hose at present in hand. While you should obtain a good grade of hose, it is not intended that any unnecessary expense be incurred in the purchase of same. You should forward a properly certified account, in duplicate, covering the cost.

The Inspector further recommends that a door be cut between the boys' infirmary and the boys' corridor. He states that this would allow for an approach from the boys' side direct and not the roundabout way through the girls' side, as at present. Please state your views regarding this recommendation of Mr. Barry and, also, the cost involved in having the door installed.

The Inspector also recommends that fire escape ladders be installed leading from the small boys' and the small girls' dormitories. He states that there are two iron ladders available at the school which were formerly used on the old school. The Department will approve of your arranging, as soon as possible, to have these fire escape ladders installed. The work should be done, as far as possible, by the school staff but, if necessary, the services of a bricklayer may be engaged, in which case you should forward certified accounts covering the cost of his services.

The purchase of the fire hose and the installing of the two fire escape ladders should receive your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Extract from Report of Mr. Inspector G.H. Barry, dated February 25, 1931, on his inspection of the Coqualeetza Indian Residential School.

Original on File 153-0-6.

Suggestions:

I would suggest that TWO lengths of fire hose, each 50 feet long, be supplied to the school. One to be for use on each side. The present supply of hose will not take the water to certain areas, unless several lengths are joined together. It would probably be found impossible to collect the lengths required in case of a real fire.

I would suggest that a hydrant be placed at the valve outside the front of the building, and 250 feet of suitable hose be provided for attachment to this outside hydrant.

I feel that a door should be cut between the boys' infirmary and the boys' corridor. This would allow for an approach from the boys' side direct, and not the round about way through the girls' side as at present. In the newer buildings such a door is provided in just this place. It looks to me as if it had been left out in this building by accident.

I very strongly recommend that no time be lost in the authorization of Fire Escape Ladders from the small boys' and small girls' dormitories. These small rooms I regret to say look very like DEATH TRAPS to me. There are two iron ladders available at the school. These are from an old building. The Principal states that he requires the consent of the Department for the drilling of the necessary holes in the brick work and for the services of a bricklayer.

Remarks:- The floors in the basements are very much worn. The material of which they are made does not seem to stand up well to the constant use to which it is put. There is a different material being used now in the newer schools, which I should recommend be used when the present covering is replaced.

Besides the jacket heater for domestic water and the high pressure boiler for the laundry water, there are two sectional boilers (Cast Iron Heaters) in use. One tubular boiler would probably do the work in a better way and reduce the cost of firing considerably.

In bringing this rather lengthy report to a close, may I say that the above suggestions are merely being made to raise the safety factor of the school.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith report on the above agency (New Westminster No. 8) as follows:

CO-ULETZA RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

I went over the school with the principal. There were 220 children in the school at the time of my visit, which happened to be "Founders' Day" and sports of all kinds were in full swing that afternoon. They were going to have for supper, bread and butter, fruit, cocoa and milk.

The school was clean and in excellent order, though as before reported, most of the floors are in very bad shape and should and will have to be attended to as soon as possible.

The Principal wishes to make some slight structural alteration in the matter of a doorway into the infirmary from the boys' side. This would give direct access, which is not so now.

I also went over the barns, which were well kept and in good order. The stock, pigs, cows and horses were clean well fed and looked after.

I went over the manual training school, which as I have before reported, is a great success. I was particularly pleased to see that the boys are taking up boat building. One quite a large launch for fishing purposes, was in the course of construction, and apparently, they seem to be making an excellent job of it.

The boys of the school were playing a football match against a white boys' team. These boys are really first class football players and played a good, keen and clean game. In fact, the sports and sporting instinct at this school reflects great credit upon the principal. Organized games such as take place at this school are, to my mind, a most important subject in the upbringing and forming of character amongst the young Indians; perhaps even more so than academic knowledge. Besides games, these children are trained in various other ways, such as cadets, scouts, girl guides, cubs, brownies, gardening, etc. There are now forming a library, in fact every activity and perhaps more than can be found at a high priced white boarding school. All these activities make for an excellent atmosphere in the school, and show what can be done to benefit the Indian children's training but at the same time they must entail endless work upon the principal and reflect great credit upon his organizing abilities.

Geo. S. Pragnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:

Report is herewith submitted covering the construction of water supply system to Kootenay Indian Residential School, together with summary of costs.

Work was done in accordance with that portion of Mr. W. C. Warren's report of March 4, 1931, which dealt with the development for domestic water supply only.

CONTRACT

Advertisements were published in the "Cranbrook Courier" inviting tenders for the construction of the water supply system according to plans and specifications which called for the construction of two concrete intake boxes at the springs and a reinforced concrete reservoir on the existing pump line from the school, the erection of wire fencing around the site of the springs and the installation of about 2800 feet of 3-inch pipe line from the springs to the reservoir. The contract for this work was let to Mr. A.E. Jones of Cranbrook and was signed by him on November 14, 1931. Work was started on the same day and continued until

G.E. Webb, Esq.,
District Chief Engineer,
Dominion Water Power & Hydrometric Bureau,
VANCOUVER, B.C.
December 5th when it had to be temporarily discontinued owing to non-delivery of pipe. Work was resumed on January 8, 1932, and finally completed on January 20th, on which date the system was in full operation.

The contract price for this work was $4400.00.

EXTRA WORK

Reconstruction of Reinforced Concrete Reservoir

As discussed in detail, in memorandum dated January 2nd and attached to this report as Appendix "A", it was deemed advisable to reconstruct the reinforced concrete reservoir. This was done on December 6th. The cost of this extra work was $410.72.

Cleaning of Pressure Tank

From the concrete reservoir, water is pumped to a steel tank from which it is raised by air pressure to the upper floors of the school building.

This tank I am informed, has a capacity of approximately 3,000 gallons. It is buried under about ten foot earth cover outside of the engine room of the school in the angle formed by the engine room and chapel walls. A timber lined shaft about 14 feet deep gives access to the manhole, which is located in the end of the tank adjacent to the engine room.

As this tank had not been inspected for over ten years it was considered advisable to clean it thoroughly before cutting in on the new water supply system from the springs.
The bottom of the tank was found to be covered some four inches deep with sludge deposited from St. Mary's river water. About thirty pails full of this material were removed, the interior of the tank was then thoroughly scrubbed with wire brushes and well rinsed out.

In addition to cleaning out the tank it was found necessary to reline the shaft leading to the manhole of the tank, the old lining being badly rotted.

**PUMPING ENGINE**

As instructed by you under date of November 26, 1931, the pumping engine used prior to December 2, 1931, was on that date removed and replaced by a Gilson internal combustion engine. After a short period of operation this engine proved most unsatisfactory and was replaced by a Petters atomic diesel engine which is reported to be giving complete satisfaction.

The final cost of this installation was $882.36.

**AMENDMENT OF PLANS**

During progress of construction it was considered advisable to make slight alterations in the design of the reservoir. These alterations are shown on the plan attached to this report, which plan supersedes the plan accompanying Mr. Warren's report of March 4, 1931.

Failure and Re-construction of Concrete Reservoir

Memorandum - Mr. Webb

Concrete work on the above project was put under way on November 18, when the upper intake box was installed. On November 20, concrete was poured for the lower intake box. When forms were removed from these structures the concrete was found to be of excellent quality and well set.

Temperature records for these days, taken at Cranbrook about six miles distant, show a maximum of 36 degrees and a minimum of 13. No records were available at Kootenay Indian Residential School but it lies at a considerably lower elevation than Cranbrook, has a sheltered location in the St. Mary's River valley, and, I am informed, winter temperatures at the school are always higher than at Cranbrook. From the above it is obvious that there was no danger of ill effects from frost action on the dates noted.

Conditions on the morning of November 21 were apparently not different from previous days and installation of the reinforced concrete reservoir was proceeded with. During that night however there was a very sudden drop in temperature, Cranbrook records showing a minimum of 10 degrees below zero.

This cold snap continued until after December 1, and I am informed, was altogether unexpected and most unusual so early in the winter season. Records kept by the Forestry Department in
Cranbrook show nothing like it since 1924.

Records obtained at Cranbrook by the Meteorological Service of Canada show the November mean temperature for the previous 23 years to have been 29 degrees. The mean temperature for November, 1931 was 24.2 degrees; for the first twenty days of the month it was 34 degrees, but for the last ten days it was only 4.5 degrees showing a period of exceptionally low temperature.

Toward the end of this cold snap, salamanders were placed in the reservoir to slowly thaw the concrete. In some countries, I am informed, concrete is allowed to freeze and later when thawed out, a good set is obtained. After a few days of thawing with the salamanders different portions of the forms inside the reservoir were removed and samples of the concrete aggregate secured. In no case, in my opinion, was there a satisfactory concrete set, the thawed aggregate appearing to be nothing better than packed sand and gravel. Orders were thereupon given to dismantle the reservoir and to prepare for its reconstruction.

The cold snap broke on December 2, and on December 4 the reservoir was reconstructed under favourable weather conditions. To safeguard against another sudden drop in temperature, all materials were heated, and immediately on completion of construction the reservoir was covered with straw and manure.

Fairly mild weather held for some days and it is confidently expected that the reservoir as now constructed will prove to be a structure of good workmanship.

Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 13th instant, in connection with the competition for the position of Inspector of Construction at the new Cocumleetza Indian School at Sandon, B.C., I am herewith forwarding Applications and Rating Sheets of the six applicants, together with the Notice advertising the position.

1st November, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

Some of our women patients have been making beaded leather novelties which have had a ready sale. Although beads have been quite hard to get, we seem to be able to locate small quantities here and there which keep our patients occupied, but it has been almost impossible to secure leather.

Following an enquiry, Mr. Indian Agent Howe has informed me that I could secure a number of moose hides from a Mr. J.E. McKintyre of Fort McLeod, B.C. at a cost of Six Dollars each, plus cost of transportation. I am not sure whether Mr. McKintyre is an Indian, or whether, (more likely), he is in charge of the Hudson Bay post.

Would it be possible to secure authority for the purchase of, say four, of these hides at a cost of $24.00 plus perhaps another $5.00 or $6.00 for transportation, from the "B.C. Special Vote"? It is necessary, in connection with our vocational work here, to make small outlays for material from time to time, and I would propose that we would sell leather from hides thus secured and use this small fund for financing odd purchases.

Mr. Howe says in his letter that we would not be able to get these hides until through the Christmas mail. It is quite likely too, that word should be sent north as soon as possible in order to make certain they are available for that mail. If it is necessary for you to communicate with Ottawa, I would suggest therefore, that you write by Air Mail and ask for an Air Mail reply. I am writing to Mr. Howe saying what steps have been taken.

Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia,
P. O. Box 70, Vancouver, B. C.

In reply to your letter of February 7th, file 107-9-1151, asking for information relative to vouchers #289 and #586.

The expenditure for the latter of course was authorized by the Department through your office. The hides are to be cut up and used in the making of moccasins and small miniature beaded moccasins, gauntlets, jackets etc., which are used for wear as lapel ornaments.

Voucher #289 covers an extensive list of small quantities of articles used by the patients for doing handicraft work. Such articles include wool, cotton, oilcloth, homespun, needles, thread, crochet hooks, linen and jack-knives. The jack-knives of course were for the purpose of encouraging the boys to do totem pole carving on the yellow cedar which you were able to secure for us quite some time ago. At times I have bought small quantities of poster paint for the necessary colouring of these totem poles. The varnish used to finish the articles comes from our own hospital stock. Some of the articles made with other supplies, some of which are indicated above, and which are worked on by the women and girls include stuffed dolls, stuffed oilcloth children's toys, table runners, cushion covers, small crocheted articles, shopping bags, afghans, and similar articles which do not come to mind at the moment.

I am sure the Department is not questioning the desirability of carrying on this type of work, as we have found that when our patients, especially the younger ones are doing these things they are really less active than when they are not occupied. With the supervision and encouragement of the teachers they are really carrying on much the same type of work as is done in the schools I believe, and more than once I have been given to understand that they are happier when they have something like this to do.

Actually of course I did not recall that the Department ever specifically authorized any special sum to be used for purchase of these necessary quite varied supplies, and they may feel it advisable to budget for this particular branch of our hospital work which I consider a necessary part of our treatment. Thus far of course it has been difficult to estimate the cost of such supplies during a full year.
To Major MacKay

February 12th, 1944.

Most of these are bought in small quantities and where available, of course can be much more easily obtained by personal purchase than requisition to the Department. So often the need arises without being able to anticipate a sufficient time in advance for reference to the Department.

The Department may wonder what is happening to the finished articles. Not long ago I indicated to the Department in connection with a request for supplies of small seed beads that the articles produced (mainly small novelties) were being sold. This is true of most of the other goods made by the patients. Depending somewhat on the particular item a portion of the selling price is returned to the patient, not so much as recompense for the time involved, but to provide them with a little spending money. Part is given over to the B.C. Indian Spitfire Fund, and a small proportion usually not more than five to twenty-five cents (depending on the total value) is retained by the teachers for buying additional supplies. We have adopted the procedure of paying the patient in cash at once out of this small fund we are trying to build up, so that he or she will not have to wait until the eventual sale of the article. We have found that patients are much more pleased and more cooperative when this is done. I have always taken the attitude that we are not a factory and no attempt whatever is being made to produce things on a commercial scale in spite of the fact that requests have come from many places for these "Indian articles". We cannot begin to supply these many requests.

Last fall at the Chilliwack Exhibition we had a display of our handicraft which excited a very great deal of interest, and as a result there was quite a flood of individual orders for this type of handicraft. I think we received some worthwhile publicity.

If there is anything further I can explain in connection with this part of our work I would be very glad to do so, and if any specific instructions from the Department are required they will be welcome. Thus far we have had to more or less let the work develop along the most suitable lines. Actually there is almost enough supervisory work involved not only with the patients, but with the many little financial transactions, to require the full-time of one person.

W.S. Barclay

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Major MacKay has given me the opportunity of writing this letter to you and I appreciate the privilege very much. There is so much to say in regards to the teaching and the occupational work at the Coqualeetza Hospital.

At first glance it might appear that our requirements are excessive in comparison with other Indian schools; but when it is understood that very few of the books can be re-issued on account of the presence of disease; that a large number of carefully graded and selected workbooks are essential because the children can use them without constant supervision (the teachers are with them for 30, 60, or 90 minute periods four days a week) and that any extra aids which will sharpen their interest, add to their happiness, or promote their well-being should be used, then you must feel that the actual expenditures are well justified and profitable.

It is a great consolation and inspiration in our work to see how eagerly the children look forward to their school period, and to see how splendidly they progress. It is an amazing fact that their progress parallels and often exceeds that of the pupil in the ordinary schools in the primary grades.

I shall forward a list of recent publications (selected and approved by the Vancouver School Board) which would be most interesting for the children. There is a very great need for a large library with a reading vocabulary suitable for pre-primer to grade three reader. We cannot obtain jack-knives here at all. Are there any available in the east? We need three dozen badly. If it would be possible I should also like some samples of Ontario bass-wood with the bark left on it, to try out carving bear, moose, etc.

You will be pleased to know that two of our boys won first prizes in the Kiwanis Hobby Show for Boys this week, one for wood carving and one for leather craft.
You are no doubt familiar with the project that I prepared under the supervision of Dr. Barclay for the teaching of tuberculosis control in the Indian Schools.

In closing I ask you to please look at my qualifications, my work, and my inspectors report; then compare my salary with the Teacher's Salary Schedule for British Columbia.

Yours respectfully,

Alice M. Degen
Ottawa, April 25, 1945.

Dear Colonel Neely,

Replying to your letter inquiring about our system of handling the Occupational Work, and also regarding the extra work course I am taking a course in Applied Psychology from Washington University. It was not ready until now, and to add to any delays in completing the course, my husband has been very ill with Bright's Disease and his doctor says he is liable to have continued acute attacks, which add to his partial paralysis, complicates life for us both.

Regarding our Occupational Work, I do all the bookkeeping, handle all the correspondence and fill orders, send out invoices and bills, buy all supplies either by personal purchase in Vancouver or by letters, send out samples to prospective customers, contacting personally where possible. In addition I have supplied all the women patients with materials for work, collected all finished on Thursday (which I use for occupational work of all kinds) and paying the women from goods supplied by the General Office. All bills come through my department, and purchased...
are paid by the General Office on presentation of these bills. I also pay for all Totems made by the Indian boys here, but Mrs. Reid does all work in connection with the Totems, as part of her work with them. I, of course, find markets and do all bookkeeping. She also helps in packing orders, and in any way possible, but she goes into the wards from three until eight P.M. and prepares her work besides, so she has little time to spare. Miss O'Connor teaches from twelve to one each day, taking her dinner at half past eleven, when the patients are also eating. At that time I attend to any executive work necessary, or senior teachers give out library books to my pupils. Miss O'Connor doing that for her pupils, sent the opportunity occurs. We both teach from nine to eleven thirty, and from two fifteen to four, on each school day, excepting Thursday, when I attend to correspondence, that I have mentioned above. Both bookkeeping and work mentioned above. Both Miss O'Connor and Mrs. Reid assist where and when they can, and we often do business in our own office with offenders.
Coqualeetza Indian Hospital

OCCUPATIONAL DEPT.

SARDIS, B.C.

And visitors, and we all help to prepare and pack exhibits. This year we have had a Coqualeetza Exhibit at the Vancouver Women's Hobby Show, the Chilliwack Indian Fair, and a Community Art Exhibit at the Vancouver Art Gallery. This always adds to our social work, and often means arranging the exhibit and packing it up again just to put it back for the hospital exhibit. As you can see, the selling end of our work makes a very heavy addition to the usual work of an Occupational Therapist, but it adds greatly to the contentment of our patients to have something to spend money on, and what they make here is frequently all the money they have.

Mrs. Reid is very talented in her own line, and has a very pleasing personality. She does most of her work among the young boys and girls, who need occupation and supervision outside school hours. Miss O'Brien is a good friend to every patient, as well as such a good and experienced teacher. We are all very interested in boys' work, and try to help where we can, in cooperation with the hospital staff.

Hope this short gives you a fair picture of the work of our teaching staff. Sincerely yours,

Dear Sir,

It being too late to make any remarks in my last Quarterly Report, I am pleased to let you know that at the Saanich Agricultural Fair, held here on the 28th and 29th of September, there was a prize given for Boys and girls under 14 years of age, for best penmanship. I did not know if I could compete or not, my school being an Indian school. At the last moment I concluded to do so. I had to compete against all the White schools in Saanich district; there being no names thrown on any of the writing I placed one copy book by the other writing to show what the Indian school could do. The First Prize was awarded to Michael Kelag, No. 5 on the School Register. The boy winning the prize is only 11 years old. The Indians are very much pleased about it, and I think it will help the school, for they are all going in to see who will be the best at the next examination.

I then called upon the teacher, Daniel Dick, and asked him what was the cause of the school being closed. He replied he could not get the children to attend. TO HIS EXCELLENCY

THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are twenty-three (23) Roman Catholic Indian children of school age on the Saanich Reserve, Cowichan Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia, for whom at present no educational facilities are provided;

THAT funds are available in Vote 165, 1941-42, Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, for the establishment of a day school on the Saanich Reserve.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a day school be established on the Saanich Reserve, Cowichan Agency, Province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 98, 1927, to be known as "The Saanich Roman Catholic Indian Day School".

Respectfully submitted,

Minister of Mines and Resources.
Dear Sir:

I beg to forward herewith an educational survey of the Saanich Reserves, Cowichan Indian Agency, recently completed by Inspector G.H. Barry.

This report shows that there are sufficient children of school age living on the East Saanich Reserve, at present not attending any school, to give a fair average attendance should a new school be established on that Reserve.

While in the Cowichan Agency recently, I visited the East Saanich Reserve and looked over the church building which has been suggested as suitable for use as a class room until such time as a day school can be provided by the Department. This building is quite suitable for our requirements, being sufficiently large, well-lighted, and adequately heated by a good wood-burning furnace. The rental suggested is $10 per month which, in view of the accommodation provided, is considered quite fair. There is a well with excellent water close to the church and is operated by a hand pump. This well was put in last year by the Engineering and Construction Service of the Department.

Until better arrangements can be made, the Department would be well-advised to favorably consider the establishment of a day school on the East Saanich Reserve as suggested in this report and if funds can be

The Secretary,

found to meet the cost of desks, furnishings, rent and the fuel required, I would recommend that these be obtained and the school made ready for the admission of pupils early in January. Provision would, of course, also have for the teacher's salary.

**General Remarks**

It will be seen that in general the results of the present survey bear out the conclusions come to in my former survey of the Saanich reserves.

A consolidated Indian Day School located on the West Saanich Indian Reserve would provide for the whole of the Saanich children whose education in residential schools for special reasons is not necessary.

During the continuation of the present emergency it will no doubt not be possible to find funds for the three room consolidated school and the necessary transportation by a school bus previously recommended.

There are sufficient children of school age not going to any school at present and living on the East Saanich Reserve to give a fair average attendance should a new school be established on that Reserve.

Of the 48 children on the East Saanich Reserve 17 Roman Catholic and 6 Non Catholic pupils would be available with 2 more Roman Catholic children at the moment missing but possibly in the U.S.A.

Should a day school be established in the Roman Catholic Church Hall near Saanichton, as has been suggested by the Missionaries, and the Non Catholic children not attend there would still be between 15 and 20 Roman Catholic pupils of school age available.

The establishment of a day school at Saanichton would not provide educational facilities for the Coal Bay or Patricia Bay children.
Recommendation:

I have visited the proposed school building on the East Saanich reserve, and find that the accommodation would be very suitable for a temporary school. The main room is some 40 feet by 20 feet and the lighting is very good for such a hall.

Some playground space would be necessary, and that now being offered to the Roman Catholic Church by one of the Indians if properly cleared would be I think satisfactory. There is a pump at the new building.

The new building is heated by hot air from a small heater in the basement.

There is some doubt with regard to just how the part of the Indian Reserve on which the new building stands was handed over to the Roman Catholic Church many years ago, for the new building is on the actual site of the former Roman Catholic Church here.

Before a temporary Indian day school is authorized at Saanichton I believe it would be well to obtain from the East Saanich Band a surrender of the site of the hall and playground in favour of the Roman Catholic Church as represented by His Excellency the Bishop of Victoria.

At least two dozen single school desks would be needed for the proposed school, as well as some blackboards and a teacher's desk and chair. The necessary furniture of such a school as I have in mind would not cost more than $200.00 Some fuel would be required for heating the building and of course the salary of a teacher would have to be provided.

I am very anxious that some education be provided for as many of the Saanich Indians as possible and considering the need for economy I would recommend that favourable consideration be given to the establishment of an Indian day school on the East Saanich Indian reserve in the building suggested by Rev. Joseph Cyre S.J.

Though it is not mentioned I may say that a suitable rental for the building while occupied as a school would be $10.00 a month.

I would further recommend that if a school be established as suggested the academic year be one of eight months only, from October 1st to May 31st yearly.

Nanaimo B.C.
October 26th 1941.

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Establishment of a day school for Roman Catholic Indian children on the Saanich Reserve, Cowichan Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia.

In a letter dated November 28 Indian Commissioner MacKay encloses an exhaustive report made by Inspector Barry regarding lack of educational facilities on the Saanich Reserve.

There is no school on the Saanich Reserve at the present time and it is evident from the report that there are at least twenty-three (23) children of school age who are not receiving any education. Dear Sir:

As you know I have striven consistently to avoid making any financial requests to the Indian Department since the world war broke out for we all realize the grave necessity of practising the utmost economy all along the line. However I feel confident that it is still the aim and purpose of the Government to keep the educational services functioning at least at a minimum. This is why I felt considerable relief when finally the new chapel at the West Saanich Reserve was taken over to be used for school purposes on behalf of Indian children who were in crying need of attention.

But there are still a score of children of school age in or near the Cole Bay Reserve who have positively no attention and naturally what has been done at long last for the West Saanich Reserve only serves inevitably to emphasize the more the dereliction of their conditions making the parents of these latter resentful and providing a subject of perpetual criticism of the Department by the many whites who take what after all must be construed as a well meant interest in the fate of their Indian neighbors. I appreciate the predicament of the Department and no matter what be the decision, will do all in my power to explain the inequalities of treatment that war may sometimes necessitate but, it will do no harm to express an opinion as to what might prove a solution to the problems of this area so long the cinderella of the Island.

The East Saanich School is small and in poor repair, the West Saanich School while new is as we know in the nature of things only a temporary arrangement though a good one under existing circumstances, so I feel that the eventual solution of the problems for the area as a whole would be a new consolidated school to which the children from East and West Saanich, as well as Cole Bay and Patricia Bay could be brought. If the sisters could be persuaded to take it over, the results would be first class.
Obviously there can be no question of a consolidated school now and from what I can gather there is no room for the Cole Bay children in either the East or West Saanich schools, so I believe the best alternative would be to rent some temporary structure at Cole Bay and use it as a school until the war situation has cleared up. Personally I am not very conversant with the cost of transportation in such cases but with the present gas and tire situation I fear it would not be economical nor, perhaps, after a time even possible.

I wish the department to understand that I wholeheartedly appreciate the difficulties they have to contend with but hope that somehow, at least, a temporary solution may be somehow available.

With every good wish,

Yours in Christ,

"John C. Cody"
Bishop of Victoria.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 20th instant, file number above noted, with reference to educational matters on the Saanich I.R.'s, I wish to advise that from your letter it would appear that I am just supposed to reply to the matters referred to in the letters attached to yours, with the added information or rather my views on the suggestion that a school be established on the Saanich I.R. #5, on a temporary basis.

(1). I am definitely against the establishment of a school at Cole Bay, either on or off the I.R., for various reasons any one of which I think is sufficient at the present time. (a) Only 20 children of school age on this reserve, 8 of which are already at Kuper Island School and would probably have to remain there anyway as it is doubtful if home conditions would be satisfactory for them to attend a day school. 2 of the 12 remaining are sickly with T.B. and would have been in the Coqualeetza Hospital now if the parents would consent. This leaves a total of 10 children available for day school and it is reasonable to expect that the average attendance would not be more than 6. (b) There is no suitable building on the Reserve and certainly none available off the Reserve as every where else is occupied with war workers at the Patricia Bay Air Station as well as wives and families of the airmen stationed there. Then again, the authorities have already closed the Sidney High School on account of its location and contiguousness to the Airport and it would certainly not be permitted for us to open a school near the Cole Bay Reserve that could be used by the children of No 4 I.R. (if there happened to be any—which there are not at the moment although there will be one boy next year). (c) Indians living on Cole Bay Reserve are the worst drifters of any in the Agency, they generally leave the Reserve very early in the Spring and don't come back until Christmas, so that actually there is just a period of about 4 or 5 months in the year that we may expect a 75% attendance of school children at any school except the Residential School which opens before the parents go Hop picking.

(2). The exact distance between the Cole Bay I.R. and the Tsartlip School is 4 miles and while the approximate cost of transportation would be sixty or sixty five dollars per month, I am not entirely satisfied that this would be the solution, although I believe that it would be the best unless having the children attend Residential School. There will be ample room for all the children at Cole Bay to attend Tsartlip School, if they could get there, but unless proper transportation facilities are provided, where the children are protected by insurance I will not recommend any haphazard method such as used in this Agency at Nanaimo prior to this year.

(3). Personally, I feel that where the parents of the children are unable to support them properly, and provide food and clothing for them regularly and all the time during the winter months, we ought as well have those children sent to the Residential school where they will be properly cared for and nourished. It may cost a little more but in the long run will be cheaper. When we take into consideration the number of children attending day schools now in the Agency whose parents are unable to support them properly, and another, and the shoes and clothing that they require when they may attend school, I believe...

Mr. Moore is evidently of the opinion that, the ten children mentioned above could be easily accommodated at the Tsartlip Indian Day School, West Saanich, if transportation were provided, the Tsartlip school being located about 4 miles from Cole Bay. Mr. Moore further estimates that the approximate cost of this transportation at between $60.00 and $65.00 per month.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box 70-
VANCOUVER, B.C.
Major D.M. MacKay

March 4, 1942.

During the present emergency, there is no certainty that gas and tires would be available for the motor vehicle used in the transportation of the Cole Bay children to Tsartlip School, and in any case I am not prepared to recommend the establishment of any school bus service in Saanich at the present time, apart from the fact that I am not at all convinced that there would be accommodation at Tsartlip for these children.

A short time ago I recommended that Indian boys and girls attending Residential Schools on or near the coast might, under certain circumstances, be discharged on reaching their fourteenth birthday, in order that such children might engage in the fishing industry. Should the Department approve of my suggestion, it is quite possible that several boys and girls would, in the near future, be discharged from the Kuper Island Residential School. The vacancies caused by such discharges as I have referred to above, might well be filled by some, at least, of the Cole Bay children now in need of education.

For the reasons given above I am not prepared to recommend provision of day school facilities for the small number of children at present available on the Saanich Indian Reserve No. 3.

Yours very truly,

G. H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools in B.C.

Indian Commissioner for B.C., P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

During a recent visit to the Saanich Indian Day School, I wish to advise that the closing date of this school for the summer holidays was brought to my attention by the Teacher. I told her that as far as I knew it would close at the end of May next but in view of the fact that it opened a month late after the Christmas holidays, I would recommend to you that it be kept open until the end of June, providing she (the Teacher) was reasonably sure that the attendance would warrant it during June.

She informed me that the question had already been taken up with some of the parents and the general opinion was that very few, if any, of the families with children of school age would be going to the U.S. this summer to pick berries as they could do better at home. This corresponds with the feeling among the Indians pretty well throughout the Agency. I would therefore recommend that this school be kept in operation until the end of June next.

I may say for your information that this Teacher, Miss Wadel, is certainly making an improvement all round in that school. She has planted a small school vegetable garden, also some flowers along the walks, not to mention the general cleanup outside the building. However, her good work does not end there as she has got the pupils right on their toes and for once they seem to be learning something, not to mention the art of cleanliness. I would say Miss Wadel is a very satisfactory teacher.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Ontario.
